headline: Lahore Journal; Pride of the Moguls and the Pride of Punjabis Still
abstract: LEAD: There are two Punjabs now, one on each side of the India-Pakistan frontier. But there is only one Punjabi city with the power to fire the Punjabi intellect and enslave a Punjabi heart. That city is Lahore.

headline: Shahid Tammtk Journal; The Bounty of the Desert: Tomatoes and Rebellion
abstract: LEAD: On a patch of oasis here, a seemingly endless sea of sand is broken by a clump of lush greenery that provides subsistence, if barely, for thousands of people.

headline: Mural Draws Shultz's Fire On Quito Trip
abstract: LEAD: A giant mural on a wall of the Ecuadorean Congress that seems to equate the Central Intelligence Agency with Nazism was sharply criticized by Secretary of State George P. Shultz today as he arrived here for Ecuador's presidential inauguration.

headline: Worker Buyouts
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Greece Issues Photos of Suspects in Ship Siege
abstract: LEAD: Greece said today that it had obtained the photographs of four suspects in the terrorist attack aboard an excursion ship in the Saronic Gulf on Monday and that it had identified two of them. The Government said it did not know the whereabouts of the attackers.

headline: Swiss Seek 2 in Stock Case
abstract: LEAD: A Swiss judge said today that he had issued arrest warrants for two more suspects in a $250 million fraud case involving bogus stock shares sold to thousands of investors in many countries. Judge Laurent Kasper-Ansermet refused to disclose the names or nationalities of the latest suspects.

headline: U.S. and Soviets Discuss Curbing Missile Exports
abstract: LEAD: American and Soviet officials today held their first in-depth discussions of ways to curb the spread of ballistic missiles to the third world.

headline: Inflation Peril In China Seen
abstract: LEAD: The American economist Milton Friedman warned China today that soaring inflation could cripple its economy unless steps were taken to speed the conversion of state-run enterprises to private ownership.

headline: Cuban Lists Conditions for Angola Troop Pullout
abstract: LEAD: Cuba will start to withdraw its troops from Angola only after South Africa begins to carry out a long-stalled United Nations plan for independence in neighboring Namibia, the chief Cuban negotiator in the talks on the Angolan conflict said here today.

headline: Yeutter Sees Slow Exports
abstract: LEAD: The growth in United States exports will probably slow as many industries reach production capacity, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   9.50   9.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   7.88   7.87   6.64        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.82   6.75   5.80        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.09   7.03   6.03        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.93   8.95   8.39        30-YR.

headline: Malaysian Founder 'Disgusted' at Successor
abstract: LEAD: At 85 years of age, Prince Abdul Rahman, who presided 31 years ago over the founding of independent Malaysia and later called himself ''the happiest Prime Minister in the world,'' pronounced himself a disappointed man today.

headline: Alitalia Loses Its Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Umberto Nordio, chairman of Italy's state airline Alitalia, resigned today after a public dispute with the airline's state-run parent company over management strategy, Alitalia said in a statement.

headline: WESTERN SAHARA MAY GET U.N. TEAM
abstract: LEAD: The United Nations has proposed sending a peacekeeping force of about 2,000 soldiers and administrators to the Western Sahara as part of a plan for ending the war there between Morocco and the Polisario guerrillas, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

headline: Center-Left Coalition Takes Office in Iceland
abstract: LEAD: A new center-left Government headed by former Prime Minister Steingrimur Hermannsson took office today, decreeing a price-wage freeze and devaluing the currency.

headline: More Texas Banks Fail
abstract: LEAD: The record for Texas bank failures in a year has been broken slightly more than halfway through 1988. Federal regulators declared three more Texas banks insolvent on Thursday and also decided to count the 40 former subsidiary banks of the First Republicbank Corporation as failed institutions.

headline: Gould's Hong Kong Plan
abstract: LEAD: Gould Inc. said today that a joint venture it owns equally with the Nippon Mining Company would build a plant in Hong Kong to produce copper foil used in printed circuit boards. Gould, an electronics company based here, said it is building the plant in response to increased demand from markets in Southeast Asia and China.

headline: Buried Bomb Kills 8 Libyans
abstract: LEAD: A World War II bomb buried in a field in northern Libya blew up, killing a family of eight, the official Libyan press agency said today. The agency, monitored here, said the 650-pound bomb exploded Saturday in Ban al Zaytun. The agency did not say how it was set off.

headline: German Savers Join Mark Exodus
abstract: LEAD: Worried about having interest on their savings taxed at the source, West Germans have joined foreign investors in a significant exodus out of mark deposits.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Martin Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: The Martin Agency of Richmond, a subsidiary of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which in turn is part of the Ogilvy Group, has signed a letter of intent to acquire Market Source, also of Richmond. Martin plans to merge Market Source, which specialized in direct response services, into the Steinrich Group, its own direct-response company.

headline: Members of Coalition Win 58% in Thai Vote
abstract: LEAD: Parties that formed Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda's coalition Government won 58 percent of the votes in Sunday's parliamentary elections, paving the way for General Prem's return to power, official results showed today.

headline: Catalyst Gets Bid By Pickens's Son
abstract: LEAD: The Catalyst Energy Corporation, an independent power producing company that owns or leases generators, said yesterday that it had received a bid of $10.75 a share from Thomas B. Pickens 3d of Dallas, the son of T. Boone Pickens.

headline: SOVIETS QUESTION A BALTIC PROTOCOL
abstract: LEAD: In a rebuff to people in the Baltic republics, Soviet officials insisted today that there is no conclusive evidence that Stalin and Hitler secretly agreed to Soviet annexation of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

headline: HERTZ ADMITS USE OF FRAUD IN BILLS FOR AUTO REPAIRS
abstract: LEAD: The Hertz Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding 110,000 customers and other motorists and insurance companies by charging them inflated and sometimes fictitious collision-repair costs.

headline: Shaky Start for Rocket Business
abstract: LEAD: Even before the nation's commercial space-launching industry lofts its first payload into orbit, it faces severe problems from intense foreign competition and weakening demand for its services.

headline: Prospects; Book Houses Consolidate
abstract: LEAD: The publishing industry witnessed further consolidation last week when Random House Inc. agreed to buy the Crown Publishing Group. Once an industry made up of dozens of independent, family-run companies, book publishing is now dominated by six major companies: Advance Publications, Hearst, MCA, the Pearson Group, Bertlesmann A.G.

headline: Canadian Church Approves Homosexual Ministers
abstract: LEAD: In a move that threatens to split the country's largest Protestant denomination, the governing council of the United Church of Canada has voted to admit homosexual men and women into the clergy.

headline: BRAZIL COMPLETE NEW CONSTITUTION
abstract: LEAD: Lawmakers finished work early today on a new Brazilian Constitution that replaces the charter drawn up two decades ago by generals.

headline: Iraq Voices Strong Doubts On Iran's Good Intentions
abstract: LEAD: Iran's acceptance of a United Nations cease-fire resolution was greeted with surprise and skepticism today by Iraqi officials, but they stopped short of rejecting the move.

headline: Conflict-of-Interest Rules Ignored, Pentagon Aides Tell House Panel
abstract: LEAD: Both Defense Department officials and private consultants have widely ignored some regulations intended to prevent conflicts of interest in weapons purchases, the Pentagon's inspector general testified today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Warner-Chilcott, a generic pharmaceutical division of Warner Lambert, to Daniel Glassman Advertising, Fairfield, N.J.

headline: Jury Finds Southmark Liable in a Civil Suit
abstract: LEAD: A California jury has found the Southmark Corporation liable for more than $130 million in damages in a civil suit brought by a San Diego businessman and his wife, the company said today.

headline: Sony Profits Soar Fivefold
abstract: LEAD: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that its profit soared fivefold in its first quarter on the strength of a ''gratifying sales performance'' and successful cost reductions.

headline: Markets Closed
abstract: LEAD: Federal, state and local government offices were closed yesterday because of the Labor Day holiday. The stock and commodity markets, banks and many businesses were also closed.

headline: Dime Savings Bank To Buy Starpointe
abstract: LEAD: The Dime Savings Bank of New York said it had reached an agreement to buy Starpointe Savings Bank, based in Plainfield, N.J., for $21 a share, or about $63 million. The acquisition gives Dime greater access to the New Jersey market for retail deposits, which the company views as the logical extension of its New York operations, Harry W.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 5, 1988:  WEDNESDAY

headline: Patents; The Jukebox Concept Applied to Music Video
abstract: LEAD: ''Everybody said I was an idiot,'' said Steven Peters, founder of Miami-based Video Jukebox Network. ''But it works.''

headline: Leader Booed in Mexican Congress
abstract: LEAD: Interrupted repeatedly by the jeers and chants of newly strengthened opposition parties, President Miguel de la Madrid delivered his final state-of-the-nation address today. He defended the disputed presidential election in July as totally ''in accordance with the Constitution and the electoral laws of the republic.

headline: U.S. AIDES CAUTIOUS ON AIRBUS INQUIRY
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration and Congressional leaders reacted cautiously today to a news report that a military investigation would show that mistakes by the crew aboard an American warship in the Persian Gulf were responsible for the downing of an Iranian airbus a month ago.

headline: Tax-Free Shopping Planned For Foreigners in Louisiana
abstract: LEAD: Louisiana will offer tax-free shopping to foreign visitors under a bill approved by the Legislature and sent to Gov. Buddy Roemer. He is expected to sign the bill, to be effective Jan. 1.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Dow Falls 16.54 to Close at 2,106.15 By LAWRENCE J. DeMARIA
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices fell yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 16.54 points to close at 2,106.15.

headline: Ranieri Firm Ousts Partner
abstract: LEAD: The Wall Street firm set up in March by Lewis S. Ranieri, the former vice chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc., has dismissed one of its five partners.

headline: Columbo Yogurt
abstract: LEAD: The Columbo yogurt business, formerly handled by the Boston office of Della Femina McNamee WCRS, has returned to Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, which had the business for about two years before losing it six years ago. The brand's distribution is largely in the Northeast. Billings are about $3 million.

headline: Reagan Reiterates Support for Cypriot Chief
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan, in a 30-minute meeting with President George Vassiliou of Cyprus today, endorsed United Nations efforts to negotiate a resolution to the 14-year conflict that has divided the island's Greeks and Turks.

headline: Bank Bailouts
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Though Unofficial, Change Is in the Air For U.S.-Hanoi Ties
abstract: LEAD: It was the Minuteman statue in Concord at the site of the opening battle of the Revolution that most impressed Le Luu, the first writer from Communist Vietnam to visit the United States since the end of the Vietnam War in 1975.

headline: CIVIC ENVOY: Toshio Nagamura; A Japanese Banker's Bid to Cement U.S.-Japanese Ties
abstract: LEAD: IN his dark blue suit, slicked-back black hair and quiet formal manner, Toshio Nagamura might seem at first like the typical Japanese businessman in America, astute but essentially detached from the American environment.

headline: I.R.A. Bombing in London Kills 1 British Soldier and Wounds 10
abstract: LEAD: In the first Irish Republican Army attack on the British mainland in four years, a British soldier was killed today and 10 others were wounded in a bomb explosion at an army barracks in North London.

headline: Olympia & York's Campeau Holdings
abstract: LEAD: The Toronto-based real estate concern, Olympia & York Developments Ltd., said it had raised its stake in the Campeau Corporation to 28.4 percent, from 27.3 percent.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chairman Appointed For First Nationwide
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company yesterday named Robert E. Lackovic chairman and chief executive of the First Nationwide Financial Corporation. He has had responsibility for the company's operations since February when the top position became vacant.

headline: Chiat President For New York
abstract: LEAD: Jay Chiat, chairman and chief executive of Chiat/Day, announced yesterday that Jane Newman had been promoted to president of the New York office.

headline: Asia Lab to Help Grace Keep Up With Japanese
abstract: LEAD: Kiichiro Sasaguri, a Japanese polymer scientist who last week opened W. R. Grace & Company's first research laboratory in Asia, sees himself as an international ''bridge'' between the business and scientific worlds.

headline: Walesa Takes to Coal Country To Press for an End to Strikes
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, went to the Silesian coal fields today to try to persuade striking coal miners to follow the lead of Gdansk shipyard workers and return to their jobs.

headline: Stocks Modestly Higher in Slow Trading
abstract: LEAD: Investors shrugged off a flow of positive news yesterday and the stock market closed modestly higher. It was the third-slowest trading day of the year, with 123.3 million shares changing hands, down from 136.1 million on Friday.

headline: Dollar Up Sharply on Rate Rise
abstract: LEAD: The dollar soared against major foreign currencies yesterday, propelled by an unexpected half-point rise in the Federal Reserve Board's discount rate to 6 1/2 percent.

headline: Caribbean Nations to End Trade Barriers in Region
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of 13 Caribbean nations agreed today to remove nearly all barriers to trade within the region by Oct. 1, Deputy Prime Minister Lester Bird of Antigua announced.

headline: Nicaraguan Cancels Planned Trip to U.S. Over a Visa Dispute
abstract: LEAD: Nicaragua announced tonight that President Daniel Ortega Saavedra would not visit the United States as planned in the coming days because the State Department had refused to grant visas to all members of his 60-member delegation.

headline: SCORES ARE KILLED IN AIR SHOW CRASH IN WEST GERMANY
abstract: LEAD: Three jets from a precision flying team of the Italian Air Force collided and crashed today during a low swoop past a crowd of 300,000 at a United States air base in West Germany, killing at least 46 people and injuring as many as 500 others. Many of the injured suffered serious burns.

headline: Orders Up By 6% for Durables
abstract: LEAD: Orders for durable goods rose 6 percent in August, suggesting to analysts that recent signs of sluggishness in the economy were probably temporary.

headline: Martin Marietta
abstract: LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation said it would realize about $140 million in after-tax profits from the sale of its interest in a London-based computer services company. Martin Marietta, which has aerospace, computer, construction and defense operations, recently sold its 68.3 percent interest in Hoskyns Group P.L.C.

headline: OPEC Leader to Travel
abstract: LEAD: OPEC's secretary general, Subroto, will visit Iran, Iraq and Kuwait later this month, the oil group said today, The visit is apparently being made in hopes of finding a way to drive up oil prices. A spokesman for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Kemal Saiki, said Dr. Subroto was likely to make his tour in the last 10 days of August, the OPEC News Agency reported.

headline: U S Sprint To Cut Loss In 3d Period
abstract: LEAD: In the first clear sign of a turnaround, the U S Sprint Communications Corporation plans to report that its operating losses decreased sharply in the third quarter, its parent company, United Telecommunications Inc., said yesterday.

headline: Television Ads Show 7.9% Rise
abstract: LEAD: Commercial television advertising grew 7.9 percent, to $11.83 billion, in the first half of 1988, from $10.96 billion a year earlier, according to the Television Bureau of Advertising.

headline: 770 Jobs to Be Cut By Union Pacific
abstract: LEAD: The Union Pacific Railroad said it would close its repair shops in Omaha and move their operations to the railroad's newer shops in North Little Rock, Ark. Railroad officials told the 770 workers at the Omaha locomotive and car shops that they would lose their jobs beginning in 90 days.

headline: Tax Watch; Review Advised For Pension Plans
abstract: LEAD: MANY employers face sharply higher pension costs as of Jan. 1 because of changes mandated by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, warns Frederic S. Kramer, a lawyer and editor for the Research Institute of America who specializes in pension plans and employee benefits.

headline: Chemical Bank Names 2
abstract: LEAD: Chemical Bank said yesterday that Barbara D. Capsalis and William C. Pierce had been appointed to its management committee. Mrs. Capsalis, who has been senior vice president in charge of the financial services division, was named chief technology officer. Mr. Pierce is the bank's chief credit officer.

headline: Drexel Sees Shift by S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. told its employees Friday that it could no longer be certain that it would receive 24 hours' notice before the Securities and Exchange Commission brought charges against it.

headline: Freddie Mac Is Offering $650 Million in Securities
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, also known as Freddie Mac, is offering $650 million of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities, or Remics. The securities are backed by 9 percent Freddie Mac mortgage participation certificates provided by Bear, Stearns & Company.

headline: Patents; Skiers' Speedometer Based on Doppler Effect
abstract: LEAD: Peter Purdy, the founder of Insight Inc. in Seattle, has patented an ultrasonic speedometer for skiers.

headline: Business Digest: Thursday July 28, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Directors of Scherer Postpone Vote Count in Proxy Fight
abstract: LEAD: A proxy fight for control of the R. P. Scherer Corporation was left undecided at the annual shareholders meeting today when directors delayed the counting of votes until next Wednesday.

headline: Promising Signs for Fall Retail Sales
abstract: LEAD: Merchants across the nation are hoping that retail sales for the fall season will return to the solid beat they had before the October stock market crash, after which many Americans cut back on their buying. But while the signs so far are vaguely promising, they are not uniformly encouraging.

headline: U.S. Aid to Uranium Mining Meets Political Resistance
abstract: LEAD: Largely hidden from press and public attention by its complexity, a plan to revitalize the depressed United States uranium-mining industry with huge injections of public money has quietly won approval in the Senate and awaits action in the House.

headline: After Storm, Jamaica's Have-Nots Have Less
abstract: LEAD: Beverly Smith looked despairingly at the empty cast-iron cooking pots in the outdoor kitchen that she and her seven children and grandchildren share with the family of nine next door.

headline: Market Place; Bullish Views On Some Stocks
abstract: LEAD: ONE antidote to summer doldrums on Wall Street is drawing up lists of stocks expected to outperform the market in the next 6 to 12 months. The Standard & Poor's Corporation, which is cautious about the market's prospects, and Prudential-Bache Securities, which is bullish, have recently announced their picks.

headline: Pope Preaches Peace on Mozambique Visit
abstract: LEAD: Victims of Mozambique's civil war sat in wheelchairs by an altar today as Pope John Paul II preached reconciliation and nonviolence at one of the largest gatherings of his tour of southern Africa.

headline: Patents; 'Smart Card' Keeps Track Of Betting
abstract: LEAD: The Gtech Corporation, the nation's largest supplier of computer systems for state-run lotteries, has developed a computerized ''smart card'' for gamblers to use to keep track of their bets.

headline: Layoffs at Tonka
abstract: LEAD: The Tonka Corporation said it had laid off 110 employees in a restructuring of its Kenner Products and Tonka toy divisions. In cutting the 87 full-time and 23 part-time employees Wednesday, Tonka cited disappointing sales of its once hot Pound Puppies line and other Tonka products as well as a need to eliminate overlapping responsibilities with Kenner Parker Toys, which it recently acquired.

headline: Tandem-Nynex
abstract: LEAD: Tandem Computers Inc. said it had entered an agreement with Nynex Information Solutions Group Inc. under which the New York company will integrate and market Tandem products in large-scale systems aimed at the finance, manufacturing and telecommunications industries. Nynex Informations Solutions is a subsidiary of the Nynex Corporation, the telephone operating company in the New York area.

headline: European Allies Put Pressure on the U.S. To Pay Its U.N. Dues
abstract: LEAD: Britain, West Germany and several other allies of the United States said today that they would not help the United Nations out of its financial difficulties because to do so would reduce pressure on Washington to pay its back dues.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  MARKETS  Drexel Burnham Lambert was charged with a two-year scheme of illegal insider trading, defrauding clients, stock manipulation and other securities violations. Some of the long-awaited charges by the S.E.C. were more severe than had been anticipated. Four Drexel employees were named, including Michael Milken, the head of its junk-bond department, whose lucrative deals have been responsible for the firm's enormous growth within the last decade.

headline: Budget Outlook Called Brighter
abstract: LEAD: Reflecting unexpectedly robust economic growth, the Congressional Budget Office announced today that it had revised sharply downward its projection for the budget deficit in the 1989 fiscal year.

headline: Investment Group Seeks Diasonics
abstract: LEAD: An investment group led by Integrated Resources Inc., the New York financial services concern, has offered to purchase all of the shares of Diasonics Inc. that it does not own for $3.12 a share, or a total of about $206 million.

headline: Market Place; The 'Greenhouse' Impact on Energy
abstract: LEAD: IF the ''greenhouse effect'' pushes temperatures up and rainfall down, which way will energy stocks move? Some analysts on Wall Street believe a global rise in temperatures could attract new interest in fuels and energy technologies that produce little of the ''greenhouse gases.''

headline: Ruling Party Sweeps to Victory in Singapore
abstract: LEAD: The ruling party won a sweeping victory today in a parliamentary election that was described here as a vote of confidence in a new generation of leaders.

headline: Arab Said to Have Killed Israeli
abstract: LEAD: A 25-year-old West Bank Palestinian man has confessed to strangling an Israeli teen-ager to death and then burning her body last month, the police said today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Thousands of Western Books Placed on Exhibit in Moscow
abstract: LEAD: Dozens of Soviet citizens got a chance to browse through stacks of American books today at a trade exhibit in Moscow.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Keye/Donna 'Musical' for New Suzuki
abstract: LEAD: ''IT was our first musical,'' said Leonard Pearlstein, describing Keye/Donna/Pearlstein's commercial for Suzuki's new four-wheel-drive vehicle, the Sidekick.

headline: Market Place; Why Discounters Are Consolidating
abstract: LEAD: INVESTORS who like the discount store concept may have to re-evaluate their favorites in view of a new consolidation trend sweeping that industry. Often this involves the acquisition of a weaker company by a stronger one, with a risk that the combination will not produce a winner.

headline: Dow, in Strong Rebound, Rises 37.34
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rebounded strongly yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average back above the 2,000 mark.

headline: Questions Push Regina Stock Down
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Regina Company, the vacuum cleaner maker, resigned yesterday, and the company reported that its financial statements for the fiscal year ended June 30 were ''materially incorrect.''

headline: Rises in Local Costs Trail U.S. Rate
abstract: LEAD: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July, but price increases so far this year have stayed below the national average for the first time in six years.

abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   6.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.13   8.11   6.63        3-MO. headline: 2 Czechoslovak Delegations Will Soon Be Sent to Israel
abstract: LEAD: Czechoslovakia, which has had no diplomatic relations with Israel since 1967, will soon send two delegations to that country to deal with consular and economic matters, an Israeli spokesman said today.

headline: About Real Estate; Residential Use of Jersey Industrial Land
abstract: LEAD: Vacant industrial land may seem an unlikely place for a large low-rise condominium development with a health club, tennis courts and jogging trails. But just such a project, the Hampton Club with 650 units, is under construction in an industrial park in New Brunswick, N.J.

headline: Guilty Plea in Intelsat Fraud
abstract: LEAD: The former No. 2 executive of Intelsat pleaded guilty Friday to conspiracy to defraud the global satellite giant of $4.8 million.

headline: Soviet Parley Called 'No Threat to Gorbachev'
abstract: LEAD: Soviet officials said today that a meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee hastily scheduled for Friday did not signal that Mikhail S. Gorbachev was in political trouble.

headline: Norway Oil Output Cut
abstract: LEAD: Norway's North Sea oil production dropped to 1.06 million barrels a day in August from 1.17 million barrels in July because of maintenance work on a production platform, a survey found. Norway is Western Europe's biggest oil producer after Britain. Although it is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Norway has agreed to 7.5 percent cutbacks since February 1987 in support of OPEC's efforts to stabilize prices by limiting supply.

headline: Larizza Industries
abstract: LEAD: Larizza Industries said it had provided certain information to a number of parties who might be interested in possible acquisition of the company or a portion of the company's assets. Larizza manufactures plastic products, electronic components and valve and pipe fittings. Larizza said none of the parties had made an offer and there were no negotiations under way with such parties.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Tarlow Given Account Of Fidelity Brokerage
abstract: LEAD: Fidelity Brokerage Services, a discount brokerage subsidiary of Fidelity Investments, Boston, has taken its $2 million print account to Tarlow Advertising.

headline: In Gdansk, a Growing Sense of Futility
abstract: LEAD: Clattering in toward central Gdansk from Nowy Port to the northwest, the No. 10 tram lurches along right under the sooty brick walls and idle, rusty cranes of the Lenin Shipyard.

headline: Israelis Kill 2 Prisoners in Riot
abstract: LEAD: Israeli troops fired on hundreds of rioting Palestinians at a Negev Desert prison camp today, killing two, the army said. Page A10.

headline: Palestinian Factions Divided On Forming a State in Exile
abstract: LEAD: Syrian-backed opponents of Yasir Arafat are opposing the establishment of a Palestinian government in exile, thus deepening a Palestinian split at a time of increased uncertainty over the future of the Israeli-occupied territories.

headline: Savings Unit Acquired
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has announced that the Loves Park Federal Savings Bank of Loves Park, Ill., has been acquired by the Home Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rockford, Ill. Loves Park is the 106th troubled savings institution to be disposed of this year. Home Federal received $4.9 million in assistance from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

headline: Godfather's Pizza Sold By Pillsbury
abstract: LEAD: Beset by management defections and disappointing results in its restaurant group, the Pillsbury Company said today that it had sold Godfather's Pizza Inc. to an investor group led by the chain's management.

headline: Soviets Send Dissident On First Leg of Exile
abstract: LEAD: An Armenian dissident, expelled from the Soviet Union, said that he was forced to fly to Ethiopia under K.G.B. guard, but that he won a promise after a hunger strike that his family could join him in the West.

headline: American Standard
abstract: LEAD: Finmeccanica Societa Finanziaria Meccanica S.p.A. said a subsidiary, Ansaldo S.p.A., had agreed to acquire the railway signaling operations of American Standard Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Finmeccanica, a unit of the state holding company Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, said in a statement that Ansaldo would acquire the Union Switch and Signal division in the United States and American Standard's Italian-based Wabco Westinghouse operations.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: A graphic accompanying the Week in Business column last week misstated the monthly increase in the rate of factory utilization. The July rate was four-tenths of a percentage point higher than June's.

headline: Partial Accord in Bond-Default Case
abstract: LEAD: Less than a week before the opening of the largest securities fraud trial in history, the Washington Public Power Supply System, a significant defendant in the case, said yesterday that it had reached a tentative settlement with representatives of about some 24,000 investors and the trustee for existing bondholders.

headline: 10 Years, a Postcard and Next, Israel
abstract: LEAD: The postcard came for David and Anna Shvartsman last week, a simple official affirmation that their application to immigrate to Israel had finally been accepted.

headline: Republicans Object to New Contra Deal
abstract: LEAD: The White House and Senate Republicans today raised strong objections to a Democratic proposal on contra aid, but Senate leaders said talks would continue through Tuesday in hopes of fashioning a plan that all sides could agree to.

headline: London Expels 2 Cuban Envoys
abstract: LEAD: The Cuban Ambassador and a commercial attache were expelled today, less than 24 hours after the junior diplomat pulled a gun in a residential street in London and shot at a group of people, wounding a British Secret Service officer.

headline: Britain Plans Sale Of Aircraft Maker
abstract: LEAD: The British Government plans to sell Short Brothers P.L.C., a state-owned aircraft manufacturer, as a single unit rather than split up the concern, a company spokesman said. ''The Government has agreed to a Short proposal that the company must remain intact as an integrated design and manufacturing aerospace business,'' the spokesman said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Wall Street Journal Shifts Work to GSD&M
abstract: LEAD: The Wall Street Journal is pulling its business out of both Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis and the troubled British-owned Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein in New York and consolidating it at GSD&M, in Austin, Tex.

headline: Excerpts From Crowe's Remarks on Downing of Iranian Jet
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from remarks by Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, at a news conference today on the Navy investigation of the downing of an Iranian airliner:

headline: Illegal Computer Exports Are Suspected
abstract: LEAD: Federal authorities are investigating whether a suburban Chicago company illegally exported hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of computer equipment that may have been resold in the Soviet Union.

headline: In Burma's Fragmented Opposition, Hint of Unity
abstract: LEAD: A group of older politicians and retired military men formed an opposition alliance in Burma today under the titular leadership of U Nu, the former Prime Minister who was overthrown in a coup 26 years ago.

headline: Pondering The Puzzle Of Hussein
abstract: LEAD: ''What am I today? A Palestinian? A Jordanian?''

headline: Patents; Edmund Andrews System Gives National Ads Local Touch
abstract: LEAD: Like an itch, the impulse to buy something can pass very quickly. Most good salespeople know that the easiest way to lose a sale is to delay when a customer seems eager to put down money.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Global Information Sets McGraw-Hill Alliance
abstract: LEAD: Global Information, which last year began publishing Global Finance, a 50,000-circulation international publication, has formed a joint venture with McGraw-Hill to publish the magazine.

headline: Israeli Troops Kill 2 Palestinians In Rioting at Negev Prison Camp
abstract: LEAD: Israeli troops fired on hundreds of rioting Palestinians at a Negev prison camp today, killing two and wounding another, the army said.

headline: Chinese Leaders Cite Unrest And Link It to Restructuring
abstract: LEAD: Social unrest is unavoidable as China continues to change its economic and political structure, Prime Minister Li Peng told a meeting of senior security personnel on Tuesday.

headline: U.S. Says Panama Is Harassing G.I.'s
abstract: LEAD: American military documents describe nearly 300 reports of harassment of American servicemen in Panama in the six months after the United States indicted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega on drug charges. The documents indicate that repeated American protests havehad no effect.

headline: U.S. Black Culture Plays Well in Africa
abstract: LEAD: In the domestic air terminal here, news vendors recently peddled copies of Ebony and Essence while video monitors showed tapes of Mike Tyson boxing.

headline: Trade Data in New Format
abstract: LEAD: The Commerce Department said today that it planned to present the nation's trade figures in a new format, which reduces the size of the monthly deficits.

headline: COMPANY NEWS; Ford Raises Prices an Average of 2.6% for 1989 Models
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would raise prices on 1989 cars by an average of 2.6 percent, which is midway between the increases announced by the other two American-owned car companies. The Chrysler Corporation's prices are to rise by 2.3 percent, and the General Motors Corporation's by 2.9 percent.

headline: The Ordeal of the Credit Fraud Victim
abstract: LEAD: IT is a different kind of household theft. The thief might be a nurse's aide or a cleaning person; the loot Social Security numbers, credit card account data and other confidential information. The thief then applies by mail for new credit cards, lines of credit and checking accounts in the name of the victim, giving a mail drop as the current address and the victim's actual address as the former residence.

headline: Oil Output Off California
abstract: LEAD: Oil production from Federal waters off California should double by 1992, according to an Interior Department official. William Bettenberg, director of the department's Minerals Management Service, said last week that production from platforms for which permits already had been granted should bring the total to 200,000 to 225,000 barrels a day.

headline: S.E.C. Action On Short Sales
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission unanimously approved a rule today that would prohibit investors from knowingly covering their short sales of a stock with securities bought in a secondary offering.

headline: Mexican Opposition Leaders Unite to Challenge Results
abstract: LEAD: Mexico's two main opposition leaders said today they will work together to reverse what they called widespread fraud by the ruling party in last month's national elections.

headline: G.M.A.C. Notes To Be Redeemed
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, plans to redeem its 10 percent notes due in 1990. The principal amount, all of it outstanding, totals $500 million.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Peter Zamiska has been named senior vice president, associate creative director and head of the art department at Lavey/Wolff/Swift, a subsidiary of the Omnicom Group.

headline: Dow Slips 0.89 as Low Volume Continues
abstract: LEAD: The prices of stocks finished slightly lower yesterday as volume remained at the slow pace of recent days.

headline: Inquiry on Food Ads Continues
abstract: LEAD: The attorneys general of eight states are cooperating in a summer-long investigation of whether the advertising of some of the nation's largest food companies has misled consumers about the healthfulness of certain products.

headline: ARBITRATORS RULE IN FAVOR OF EGYPT ON SINAI ENCLAVE
abstract: LEAD: An international arbitration panel ruled in Egypt's favor today in a dispute with Israel over a border enclave, but left it to the two sides to work out a final section of the boundary.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Air Wis Services Inc., Appleton, Wis., said it had rebuffed a second request by its largest shareholder to discuss an acquisition proposal, repeating that the company is not for sale.

headline: Shultz Says He Would Meet With Iranian
abstract: LEAD: The United States has received a private response to American messages sent to Iran, Administration officials said today, and Secretary of State George P. Shultz indicated his willingness to meet with Iran's Foreign Minister if the Iranians asked for such a meeting.

headline: Korea to Lift Curb on Won
abstract: LEAD: South Korea plans to make the won an internationally traded currency in several months by lifting foreign exchange restrictions, a Government economist said today.

headline: Industrial Operating Rate Increased to 83.7% in August
abstract: LEAD: The nation's industrial operating rate rose for the fifth consecutive month in August, but economists played down the inflationary effect of the increase because it was entirely attributable to a temporary summer surge at utilities.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: British Commandos Testify on Gibraltar
abstract: LEAD: Hidden behind a brown curtain, a member of Britain's elite Special Air Service regiment, identified only as ''Soldier A,'' testified in clipped tones how he fired five bullets at close range into two Irish Republican Army guerrillas here in March.

headline: Pacific Dunlop Diversifies Its Way Into America
abstract: LEAD: COWARD shoes, Champion batteries, Ansell medical gloves, Lifestyle condoms, Telectronics pacemakers.

headline: APPEAL BY WALESA FAILS TO RESOLVE ALL POLISH STRIKES
abstract: LEAD: Striking Polish workers, voicing strong misgivings about the results of talks between the Government and Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, were deeply divided today over whether to heed his appeal that they end their strikes and return to work.

headline: August Truck Sales Up
abstract: LEAD: August retail truck sales by franchised dealers of United States manufacturers rose 4.7 percent, to 375,302, from 358,365 in August 1987, the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association said today.

headline: COMPANY-NAME CONSULTANTS BATTLE OVER POLL
abstract: LEAD: A battle for recognition has broken out in the small world of consulting firms that help companies find new names. Two established firms that created such names as Navistar, Unisys and Primerica are defending their skills against a competitor's claims that, at least to consumers, such names are jabberwocky.

headline: Soviets Agree to Open Files on the Nazi Genocide to U.S. Scholars
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has agreed for the first time to open its archives on the Nazi genocide to United States scholars, a step that is expected to give a clearer picture of how Eastern European collaborators helped put to death millions of Jews and others.

headline: Gabelli Holds S.E.C. Talks
abstract: LEAD: Gabelli Group Inc. and various subsidiaries confirmed yesterday that they are in settlement talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission over possible violations made in their 1987 takeover attempt of the Di Giorgio Corporation.

headline: P.L.O. Says It Will Pay Salaries in West Bank
abstract: LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it was assuming responsibility for paying civil servants in the West Bank whose salaries were cut off when Jordan broke ties with the Israeli-occupied territory last month.

headline: Corrections
abstract: LEAD: A table last week with an article about McGraw-Hill Inc. mislabeled the company's second-quarter results for 1988 and 1987. For the 1988 quarter, revenues were $443.8 million, net income was $44.8 million and earnings per share were 92 cents. For the 1987 quarter, revenues were $425.9 million, net income was $40 million and earnings per share were 79 cents.

headline: Wyatt Cafeterias
abstract: LEAD: The board of directors of Wyatt Cafeterias Inc. has rejected an offer by Furr's/Bishop's Cafeterias L.P. of $89 in cash and $2.25 in securities per share, Furr's/ Bishop's said. The offer, which totaled $188 million, was the second by Furr's/Bishop's. Last week the Dallas-based Wyatt rejected the partnership's first offer of $179.3 million, or $87 a share, in favor of a proposed employee stock ownership plan valued at $84 a share.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * BEI Holdings Ltd., Atlanta, a consulting and management service company, announced a definitive agreement to acquire the Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association of Nashville for $33 a share in cash, or a total of about $119 million.

headline: Tax on Wealth Sought By French Government
abstract: LEAD: France's minority Government today approved plans to introduce a tax on wealth, setting the scene for Socialist Prime Minister Michel Rocard's first major battle in parliament.

headline: South Africa Violated Pact, Mozambique Says
abstract: LEAD: The official Mozambican press agency said today that South Africa had secretly flown foreign journalists into rebel-held areas of Mozambique in violation of a security pact between the two countries.

headline: Mellon Stock Faltering Since Plan's Debut
abstract: LEAD: A backlash has developed in the investment community to the Mellon Bank Corporation's decision to spin off $1 billion of its bad loans into a separate entity and recapitalize the ''good'' bank that remains.

headline: Soviets Expel Armenian Dissident, Signaling Tough Policy on Unrest
abstract: LEAD: Soviet authorities ordered Armenia's best-known dissident stripped of his citizenship today and expelled from the country, signaling a tough new official position on the threat of renewed Armenian unrest.

headline: NCNB Texas Deposits Cut
abstract: LEAD: Depositors at the NCNB Texas National Bank have withdrawn about $300 million in recent weeks, and bank officials say the total could double.

headline: Engineers Quit Koppers
abstract: LEAD: While Brian C. Beazer continues to seek buyers for the chemical operations of his newly acquired Koppers Company, the Pittsburgh concern's engineering department announced Wednesday that it was breaking away to form a consulting firm. The new Chemtech Consultants Inc. will employ about 30 people, 18 of whom will be investors.

headline: D.M.B.&B. Office Gets Naturalizer Shoe Brand
abstract: LEAD: The Brown Shoe Company, part of the Brown Group of St. Louis, has appointed the St. Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles to do advertising for its Naturalizer brand of women's shoes. Its budget is believed to be around $4 million.

headline: Hunts Sign Penrod Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Hunt brothers said today that they had signed a bank-approved reorganization plan for their Penrod Drilling Company, bringing their three trust estates a step closer to emerging from bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: U.S. PEACE PLAN IN JEOPARDY; Shultz Concerned
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Jordan should continue to take part in any Middle East peace negotiations, even though King Hussein of Jordan has given up his claims to the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

headline: Griffin Wins Case
abstract: LEAD: The plan by the entertainer Merv Griffin to buy Resorts International Inc. moved a step closer to completion. The Delaware Chancery Court found Wednesday that the $36-a-share offer to holders of class A shares ''is both generous and fair and that the settlement must be approved.''

headline: British Inflation Rate Up
abstract: LEAD: Britain's annual consumer inflation rate rose four-tenths of 1 percent, to 4.6 percent, in June from the previous month, the Government reported today. The Department of Employment attributed the rise to higher prices for motor vehicles, non-seasonal foods, gasoline and clothing.

headline: Interface Offering Convertible Debt
abstract: LEAD: Interface Inc., a manufacturer of carpet tile, is offering $95 million of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2013, at a price of par, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

headline: Drexel Burnham Fights Back
abstract: LEAD: WHEN officials from the Securities and Exchange Commission arrived last Wednesday at the Federal Courthouse in Manhattan to file their civil complaint against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., they got a sample of the tenacious battle they have in store.

headline: Discounts at Buick
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation is offering an additional discount of $100 to $300 on various optional equipment packages for its Buick Regal. The SD option package, for example, now represents a $1,350 saving over the list prices for the options it includes, compared with a $1,050 savings under the previous program.

headline: Satellite Sales Split Agencies
abstract: LEAD: Amid a fierce interagency battle, the State Department has recommended that the United States allow the export of communications satellites for launching on Chinese rockets, officials at the department said today.

headline: Market Place; The Sharp Rise In DeKalb's Stock
abstract: LEAD: IN the 10 months that the DeKalb Corporation has been telling Wall Street about its unusual restructuring plan, the company's stock price has nearly doubled. The idea is for the Illinois-based conglomerate to split into three, possibly four, publicly traded companies by the end of this month. That would allow its disparate lines of business, which include oil and gas exploration, oil well servicing, irrigation equipment manufacturing and agricultural genetics, to stand alone.

headline: Sun Reports Record Profit
abstract: LEAD: Bouyed by strong shipments of all its products, Sun Microsystems Inc. reported record results for the quarter and year ended June 30. For the fiscal fourth quarter, Sun earned $25.3 million, or 66 cents a share, more than double the $10.9 million, or 31 cents a share, reported in the comparable period a year ago.

headline: AS MEXICANS VOTE, FRAUD IS ALLEGED
abstract: LEAD: As the opposition charged vote fraud and the Government pledged that the letter of the law would be obeyed, millions of Mexicans voted today in the most important and hotly contested presidential and congressional election here in nearly half a century.

headline: Chip Industry Orders Dip
abstract: LEAD: The semiconductor industry association's leading indicator dipped again in August, as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported an increase in shipments, but a decline in orders, a trade group reported today. The Semiconductor Industry

headline: Havana Cocktail Party Upsets U.S.-Cuba Ties
abstract: LEAD: About a week ago, the small United States diplomatic mission here invited about 20 Cuban human rights advocates and a few foreign diplomats to a cocktail party at the apartment of one of the Americans.

headline: Criticizing U.S., Hanoi Withdraws Offer to Help Account for Missing
abstract: LEAD: Vietnam has suspended cooperation with the United States on efforts to determine what happened to the 1,758 American military men still unaccounted for in Vietnam, the two countries said today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Wyse Executive
abstract: LEAD: Allan D. Gardner, 50 years old, is joining Wyse Advertising of Cleveland and New York as president of the New York office. He is replacing Lois Wyse, who will continue as president of the parent company, of which Marc A. Wyse, her former husband, is chairman. A Brooklyn native and Columbia graduate, Mr.

headline: Soviets Press Offer on Disputed Radar
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, today enlarged on an offer by Moscow to turn a disputed Soviet radar into an international space research center by inviting the United States to do likewise with two American military radar stations.

headline: Economic Scene; Democrats Seek Big Issue for 1988
abstract: LEAD: WHAT is the main economic issue on which the Democrats will fight the 1988 Presidential campaign? In Atlanta this week, Jesse Jackson sought to make that issue the unequal distribution of income and opportunities in the United States. He made his own life the symbol of the issue - and of hope that others could follow his example in making it.

headline: Coast Guard Calls Off Mexico Rescue Efforts
abstract: LEAD: The United States Coast Guard halted rescue missions into flood-ravaged northern Mexico today, two days after responding to pleas for aid from dozens of isolated towns.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: MWCC Receivables Trust One, a subsidiary of Montgomery Ward, is offering $245 million of debt backed by credit-card receivables through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * American Carriers Inc., Overland Park., Kan., a motor carrier holding company, named John Bigger president and chief executive, succeeding Leon Robertson, who is retiring.

headline: Company News; Semiconductor In Stock Buyback
abstract: LEAD: The National Semiconductor Corporation said it would buy back the National common stock and warrants it gave Schlumberger Ltd. for the purchase of Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation last fall. The buyback, in effect, is a decision by National to pay Schlumberger in cash instead of in stock for the acquisition.

headline: INSTALL ANOTHER
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril assumed power in Haiti today after noncommissioned officers of Haiti's Presidential Guard seized power from Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy.

headline: Finance/New Issues; Kidder Offering
abstract: LEAD: Kidder, Peabody & Company is issuing $200 million of collateralized mortgage obligations backed by Government National Mortgage Association certificates. Coupon rates range from 7.70 percent in 1997 to 9.43 percent in 2016. The issue, which is being offered through Kidder, Peabody Mortgage Assets Trust Eighteen, is in 11 classes of bonds, including fixed-rate, floating-rate and planned amortization class bonds.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Social Analysis From Good Housekeeping
abstract: LEAD: NOT long ago, while on a business trip, Alan Waxenberg, publisher of Good Housekeeping since May, and Sandra Spaeth, director of marketing and promotion, used the quiet of a plane ride to relate the magazine's readership to general social trends.
