headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; McCann-Erickson To Buy Canada's Foster
abstract: LEAD: McCann-Erickson Worldwide, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies., said it intended to buy Foster Advertising of Toronto and Montreal.

headline: Ashland, Ex-Officials In Settlement
abstract: LEAD: Ashland Oil Inc. said today that it would pay $25 million to two former executives who contended they had been dismissed for refusing to offer or cover up bribes to foreign officials. As a result, Ashland said it would take an after-tax charge of about $25 million in its fiscal fourth quarter.

headline: F.C.C. Fights Cable Piracy
abstract: LEAD: Federal Communications Commission agents have seized illegal satellite unscrambling devices from businesses in four states in a drive to end cable piracy, the F.C.C. said today.

headline: Shift Seen For Official Of I.B.M.
abstract: LEAD: As part of an effort to stimulate lagging personal computer sales, the International Business Machines Corporation will reportedly put the head of its Asian operation in charge of its Personal Systems Group.

headline: Yellow Pages Project For Southwestern Bell
abstract: LEAD: The Southwestern Bell Corporation's Southwestern Bell publishing unit and Donnelley Directory, a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, have formed a partnership to publish Yellow Pages directories in the Baltimore and Washington markets.

headline: In Kabul, Rumors and Rockets Fly
abstract: LEAD: At a European embassy here, diplomats sent a terse private cable to their Government the other morning summing up the latest news about Afghanistan's enigmatic leader, President Najibullah.

headline: National City Unit Sets Deposit Issue
abstract: LEAD: National City Bank, a unit of the National City Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 5/8 percent deposit notes due in 1993, at a price of par, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Congressional Aides Say Drexel Committed Added Violations
abstract: LEAD: Officials with a Congressional subcommittee have obtained documents that they say show that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. committed violations of Federal securities laws in addition to those mentioned in a civil complaint filed last week by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Judges' Views on Eastern
abstract: LEAD: Two Federal appeals judges suggested today that business considerations and not union-busting tactics motivated Eastern Airlines' decision to lay off 4,000 workers.

headline: Consumer Prices Rise 0.3%, Easing Inflation Fear
abstract: LEAD: In a report that allayed some fears about a resurgence of inflation, the Labor Department said today that the Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the same as in May and less than the rises in March and April.

headline: ...But East Germans Are Intent on Staying As Is
abstract: LEAD: Although the East German press reported fully on the keynote speech by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the Soviet party conference, East Germany's conservative leader has repeatedly made clear he has no immediate intention of importing any of the Soviet leader's program of change.

headline: Electoral Panel Prolongs Delay In Mexico Tally
abstract: LEAD: The confusion over who has won Mexico's presidential election deepened here today as the Federal Electoral Commission canceled all further scheduled meetings and said no election results would be announced until Sunday.

headline: May Stores Begins Offer for Shares
abstract: LEAD: The May Department Stores Company said it had begun a ''Dutch auction'' tender offer for 14.1 million shares of its stock to finance its recently announced shopping-center joint venture with Melvin Simon & Associates and the Prudential Insurance Company of America. The shares sought represent 9.4 percent of

headline: Mall Stake Sold By Carter Hawley
abstract: LEAD: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said it had sold its interest in a California shopping center for $32 million. Carter Hawley, the nation's 14th-largest retailer, also said it had established $25 million in reserves for consolidation and other costs in its fourth quarter, which ended June 30.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Improving Brazilian Social Welfare Proves Far Easier Said Than Done
abstract: LEAD: Even local viewers accustomed to seeing life through a rose-tinted screen are having trouble recognizing Brazil in a series of television commercials publicizing increased Government investment in education, health and nutrition.

headline: Canada Prices Up 0.3%
abstract: LEAD: The Canadian consumer price index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in August, compared with a six-tenths of 1 percent rise in July and a one-tenth of 1 percent increase in August 1987, the Government agency Statistics Canada said Friday. The August year-to-year rise was 4 percent, compared with a 3.8 percent in the July year-to-year figure.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Common Stock

headline: A Hearing On Planners
abstract: LEAD: David S. Ruder, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he could not reconcile the large estimates of the total number of financial planners in the United States with the smaller number of registered investment adviser firms.

headline: Mexico Plan on Oil Exports
abstract: LEAD: Mexico is prepared to reduce its oil exports to help stabilize prices, but only if the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries develops a reasonable plan for similar action, Energy Minister Fernando Hiriart said today.

headline: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES PLANS LAYOFFS OF 900
abstract: LEAD: Continental Airlines Inc., a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, said today that it would lay off 900 managers, pilots, flight attendants and ground employees in a schedule realignment and management restructuring.

headline: Carson Pirie Stake
abstract: LEAD: An investor group that includes Arnhold and S. Bleichroeder Inc., New York, investment bankers, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had reduced its stake in Carson Pirie Scott Inc. to 641,749 shares, or 4.7 percent of the outstanding common stock. The group, which had previously held 5.7 percent, said it sold 139,300 shares of the Chicago retail company in open-market transactions between June 1 and July 18 at $12.50 to $14.50 a share.

headline: U.S. Averts Atom Agency's Ouster of Pretoria
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration appears to have succeeded in its drive to stop South Africa from being expelled from the international organization that oversees the nuclear industry and tries to halt the spread of atomic weapons, American officials said today.

headline: Minnesota Dean Hired By Conference Board
abstract: LEAD: The Conference Board yesterday named Preston Townley, who has been dean of the Carlson School of Management at the University of Minnesota since 1984, as its new president.

headline: 4 Die as South Africans Storm Hijackers in Lesotho
abstract: LEAD: A South African anti-terrorist squad stormed a bus in which 69 Roman Catholic pilgrims were being held hostage here tonight, killing three hijackers and a hostage and ending a 26-hour ordeal.

headline: Lisbon Journal; A City's Heart in Ruins: Now to Put It Together
abstract: LEAD: The fire began in a department store and quickly spread through the historic Chiado district, a neighborhood of steep, narrow streets.

headline: Fall in Computerized Trading Indicated on Stock Exchange
abstract: LEAD: The first detailed report on program trading on the New York Stock Exchange, released yesterday, showed that the computerized trades might not be so pervasive as some investors had feared.

headline: Breaking Out of the Biotech Pack
abstract: LEAD: WHEN kidney dialysis patients taking part in the clinical trials of Amgen Inc.'s erythropoietin talk about the drug's impact on their lives, they tend to use words like ''wonderful'' and ''dramatic,'' with all the restraint of a carnival barker hawking snake oil.

headline: Geneva Talks on Cyprus Due
abstract: LEAD: The Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, and the Greek Cypriot President, George Vassiliou, arrived in Geneva today for United Nations-mediated talks. They said they hoped their divided island could be united in a federal republic.

headline: Armenians Hold Rally Over Disputed Region
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of striking Armenians gathered today in Yerevan, the capital of the Soviet republic, to protest violence in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan, a neighboring republic.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Walter Horsfall has been elected senior vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide. He is a group creative director in the Chicago office.

headline: Lahore Journal; Pride of the Moguls and the Pride of Punjabis Still
abstract: LEAD: There are two Punjabs now, one on each side of the India-Pakistan frontier. But there is only one Punjabi city with the power to fire the Punjabi intellect and enslave a Punjabi heart. That city is Lahore.

headline: Shahid Tammtk Journal; The Bounty of the Desert: Tomatoes and Rebellion
abstract: LEAD: On a patch of oasis here, a seemingly endless sea of sand is broken by a clump of lush greenery that provides subsistence, if barely, for thousands of people.

headline: Mural Draws Shultz's Fire On Quito Trip
abstract: LEAD: A giant mural on a wall of the Ecuadorean Congress that seems to equate the Central Intelligence Agency with Nazism was sharply criticized by Secretary of State George P. Shultz today as he arrived here for Ecuador's presidential inauguration.

headline: Worker Buyouts
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Greece Issues Photos of Suspects in Ship Siege
abstract: LEAD: Greece said today that it had obtained the photographs of four suspects in the terrorist attack aboard an excursion ship in the Saronic Gulf on Monday and that it had identified two of them. The Government said it did not know the whereabouts of the attackers.

headline: Swiss Seek 2 in Stock Case
abstract: LEAD: A Swiss judge said today that he had issued arrest warrants for two more suspects in a $250 million fraud case involving bogus stock shares sold to thousands of investors in many countries. Judge Laurent Kasper-Ansermet refused to disclose the names or nationalities of the latest suspects.

headline: U.S. and Soviets Discuss Curbing Missile Exports
abstract: LEAD: American and Soviet officials today held their first in-depth discussions of ways to curb the spread of ballistic missiles to the third world.

headline: Inflation Peril In China Seen
abstract: LEAD: The American economist Milton Friedman warned China today that soaring inflation could cripple its economy unless steps were taken to speed the conversion of state-run enterprises to private ownership.

headline: Cuban Lists Conditions for Angola Troop Pullout
abstract: LEAD: Cuba will start to withdraw its troops from Angola only after South Africa begins to carry out a long-stalled United Nations plan for independence in neighboring Namibia, the chief Cuban negotiator in the talks on the Angolan conflict said here today.

headline: Yeutter Sees Slow Exports
abstract: LEAD: The growth in United States exports will probably slow as many industries reach production capacity, Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: LEAD:           In percent               Tax-Exempt Bonds   7.83        Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index               Money Market Funds   7.22        Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield               Bank Money Market Accounts   5.83        Bank Rate Monitor               Home Mortgage   10.50        Federal Home Loan Bank, national average               Unsecured Personal Loans        Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity        Chase Manhattan, New York   13.90        Continental Illinois, Chicago   14.90        Bank of America, San Francisco   21.25

headline: Article 196788 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Maxicare Health Plans Inc., the nation's largest for-profit health maintenance organization, today reported a second-quarter loss of $59.5 million, nearly $10 million more than it had predicted two weeks ago.

headline: Into the 21st Century - Supersonically
abstract: LEAD: A GROWING number of authorities believe that the age of mass supersonic air transportation in long-haul routes may be in the offing. If they are correct, there will be major opportunities for aircraft manufacturers, airlines and travelers alike. Significant steps are being taken to make this development a reality.

headline: U.N. Will Teach Afghan Refugees to Defuse Mines
abstract: LEAD: The United Nations official overseeing aid for Afghanistan plans to spend much of this winter on a campaign to teach Afghan refugees how to defuse the hundreds of thousands of mines, booby traps and unexploded munitions that litter their homeland after eight years of civil war.

headline: Irving Says Suitor Made Rival Flee
abstract: LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation yesterday sued the Bank of New York Company, asserting that it improperly persuaded Banca Commerciale Italiana to withdraw its friendly bid for Irving last August.

headline: Seoul Pulls Out All the Stops to Pre-empt Terrorism
abstract: LEAD: As concern grows about possible terrorist attacks by North Korean agents or the Japanese Red Army before and during the Summer Olympics, this near-fortress city is buttressing its already formidable defenses.

headline: Birnin Kudu Journal; For Women in Politics, the Microphone Is Dead
abstract: LEAD: The topic was women, but, as is often the case in Nigeria's traditional, Islamic north, the speakers here were men.

headline: A Low for Crop Acreage
abstract: LEAD: American farmers this year are likely to harvest the lowest number of acres in this century, the United States Agriculture Department said Friday. In a monthly report, the department said that record acreage left unplanted under Government programs and high crop failure this year because of the summer drought resulted in the record low acreage.

headline: Dollar Up Sharply on Trade Data
abstract: LEAD: Buoyed by trade figures, the dollar surged yesterday to an 11-month high again against the West German mark and a nine-month high against the Japanese yen. The rally came despite concerted intervention by the Federal Reserve and European central banks.

headline: Polaroid Stock Up on Rumor
abstract: LEAD: Trading in shares of the Polaroid Corporation advanced sharply early yesterday on rumors that Goldman, Sachs & Company, the big investment house, might have a client interested in buying the instant-photography company, but fell back later in the session after professional buying subsided.

headline: Market Place; Fund Managers Regain the Lead
abstract: LEAD: AT the beginning of the year, some market analysts boldly stated that this would be the year that investment managers began beating the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, and it appears that they were correct. After lagging behind the index for four of the last five years, the average independent investment management firm has been outpacing the once seemingly unbeatable index -and by a fairly wide margin.

headline: Bankers Trust Shows Strong Gain in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation surprised banking analysts yesterday by restating its 1987 financial results in a way that raised questions about its internal accounting practices, but did not alter last year's earnings.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Kenneth E. Runkel has been promoted to senior vice president, management supervisor, at Tracy-Locke, Dallas.

headline: European Bank Idea Rebuffed
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today that monetary union in the European Community would be difficult and that progress toward such integration would not necessarily involve a common European central bank.

headline: For Moscow Jews, Fear Of Prejudice Is Stirring
abstract: LEAD: There is a sense of fear among Jews in Moscow these days, a disquieting feeling that the changes taking place in Soviet society, changes that seem to encourage more openness and tolerance, are somehow stimulating the anti-Semitism that has deep historical roots in this country.

headline: Massachusetts Utilities in Pact
abstract: LEAD: In a move intended to prevent power shortages and avoid construction of new generating plants, six Massachusetts utilities have agreed to cooperate on energy conservation programs.

headline: Singer Divestment
abstract: LEAD: The Singer Company, in the latest move in its divestment program, agreed to sell its American Meter division to West Germany's Ruhrgas A.G. for about $132 million. Since the investor Paul A. Bilzerian bought Singer in January, the Stamford, Conn., company has pursued a policy of divestment, so far concluding seven sales agreements with a total value of about $1.7 billion.

headline: Article 283888 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million of 9.80 percent fixed-rate notes due in 2000 at a price of par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: Aviation Unit Rebuffs Iran's Bid Against U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The International Civil Aviation Organization today rebuffed a bid by Iran for a condemnation of the United States for shooting down an Iranian airliner in the Persian Gulf. It voted instead to issue a statement that ''deplored'' the use of weapons against a civilian aircraft but did not mention the United States.

headline: MOSCOW IMPOSES EMERGENCY DECREE IN ETHNIC CONFLICT
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union today declared a state of emergency in a disputed southern territory as the ethnic conflict between Armenians and Azerbaijanis worsened.

headline: Tamil Groups Are Choosing Election Role
abstract: LEAD: Prospects for the rebuilding of northeastern Sri Lanka after years of violence depend in part on whether ethnic Tamil groups decide to take part in regional elections.

headline: Dow Drops 25.60 More, To 2,060.99
abstract: LEAD: The stock market fell sharply again yesterday in a broad selloff that disappointed many traders who thought stock prices would rally on what they considered bullish economic news.

headline: Patents; Household Plants Used In Roach-Killing Mix
abstract: LEAD: Two amateur inventors in Los Angeles received patents this week for compounds that they contend are deadly to roaches but harmless to people and pets. The compounds are made from household plants.

headline: July Inventory Rise of 0.3% Slowest Rate in 11 Months
abstract: LEAD: Business inventories in July rose at the slowest rate in 11 months, suggesting to analysts that underlying economic growth remains strong despite a pause in business sales.

headline: A Burmese Power Shift; Though Government Schedules Election, Decision Rests With People in the Streets
abstract: LEAD: The Burmese Government has scheduled general elections, as a leading opposition figure did separately a few days earlier, but it is the people in the streets, where political power now seems to be, who will decide whether the elections can proceed.

headline: IRAQI AID TAKES HARD LINE AT U.N.
abstract: LEAD: Iraq's Foreign Minister joined the Persian Gulf peace talks here today and took a hard line, demanding direct negotiations with Iran as proof that it is sincere in wanting peace.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY JULY 29, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Zenith to Meet With Dissident
abstract: LEAD: The Zenith Electronics Corporation today asked for a meeting with its dissident stockholder,Brookhurst Partners, which said Wednesday that it would push for the prompt sale of the company.

headline: Copper Prices, Now Up, Are Seen Settling Down
abstract: LEAD: After slipping for several weeks, copper prices have begun to rebound again because of a renewed tightening of supplies brought on in part by copper workers' strikes in Peru and Canada.

headline: Perot's Postal Service Pact Is Suspended by the G.S.A.
abstract: LEAD: H. Ross Perot's $500,000 consulting contract with the Postal Service was suspended yesterday by the General Services Administration because his company had refused to supply documents to the G.S.A.'s Board of Contract Appeals.

headline: Drought Cutting U.S. Grain Crop 31% This Year
abstract: LEAD: In the gloomiest assessment yet of damage wrought by the drought, the Agriculture Department said today that the United States grain harvest this year would be 31 percent lower than last year. The harvest, estimated at 192 million metric tons, would be the smallest since 1970.

headline: Miles Per Gallon
abstract: LEAD: Opposed to the CAFE regulations, we have the president of a corporation that was a leader in helping excavate the pit of perdition in which the domestic auto industry finds itself. Over many years, General Motors failed to pay attention to what its overseas competition was doing and insisted that what the

headline: Company News; Tesoro Tax Pact
abstract: LEAD: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said it had reached a tentative $20.6 million settlement with the Internal Revenue Service to resolve all pending income tax issues for the company's 1981 through 1985 fiscal years. The settlement calls for San Antonio-based Tesoro to pay $10.6 million in additional taxes and $10 million in interest, Tesoro said.

headline: Accord Reached With Allegheny
abstract: LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. and a dissident shareholder group that failed to take control of the company's 13-member board in a proxy fight agreed to stop their legal wrangling. Lawyers for Allegheny International and Spear Leeds & Kellogg, a New York brokerage house that led the effort to gain control of the consumer products company's board, announced the settlement Thursday to Chief Bankruptcy Judge Joseph

headline: Polaroid Files Lawsuit To Block Takeover
abstract: LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation said today that it had filed a lawsuit that seeks to block a $2.4 billion hostile takeover bid from Roy E. Disney's Shamrock Holdings Inc.

headline: Agency Merger In Richmond
abstract: LEAD: Even young ad agencies are jumping into the acquisition game. Hawley Martin Partners, which opened its doors in Richmond two weeks ago, has acquired that city's Ford & Westbrook in an exchange of stock. The deal brings Hawley Martin's total billings to $50 million - Richmond's No. 2 in size behind the Martin Agency.

headline: Boat Loans To Back Issue
abstract: LEAD: The different types of asset-backed securities brought to market since their inception in 1985 expanded yesterday. Chemical Bank Grantor

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: California tapped the short-term debt market yesterday with the largest single-maturity note issue to date. The $3.2 billion offering of revenue anticipation notes was tentatively priced through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Jamaica Reviving After Hurricane But Food Shortages Are Predicted
abstract: LEAD: One week after Jamaica was stunned by the century's most powerful hurricane, the island seemed well on its way to recovery today.

headline: Questions Lingering Over Swift Iraqi Rout Of Kurdish Minority
abstract: LEAD: Iraq's military campaign against its Kurdish minority has ended and its forces control northern regions formerly considered Kurdish rebel bastions, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today.

headline: Competition Grows in Paperback Business
abstract: LEAD: Sales of mass-market paperback books have been flat for three years, unsold paperbacks are being returned in record numbers and the outlook for the next several years is equally bleak. In theory, then, mass-market publishers should be cutting back on the number of books they publish, and other publishing houses should be thankful they are not in such a cutthroat end of the business.

headline: American Allies Voice Regret Over Shooting Down of Plane
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain today expressed understanding of an American warship's downing of an Iranian airliner on Sunday, while most other European allies and Japan expressed deep regret about the military action.

headline: A Dream as Bright as Its Chrome
abstract: LEAD: The December 1946 issue of the now defunct Science Illustrated magazine carried a dramatic front view of a vehicle with fenders that pivoted with the front wheels and a drawing of an all-hydraulic drive train. This was the Tucker - a new car concept that set the stage for Preston T. Tucker's entrance onto the automotive scene.

headline: Price Rise Set for Steel Used in Cans
abstract: LEAD: The nation's three largest steelmakers have announced price increases on sheet steel used for cans, a move that will affect prices on everything from food cans and aerosol containers to oil and air filters.

headline: At Loehmann's, Mystique Fades
abstract: LEAD: For generations of style-seeking women, Loehmann's has offered a kind of fashion salvation, selling top designer clothes, without the labels, at a discount. But these days, women who once flocked to Loehmann's stores can find similar bargains elsewhere - at other discount houses, factory outlets and department stores that seem to offer perpetual markdowns.

headline: WALL ST. RETHINKS ITS GLOBAL PLANS
abstract: LEAD: A year ago, the big London offices of Wall Street's leading investment banks seemed dedicated to slugging it out in the hotly competitive markets for international stocks and bonds.

headline: Economic Scene; The Broad Protest On Strauss's Plan
abstract: LEAD: ROBERT S. STRAUSS, the veteran Texas lawyer who serves as co-chairman of the bipartisan National Economic Commission, set off a storm this week when, at a Washington monetary conference, he disclosed his thinking about the combination of tax increases and cuts in military outlays and in Social Security and other entitlement programs required to eliminate the

headline: Fire Damages Brazilian Park
abstract: LEAD: Fire has destroyed at least 60 percent of Brazil's National Park of the Rheas, one of the richest wildlife preserves in South America, officials said today.

headline: Koreans Protest Film
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of movie stars, directors and others demonstrated Saturday outside two theaters planning to show ''Fatal Attraction,'' the first American film to be distributed directly in South Korea. The direct American distribution of films, which bypasses local distribution companies, is part of trade liberalization measures between the United States and South Korea.

headline: Jobless Insurance System Aids Reduced Number of Workers
abstract: LEAD: The unemployment insurance system, created in the New Deal days as the principal welfare program for the nation's jobless, is no longer functioning as a safety net for the vast majority of the unemployed.

headline: German Lombard Rate Is Raised to Curb Dollar
abstract: LEAD: West Germany took a further step today to help curb the dollar's recent strength by raising an important lending rate.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * AEL Industries, Lansdale, Pa., an electronic equipment manufacturer, said it had received a $4.3 million Navy contract.

headline: A Takeover Battle In the Gold Fields
abstract: LEAD: Two gold-mining giants began a takeover battle. A division of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa offered $4.9 billion for Consolidated Gold Fields, a London-based company with huge mines in South Africa. Anglo American, the Western world's largest gold producer, is controlled by the Oppenheimer dynasty of South Africa, which runs the De Beers diamond operations.

headline: Intel Profit Up Sharply In Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Riding a wave of popularity for its latest microprocessor, the Intel Corporation reported today that its net income nearly tripled in the second quarter from a year earlier.

headline: 100 Die as India Train Falls Off Bridge
abstract: LEAD: More than 100 people were killed today when a train derailed while crossing a bridge in southern India, plunging the engine and nine cars packed with passengers into a lake.

headline: Flight Delays Rise in Europe
abstract: LEAD: The Association of European Airlines said today that the number of delays in scheduled European flights in June was at least three times higher than in June 1986.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: Balfour Maclaine Corp. agreed to sell the corn and sorghum operations of its Seedtec International Inc. subsidiary to Nickerson American Plant Breeders Inc. of Mission, Kan. The price will be in the range of $10 million to $14 million ,

headline: Canada to End Paper $1
abstract: LEAD: Canada's one-dollar coin will completely replace the paper dollar bill within two years, the Government has announced. The coin was introduced last year under a plan to save taxpayers $175 million (Canadian) over 20 years because coins have a longer circulation life than paper bills. Public acceptance of the gold-colored 11-sided coin has been limited, but the Government has said that production of dollar bills will end on June 30, 1989, and that the bills will cease to be legal tender about a year later.

headline: Racing Form: Trifecta for Murdoch?
abstract: LEAD: Every day, as the bugler calls the horses to the post and the bettors to the betting windows at dozens of thoroughbred race tracks across North America, horse players have two ways of trying to pick winners: stabbing at their programs with a hatpin or consulting the sea of statistical data in the Daily Racing

headline: Swiss Ask S.E.C. for Help in Stock Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Swiss and French investigators are stepping up their inquiry into a stock swindle that they say cost investors at least $80 million.

headline: New York Fed Names Its New No. 2 Officer
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has named James H. Oltman first vice president and chief administrative officer, the bank's No. 2 post.

headline: Early August Vehicle Sales Encouraging
abstract: LEAD: Early August sales of new American-made cars and light trucks were among the strongest in recent months, but were down 6.6 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.

headline: New Trade Law's Impact Depends On President's Push, Analysts Say
abstract: LEAD: The House of Representatives yesterday passed the first major trade legislation since the 1970's, but the bill will have a major impact only if the next President is an activist bent on forcing other countries to purchase more American goods, according to economists, trade experts and Government officials.

headline: Paris Bank Branch Offers 10% Notes
abstract: LEAD: The New York branch of Banque Nationale de Paris is offering $200 million of 10 percent notes due in 1998, at a price of par, to yield about three-quarters of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

headline: Namibia's Changing War Map: Cubans Now a Factor
abstract: LEAD: Until Cuban mechanized, air and antiaircraft units began moving into the area six weeks ago, South African forces operated freely in southern Angola in their war against guerrillas seeking control of South-West Africa. But a clash late last month between South African troops and guerrilla units backed by

headline: Deaths and Illness Rise in Bangladesh
abstract: LEAD: Reports of illness and deaths from gastrointestinal diseases began to rise suddenly today, increasing fears of an epidemic even as the waters of this country's devastating flood continue to recede.

headline: At Gorbachev's Cracow Tour, Guests Appear Handpicked
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, came to this ancient city of Polish kings today. But the crowd that came to welcome him might have been from central casting.

headline: BBDO/Minneapolis Gets Chicken by George
abstract: LEAD: BBDO/Minneapolis, which already serves Geo. A. Hormel & Company of Austin, Minn., has also been assigned Chicken by George, a line of ready-to-cook marinated chicken breasts. The ad budget has not been set.  Hormel recently acquired the Kentucky-based company that has the same name as the product.

headline: E-II Lawsuit Is Dismissed
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit by bondholders of E-II Holdings Inc. against American Brands Inc.

headline: U.S. Jeep/Eagle Dealers Plan a Joint Campaign
abstract: LEAD: Chrysler's 1,500 Jeep/Eagle dealers, which sell the Eagle Premier and Jeep Cherokee, have decided to pool their resources in celebrating their first anniversary with a jointly purchased media campaign scheduled to make its debut Sept. 6.

headline: No Hard and Fast Limitations On Flight Paths, Experts Say
abstract: LEAD: Even as the Pentagon backtracked from its assertion that the Iranian airliner shot down on Sunday morning had flown outside the official airway, aviation experts said yesterday that no hard and fast rules would have barred such a flight path in any case.

headline: Japan to Press 3d World Aid
abstract: LEAD: Japan will apparently press ahead with its plan to help debt-ridden third world nations at a series of international monetary meetings in West Berlin later this month, Government sources said today.

headline: Hallmark Will Review Agency's Work
abstract: LEAD: HALLMARK CARDS, the leader in the greeting card field, is going to be reviewing its advertising, which is currently handled by Ogilvy & Mather. The budget is about $35 million.

headline: Making, and Unmaking, the News in Beijing
abstract: LEAD: Last Sunday, People's Daily, the organ of the Chinese Communist Party, reported on its front page that Qi Wenzeng marched into Zhongnanhai, the walled and guarded compound where China's leaders live and work, and proceeded to peddle more than $8,000 worth of stock in his company.

headline: Chicago Milwaukee To Shed Properties
abstract: LEAD: The Chicago Milwaukee Corporation said it would spin off its real estate properties into a limited partnership to be distributed to shareholders. The interests are expected to go out in December after shareholder approval is obtained, it said.

headline: Passenger Traffic Down at Eastern
abstract: LEAD: Eastern Airlines Inc. has reported a 15.7 percent decline in passenger traffic in June and said it reflected its continued ''downsizing.'' Revenue passenger miles, the number of miles flown by paying passengers, fell 18.6 percent for the first six months of 1988, compared with the first half of 1987.

headline: New Liberation Faith: Social Conflict Is Muted
abstract: LEAD: After 20 years, liberation theology, which is widely believed to have altered the political and religious landscape of Latin America, is looking beyond social and economic conflict, relying less on Marxism, focusing more on spirituality and rethinking its attitudes toward democracy and socialism.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., and Lucas Industries P.L.C., London, said Lucas would purchase the Utica Power Systems unit of Allied, which makes engine power transmission products, for $40 million.

headline: NCNB Raises Funds For Rescue in Texas
abstract: LEAD: Exceeding a pledge made last July, the NCNB Corporation said today that it had raised $250 million through the private sale of preferred stock. The bank holding company said it would commit $210 million of the total to buy 20 percent of the newly formed Texas bank, NCNB Texas.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Doskocil Sweetens Wilson Foods Bid
abstract: LEAD: Seeking to top a competing bid for the Wilson Foods Corporation, the Doskocil Companies said it would raise its offer by $2.25 a share, to $14.50, putting a new value of about $147 million on the meatpacking concern. Doskocil, which makes pizza toppings, wants to buy Wilson to gain entry into grocery stores and delicatessens.

headline: Trade Gap With Japan
abstract: LEAD: The United States trade deficit with Japan will probably shrink but never be eliminated entirely, a Congressional expert told the House Committee on Foreign Affairs today. ''Under any scenario, we're going to have a trade deficit with Japan,'' said Allan Mendelowitz, a senior associate director with the General Accounting Office, the research branch of Congress.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Crop Prices Rebound; Precious Metals Follow
abstract: LEAD: Prices of all farm crops rebounded yesterday as the futures market awaited the Agriculture Department's special report on the damage caused so far by the worst drought since the Dust Bowl of the 1930's.

headline: Output Falls in Quarter; Largest Drop Since '81
abstract: LEAD: The productivity of American businesses in the second quarter deteriorated at a rate unequaled since 1981, the Labor Department said today in a report that caused some analysts to predict signifcant trouble for the economy's competitive vigor.

headline: The Media Business: Advertising; Scali Avoids Client Woes In Mergers
abstract: LEAD: AT a time in adland when the mere mention of client conflicts raises hackles in agency circles, a conversation with Marvin Sloves, chairman and chief executive of the 21-year-old Scali, McCabe, Sloves, offers a calming perspective.

headline: Among South Koreans, Olympics Foster True Believers and Infidels
abstract: LEAD: This nation, for centuries a victim of foreign invasions, is pouring all the fury at its past and pride in its present into an Olympics meant to prove Korea's worth to the world.

headline: 10,000 in Prague Protest 1968 Invasion; Kremlin Is Silent
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union today observed the 20th anniversary of its invasion of Czechoslovakia with an enforced silence in the streets and in the press.

headline: Signs of Slowdown Are Well-Received
abstract: LEAD: A slowing of the economic pace seemed to be registered in the week's statistics. Far from being alarmed, most economists welcomed signs that the strong growth of earlier this year, and its potential for inflation, might be easing. The statistics included a two-tenths of 1 percent drop in retail sales in August.

headline: Wanted in Poland: Less Money, More Goods
abstract: LEAD: The resignation of Poland's Government last week was the most candid admission to date that the ambitious economic program announced last fall has not worked. Zbigniew Messner, the outgoing

headline: U.S. Considers Compensation In Airbus Case
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration has begun to review whether the United States should offer to pay compensation to the families of those killed when an Iran Air jetliner was shot down Sunday, Administration officials said today.

headline: BANKING PANEL BACKS LIMITED NEW POWERS
abstract: LEAD: The House Banking Committee voted today to give the nation's commercial banks and their parent holding companies broad new powers to underwrite securities. But it also imposed sweeping restrictions on the marketing of those products and on which banking companies would be eligible to enter the new businesses.

headline: For Eastern Workers, No Layoffs, But Limbo
abstract: LEAD: Nick Melisse, a customer service representative at Eastern Airlines for 14 years, stood outside the huge reservation center here handling a white carnation that symbolized the end of his career at Eastern.

headline: Malaysia Cocoa Futures
abstract: LEAD: The Kuala Lumpur Commodity Exchange began trading in cocoa futures today to coincide with the date 8/8/88, which many Chinese and others in Malaysia believe brings great prosperity. The exchange is the first futures market for cocoa in Asia. Malaysia is the world's third-largest producer of cocoa after the Ivory Coast and Brazil.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Aritech Corp., Framingham, Mass., said it would reorganize its North American operations into two divisions and consolidate its manufacturing operations at a plant in Hickory, N.C.

headline: Time and McGraw-Hill Post 2d-Quarter Earnings Gains
abstract: LEAD: Two New York-based media companies, Time Inc. and McGraw-Hill Inc., yesterday reported higher second-quarter profits.

headline: Sri Lanka Capital Becomes City of Fear
abstract: LEAD: A sudden, silent campaign of intimidation and terror closed down this capital city Monday. Residents of Colombo, who have tasted much bitterness and violence in the last few years, say they have never experienced anything like this.

headline: Programmer Convicted After Planting a 'Virus'
abstract: LEAD: A former computer programmer who wiped out 168,000 payroll records after being dismissed by an insurance company has been convicted of harmful access to a computer, a third-degree felony.

headline: Ruling in Case Of Apple Suit
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge on Friday denied the request of Apple Computer Inc. that he disqualify himself from its copyright infringement case against the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Microsoft Corporation because his son works for Hewlett-Packard. Apple sued the companies in

headline: PROTESTS MARK BERLIN WALL'S 27TH ANNIVERSARY
abstract: LEAD: West German protesters threw tomatoes and eggs at East German guards at the Berlin wall and Communist police hauled away protesting East German youths today as both sides marked the barrier's 27th anniversary.

headline: Yugoslavia Threatens Tough Moves on Unrest
abstract: LEAD: The Communist leadership ended a meeting today with a threat to take tougher action against unrest in the southern province of Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians are demanding greater autonomy.

headline: San Jose Journal; Pastora, the Sometime Hero, Waits to Go Home
abstract: LEAD: Nicaragua's most prominent political exile, the former guerrilla hero Eden Pastora Gomez, says he hopes to return to Managua as an anti-Sandinista politician.

headline: Burma Picks a Hard-Liner To Succeed Longtime Ruler
abstract: LEAD: U Sein Lwin, a hard-line retired army general who reportedly commanded the forces that suppressed student riots in March, was chosen today to succeed U Ne Win as the leader of Burma's ruling party.

headline: Two Koreas Move Closer to Talks
abstract: LEAD: The two Koreas moved closer today toward their first talks in nearly three years when North Korea proposed a preliminary meeting next week at the truce village of Panmunjom.

headline: Skipper Accused Of Abandoning Asian Refugees
abstract: LEAD: The Navy said today that it had charged a warship captain with failing to obey standing orders by refusing adequate assistance to a boat carrying Vietnamese refugees, many of whom later died of exposure and starvation.

headline: All Dressed Up and No Place to Go?
abstract: LEAD: AT a time when many individual investors have fled the stock market in fear, one pack of investors is feverishly raising cash to buy up stocks. Leveraged buyout investors, who buy companies with borrowed capital and then resell them for hefty profits, are furiously piling up billions of dollars.

headline: India and Gurkha Militants Reach Accord to End Regional Violence
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi tonight approved an agreement to end two years of confrontation in northeastern India, where more than 300 people have died in a campaign by Gurkhas seeking greater control of their political and economic affairs.

headline: Chip Index Is Still High
abstract: LEAD: A key index of semiconductor industry sales remained at a high level in June, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: LEAD:            Net      Percent       Income      Change                $      Net Income   Percent        Apr.-June   Change        1988   From '87     Alcan Aluminium Ltd.   $ 243,000,000    +   133.7     Allied-Signal Inc.   128,000,000    -   13.5     A.T.& T.   594,000,000    -   0.3     AMR Corp.   141,400,000    +   53.4     Consolidated Rail Corp.

headline: Poverty, Fear and Strife Still Add Up to Fewer Jobs for Catholics in Ulster
abstract: LEAD: Nearly 20 years after a group of young Roman Catholic civil rights demonstrators began a major protest against job discrimination, the Catholic minority in Northern Ireland still has more unemployment than the Protestant majority.

headline: Bundesbank On Inflation
abstract: LEAD: West Germany's central bank today issued a warning about inflation, citing a weaker mark and the rising cost of imported goods.

headline: Dow Drops 1.78 as Wariness Persists
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average declined 1.78, to close at 2,037.52.

headline: The Media Business; McCall's Brings Back Betsy McCall for K Mart
abstract: LEAD: For a generation of little girls Betsy McCall, a paper doll that lived within the pages of McCall's magazine, was a very special friend. Now, updated considerably, she will be back as the theme and title of a special insert the magazine is creating in behalf of the K Mart Corporation.

headline: Voice of America Is Granted Permanent Moscow Bureau
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union gave permission today for the Voice of America to open a permanent bureau in Moscow, welcoming a broadcast organization it used to jam.

headline: Treasury Issues End Day Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds ended mixed after a volatile session yesterday as technical factors and a steady dollar helped overcome an unexpectedly bad report on the nation's merchandise trade deficit.

headline: Exports of American Steel Surge
abstract: LEAD: American steel companies, stepping up exports in anticipation of a continued weakness in the dollar and tighter supplies, will this year have the highest level of shipments to foreign countries since the early 1980's, industry officials said.

headline: A Spinoff For Sports Illustrated
abstract: LEAD: SPORTS ILLUSTRATED, the Time Inc. weekly that is celebrating its 35th anniversary next year, will begin 1989 by spinning off a new magazine with a number of missions.

headline: Texaco's Deal Advances
abstract: LEAD: Texaco Inc.'s plan to sell Saudi Arabia a half-interest in three United States refineries and associated marketing properties can go forward without the approval of the Federal committee that reviews foreigners' purchases of American companies, a Treasury Department official said yesterday.

headline: News Corp. Profit Off 67.5%
abstract: LEAD: The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's Australian holding company, reported yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter ended June 30 had plunged 67.5 percent even though its revenues had increased 23.3 percent.

headline: 2 Sweeteners Are Patented
abstract: LEAD: The General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it had received a patent on two new sweeteners that are 2,000 to 2,500 times sweeter than sugar.

headline: New Hershey Product
abstract: LEAD: The Hershey Foods Corporation today announced a powdered chocolate mix that will be shipped to stores. Earlier this summer, Hershey withdrew its 32-year-old entry in the $200 million a year powdered-chocolate market, Hershey's Instant. The company said it planned a large television and direct mail advertising campaign.

headline: Home Buying Costs Increase
abstract: LEAD: Americans hoping to buy their first homes face the worst conditions in 10 years, the National Association of Realtors said in a report released Wednesday.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  LAW OF THE SEA - PREPARATORY COMMISSION - SPECIAL COMMISSIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Chicago Pacific Tells of Suitor
abstract: LEAD: The Chicago Pacific Corporation said today that it had recently been approached by a group interested in buying the company at a ''substantial premium'' to current market values.

headline: South Africa's Strategy on Angola Falls Short, Enhancing Cubans' Role
abstract: LEAD: South Africa's military strategy in Angola appears to have backfired, placing the Pretoria Government in an uncomfortable bargaining position in the latest round of talks on the Angolan conflict. And the South Africans are finding their image of invincibilty in southern Africa challenged by the Cuban forces allied with the Angolan

headline: Taiwan President Will Also Head Party
abstract: LEAD: In a move that could bolster Taiwan's drive toward democracy, President Lee Teng-hui won the powerful post of ruling party chairman today at a landmark convention that will test the party's commitment to further change.

headline: 9 Reportedly Seized as Suspects in Zia Crash
abstract: LEAD: Nine people, including a Pakistani Air Force officer, were arrested Thursday in connection with the crash that killed President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, a newspaper said today.

headline: Maxwell Lifts Macmillan Takeover Bid to $86.80 a Share
abstract: LEAD: In a surprise move, Robert Maxwell, the British entrepreneur, raised his takeover bid for Macmillan Inc. yesterday to $86.80 a share in cash, or about $2.4 billion.

headline: Soviets Buy More Corn
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 550,000 metric tons of United States corn, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. The sale brought total corn sold to the Soviets in the last four weeks to more than 3.5 million tons. The corn is for delivery in the 1988-89 year, which began Sept. 1.

headline: Rates Spurt at Sale Of Citicorp Paper
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates rose sharply at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper Tuesday.

headline: Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * Sudler & Hennessey will open a health communications agency in Australia called S&H/Melbourne.

headline: INVESTING; Pearls From a Former Shell?
abstract: LEAD: ONE rarely finds a company that has $650 million of annual revenues in the ''pink sheets,''a printed listing of mostly obscure securities. But that is where the stock of Schick Companies Inc. is listed, at about $4 a share.

headline: Eastern Bloc Seeks Trade Ties to West
abstract: LEAD: Countries of the Soviet bloc are scrambling to negotiate preferential trade agreements with the European Community - agreements that they hope will help lower barriers to imports of badly needed Western technology and foster the creation of joint ventures between Western companies and East bloc enterprises.

headline: Florida Steel
abstract: LEAD: The Florida Steel Corporation said that its senior management was considering a leveraged buyout that would involve cash and securities valued in the ''mid-to-high 40's'' a share. The company's shares jumped $3.625 today, to $47, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company has about 6,100,000 shares outstanding.

headline: Cullum Reports Several Offers
abstract: LEAD: Tender offer documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Cullum Companies Inc., a Dallas-based operator of grocery stores, disclosed that the Dart Group Inc. of Landover, Md., and Odyssey Partners of New York, a leveraged buyout group affiliated with Oppenheimer & Company, had expressed an interest in acquiring the company at one time.

headline: Sale of American Savings Is Near
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had nearly completed its long negotiations to give control of the nation's largest insolvent savings institution to a Texas investment group. But it said the deal would not be finished for another month.

headline: HAITI IN TURMOIL IN WAKE OF COUP
abstract: LEAD: Civil disorder increased today in Haiti, with strikes by public employees, widespread violence in the streets and reports of major breaches in the military chain of command three days after a coup.

headline: Israeli Labor Party Opens Campaign; Asks Halt in Rule Over Arabs
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Labor Party opened its campaign for the Nov. 1 parliamentary elections today, vowing to ''terminate Israeli rule over 1.5 million Palestinian Arabs who are inhabitants'' of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

headline: The Downing of Flight 655; Britain Regrets Jet 'Tragedy' And Backs the U.S. Account
abstract: LEAD: Britain said today that it deeply regretted the deaths of those aboard an Iranian airliner shot down in the Persian Gulf this morning, and it endorsed Washington's explanation that American forces believed they were acting in self-defense when they fired on the jet.

headline: Panel Finds Less Support for U.S. Troops Abroad
abstract: LEAD: Citing declining American political support for the deployment of forces abroad, a House Armed Services subcommittee warned today that Western Europe and Japan must rely less on the United States and more on their own forces and funds to defend themselves.

headline: Company News; Enron's Stock Drops Sharply
abstract: LEAD: The stock of the Enron Corporation dropped sharply today after the company said late Wednesday that it would not accept any of the bids submitted last week for its oil and gas subsidiary.

headline: Market Place; Zenith Dissident Meets Skepticism
abstract: LEAD: BROOKHURST PARTNERS' announcement last week that it would begin a consent solicitation against the Zenith Electronics Corporation produced both skepticism and confusion among investors.

headline: Business People; New CBS Radio Chief Is Willing to Take Risks
abstract: LEAD: Nancy C. Widmann, who was recently named the president of the CBS Radio division, attributes her success in the radio business to her hard work, the high quality of her staff and her willingness to take risks.

headline: Senate Delays Move on New Israel Embassy
abstract: LEAD: The Senate has voted to let the next Administration decide whether to build the new United States Embassy in Israel in Jerusalem or in Tel Aviv.

headline: Home Resales Fell 5% in July
abstract: LEAD: Sales of existing single-family homes fell 5 percent in July as mortgage rates moved higher, a real estate trade group reported today. It was the first decline in six months. The National Association of

headline: Fijians Fretting Under One-Man Rule
abstract: LEAD: Beneath a deceptively languid surface, Fijians are fretting under a thinly disguised one-man military Government.

headline: Jail Term for Ex-Banker
abstract: LEAD: A former official of the Ka Wah Bank, Wong Ka-ning, was sentenced to two years in prison by the Hong Kong high court today for conspiring to defraud the bank. Mr. Wong, a 49-year-old Australian citizen, pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the bank with two of its directors between October 1984 and June 1986.

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 443 money market mutual funds decreased by $330.2 million, to $266.35 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 124 institutional funds decreased by $540.3 million, to $68.74 billion. The assets of the 220 general purpose funds were up by $278.3 million, to $83.21 billion.

headline: Britain's Postal Strike Ends With a Settlement
abstract: LEAD: The British post office and the Union of Communication Workers agreed today to settle a strike that has stopped mail deliveries throughout most of the country, but postal officials said it would take a week or two to break up a backlog of 150 million letters and packages.

headline: Suspect Placed in Athens on Eve of Hijacking
abstract: LEAD: Mohammed Ali Hamadei, who is on trial in Frankfurt on charges of air piracy and killing an American hostage, was in Athens on the eve of the hijacking there of a Trans World Airlines jetliner in June 1985, the court was told today.

headline: West Germany Builds Trade Ties With India
abstract: LEAD: Steadily and with quiet efficiency, West Germany has edged past the United States, Japan and Britain as the largest net exporter of goods to India, and both countries envision a growing link in high-technology enterprises.

headline: Rover to Close 2 Plants
abstract: LEAD: The British auto maker Rover Group P.L.C. said this week that it plans to close two plants in the next few years, cutting 3,400 jobs. The company, which currently employs 46,400 people, said it would phase out its car assembly plant in Cowley South, Oxford, by the early 1990's and would shut its pressings factory in Llanelli, Wales, in two years.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Stephen Gardner, Stepher Felter and Marcus Kemp have been named senior vice presidents at Ammirati & Puris.

headline: Why Kroger Was Ripe for Attack
abstract: LEAD: When a takeover fight for the Kroger Company erupted last week, it seemed to confirm what many in the supermarket industry had begun to suspect: that giant publicly traded supermarket chains are an endangered species.

headline: Using Face Lifts to Solve an Identity Crisis
abstract: LEAD: Conference centers are facing an identity crisis. Throughout the early 1980's, their reputation rested on being serious: a campus-like collection of meeting rooms with audio-visual equipment that were dedicated to business use.

headline: Man Arrested in June Killing That Led to 911 Suspension
abstract: LEAD: A 26-year-old Queens man was arrested yesterday for the June 21 murder of his ex-girlfriend, the police said. The murder drew wide attention because a 911 dispatcher apparently delayed at least 20 minutes before sending a car to the scene, and the victim was shot while she was making a second desperate call to police.

headline: Austria Weighs Joining European Community
abstract: LEAD: After years of resisting the idea of joining the European Community, neutral Austria is seriously considering full membership as the organization's 12 members move toward the goal of a single market by 1992, according to Austrian officials and politicians.

headline: Fraud Trial Begins on ZZZZ Best
abstract: LEAD: The fraud trial of Barry J. Minkow, the one-time carpet-cleaning ''whiz kid,'' opened in Federal court here today.

headline: Gannet Rival Joins Foes Of Merger
abstract: LEAD: The Arkansas Democrat of Little Rock will today join the battle over the proposed merger of The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News, taking the side of readers and advertisers who oppose the combination.

headline: PROFITS RISE AT 3 MORE OIL COMPANIES
abstract: LEAD: Three more major oil companies yesterday reported sharp improvements in their earnings in the second quarter, with gains in refining and marketing operations compensating for declining profitability in crude oil production.

headline: New York Area Remains Costly
abstract: LEAD: Prices of single-family homes in New York and the surrounding area are among the highest in the country but are increasing at slower rates than those in Southern California.

headline: Colgate Sells Health Unit to Buyout Group
abstract: LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Kendall hospital-supply and health-care unit and related businesses for $960 million. The buyers are the leveraged-buyout firm of Clayton & Dubilier and Kendall's management.

headline: 4 G.I.'s Wounded in Honduras
abstract: LEAD: Four American soldiers were wounded early today when attackers opened fire and threw grenades at them as they left a discotheque in the northern Honduran city of San Pedro Sula, the police said.

headline: Now, PC's That Read A Page and Store It
abstract: LEAD: The ability of computer programs to accurately read a printed page, including both text and graphics, and store the page's contents in a computer is improving rapidly, and the cost of the software is dropping. This will soon make the new technology widely accessible to many personal computer users and could significantly speed the work flow in many offices.

headline: Freddie Mac Offers Mortgage Program
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday introduced its Multifamily Guarantor Program, whereby the corporation will buy three types of fixed-rate multifamily mortgages from lenders for a like amount of multifamily mortgage participation certificates. Included will be both conventional and Federal Housing Administration mortgages.

headline: Peruvians Combating Red Tape
abstract: LEAD: With Peru caught in its worst economic crisis in decades, the line separating rich and poor here is growing sharper than ever.

headline: Wozniak Unit To Sell Assets
abstract: LEAD: CL9, the company founded by Steve Wozniak to produce a high-technology remote-control device, said it was negotiating the sale of its business, technology and patents.

headline: Afghan Guerrillas Map The Post-Soviet Future
abstract: LEAD: On a summer afternoon in a quiet valley 75 miles southwest of the heavy fighting around Kabul, a group of Afghan guerrilla commanders sat cross-legged, drinking tea and making plans for war against the troops of the Soviet-installed Government.

headline: Market Place; Analysts Wary On Chip Maker
abstract: LEAD: AFTER shocking Wall Street on Monday with a first-quarter loss far bigger than expected, the National Semiconductor Corporation came back yesterday with a broad announcement of new products from its mainframe computer business, National Advanced Systems.

headline: Pan Am Faces Pension Outlay
abstract: LEAD: Pan American World Airways Inc. has said that it might have to pay $119.1 million to cover its annual pension contributions for the fiscal years 1987 and 1988.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Endless Vacation Coming Back to Stands
abstract: LEAD: Endless Vacation, a six-a-year travel magazine that had suspended publication earlier this year, is back with its September-October issue under Horace Sutton, editor, and Milton Glaser, art director.

headline: Third World Tells I.M.F. That Poverty Has Increased
abstract: LEAD: Third world officials painted a stark picture today of how debt burdens, trade barriers and slow growth have combined to worsen living standards for the world's poor.

headline: U.S. Rolls-Royce Losing Chief, Maybe to Porsche
abstract: LEAD: Robert Schwartz, who has had success selling Rolls-Royce automobiles to Americans, is leaving the company amid industry rumors that his next job may be as chief executive at Porsche's American operation, to revive sagging sales there.

headline: GAF Is Charged In Stock-Price Case
abstract: LEAD: Indictments were issued against the GAF Corporation, its vice chairman and two of its subsidiaries on charges that they manipulated the price of Union Carbide stock in 1986 after GAF failed in an attempt to take over Carbide. Prosecutors contend that GAF and Jefferies & Company, a Los Angeles brokerage, agreed for Jefferies to buy large blocks of Carbide stock to inflate the price so that GAF could get a higher return from selling its 10 percent stake in Carbide.

headline: At Hospital Giant, Hint Of a Buyout
abstract: LEAD: Senior executives of the Hospital Corporation of America, the nation's largest hospital operator, said yesterday that they might propose a leveraged buyout for $47 a share, or $3.3 billion.

headline: Nader Criticizes Cadillacs
abstract: LEAD: The consumer advocate Ralph Nader contended today that workmanship on the Cadillac sedan has steadily slipped since the early 1970's.

headline: Talks in Brazil Please Shultz
abstract: LEAD: Arriving here today after a weeklong tour of Latin America, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said he was pleased with talks held in Brasilia with Brazilian leaders. The talks, held Friday, concerned Central American security and a trade dispute between the United States and Brazil.

headline: Iraq Trying to Buy an Idled Steel Works in Texas
abstract: LEAD: The USX Corporation wants to sell its idled Texas steel works to Iraq for more than $100 million. Iraq wants to take the plant apart and ship it home, where it would be reassembled and used to produce pipes for oil production and irrigation.

headline: Partial Pact In Boesky Case Seen
abstract: LEAD: A major settlement will be announced this week in a group of lawsuits against the investors in Ivan F. Boesky & Company, the investment vehicle for the fallen Wall Street speculator, people involved in the suits said yesterday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Marc Goldstein has joined Lintas:USA as senior vice president, director of national broadcast media and programming, for both Lintas:New York and Lintas:Campbell-Ewald.

headline: MILITARY CABINET NAMED IN LEBANON
abstract: LEAD: President Amin Gemayel appointed a military government headed by a Christian general to rule Lebanon today after a deeply divided Parliament failed to choose a successor for him on the last day of his six-year term.

headline: Cigna to Sell Horace Mann for $500 Million
abstract: LEAD: The Cigna Corporation agreed today to sell the Horace Mann Companies, a personal insurance company that sells mainly to teachers, for about $500 million in cash to a group led by the leveraged buyout firm Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd.

headline: Company News; Drexel Said To Expect Charges
abstract: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert is stepping up its campaign to brace employees and major customers to the likelihood that it faces impending charges of securities law violations, several customers of the firm said yesterday.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Robert Skollar has been promoted to senior vice president at Grey Advertising.

headline: Output Rate Up to 83.5% Of Capacity
abstract: LEAD: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 83.5 percent of capacity in July, the highest operating level in eight years.

headline: To Live and Breathe in L.A.
abstract: LEAD: LIKE Disneyland or Hollywood, smog has long been a symbol of Southern California. Now environmentalists, Government officials and the business community here are debating whether the cost of solving the intractable problem is the reining in of a local economy that has been as vibrant and unfettered as the air is dirty.

headline: Former Apollo Officer Joins Honeywell Bull
abstract: LEAD: Roland D. Pampel, who resigned a week ago as president and chief operating officer of Apollo Computer Inc., has been named president of Honeywell Bull Inc.

headline: SCHOOLS FOR ARABS CLOSED BY ISRAELIS
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of Arab students pelted Israeli soldiers with rocks and blocked a main road here today. The Israeli Army ordered all West Bank Arab schools closed for three days, beginning Tuesday, in an effort to limit student participation in the Palestinian uprising.

headline: Iran Is Said to Use 'Pressure' on Iraqi Captives
abstract: LEAD: A United Nations report on prisoners in the Persian Gulf war accuses Iran of using ''mental pressure'' to turn Iraqi captives into pro-Khomeini militants who could riot if forced to return home.

headline: British Barracks Bombed in West Germany
abstract: LEAD: A bomb exploded at a British Army barracks here today, injuring three soldiers and a civilian and tearing off part of the roof, a military spokesman said.

headline: Angolans Strive for Military Victory
abstract: LEAD: Angola's leadership appears determined to press for a military victory in the country's 13-year-old civil war, despite African, American and Soviet appeals for a negotiated settlement.

headline: Northwest Cuts Fares
abstract: LEAD: Northwest Airlines, a subsidiary of NWA Inc., today cut its lowest discount fares in more than 500 markets, with reductions ranging from $6 to $150 for round-trip tickets. Northwest also said adult passengers who begin their trips in Louisville, Ky.; Buffalo, and the Wisconsin cities of Green Bay and Madison would be eligible for children's excursion fares on tickets bought in July for travel during off-peak periods.

headline: Chrysler Rebate
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation increased cash incentives for its Eagle Premier automobiles to $750 from $600, retroactive to Sunday. The nation's third-largest car maker said the incentives would be available on 1988 and 1989 models and the offer would be available indefinitely. The company said it sold 2,058 of the cars in the first 20 days of August, down 10.8 percent from the 2,281 sold in the July period.

headline: U.S. Experts Helping Zia Crash Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: The United States sent two teams of experts to Pakistan today to help the Government investigate the airplane explosion that killed the nation's President and the American Ambassador there. State Department officials said they had growing suspicions, but no proof, that sabotage was a factor in the crash.

headline: BUKHARIN'S STATUS IN PARTY RESTORED
abstract: LEAD: A Communist Party commission reviewing the repressions under Stalin announced today that Nikolai I. Bukharin, among the most prominent victims of Stalin's terror, was posthumously reinstated as a member of the party on June 21.

headline: Market for Swaps Totaled $1.1 Trillion at End of 1987
abstract: LEAD: The market for interest-rate and currency swaps totaled about $1.1 trillion at the end of 1987, remaining one of the fastest-growing sectors of the financial markets, according to a recent survey by the International Swap Dealers Association.

headline: Consumer Rates; Yields Rise On C.D.'s
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were up for the week ended yesterday, much the same pattern of the past few weeks.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Sets 10% Purchase of Octel
abstract: LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it would buy a 10 percent stake in the Octel Communications Corporation, a fast-growing Silicon Valley company that supplies voice-processing systems. Octel products will also be distributed in Europe under the Hewlett-Packard name.

headline: Acquisition Set By Ultramar
abstract: LEAD: Ultramar P.L.C., a British-based petroleum exploration and development company, said today that it had agreed to buy a California oil refinery owned by the Union Pacific Corporation for $440 million.

headline: Article 623988 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: A committee of the General Assembly agreed today to raise $35.7 million to pay for the first three months of a peacekeeping force to monitor the cease-fire between Iran and Iraq.

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 440 money market mutual funds decreased $1.93 billion, to $264.36 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 122 institutional funds decreased $851.3 million, to $70.10 billion. Assets of the 220 general purpose funds were down $390.0 million, to $81.44 billion.

headline: Burlington Motor
abstract: LEAD: Burlington Motor Carriers Inc., the trucking subsidiary of Burlington Northern Inc., has been spun off to an investor group in a leveraged buyout for $90 million. The buyout group includes the company's senior management, and investment bankers from Lepercq, de Neuflize & Company; Chase Manhattan Bank, and Alex.

headline: The U.S. Needs Foreign Investors
abstract: LEAD: ECONOMIC nationalism is on the rise and foreign investment in America is increasingly a target. A recent survey showed that 78 percent of the public would favor limiting foreign investment in this country and 40 percent would like to halt it altogether. Politicians are pandering to the public's fears and advocating restrictions on foreign investments.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 18, 1988:  MONDAY

headline: Action Taken by Unisys
abstract: LEAD: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that it was undertaking several ''corrective'' actions in response to a Government investigation of the company's military contracting practices.

headline: Bank of Nova Scotia Joins Flurry of Bank Offerings
abstract: LEAD: Last week's flurry of bank debt offerings in the corporate market, the result of recent movements in interest rates, raised the total amount of new bank issues over the last two weeks to more than $2 billion, or nearly a third of all straight debt offerings during the same period.

headline: Loss Posted At Federated
abstract: LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc., which has been restructured since being acquired by the Campeau Corporation, today reported a second-quarter loss of $100 million, on sales of $970.5 million.

headline: Collecting Recyclables For Profits and Grades
abstract: LEAD: ON the campus of Rutgers University in New Jersey, students at the business and engineering schools are participating in an unusual experiment: sifting through barrels of discarded plastic garbage.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD: THE ECONOMY  Orders for machine tools rose 17.8 percent in June. The amount of total orders, $382.5 million, was up 88.6 percent from a year earlier. Experts said the increase reflected strong capital spending as businesses gained confidence in the economy. [ Page D1. ] Trucking companies are struggling to recruit drivers.

headline: A Fresh Look to Help Ad Council's Vote Effort
abstract: LEAD: Backer Spielvogel Bates has given a new, fresh look to an old, traditional advertising chore - the get-out-the-vote campaign for the Advertising Council.

headline: Pretoria Willing to Discuss Atom Ban
abstract: LEAD: South Africa has told Britain, the Soviet Union and the United States that it is prepared to discuss renouncing nuclear weapons and opening all its atomic establishments to international inspection, diplomats and officials here say.

headline: AMC Plans to Sell 605 Movie Theaters
abstract: LEAD: AMC Entertainment Inc. said it plans to sell about 40 percent of its movie theater screens for about $200 million to New York-based TPI Enterprises Inc. The Kansas City-based movie theater chain, which owns almost 25 percent of TPI's stock, would manage the theaters, under the AMC name, and would continue to negotiate for their films.

headline: Zia Is Buried Before a Muted and Prayerful Throng
abstract: LEAD: Beneath the four white marble minarets of a mosque that looms over this capital, President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was buried today in a military funeral attended by at least 100,000 Pakistanis.

headline: Baltic Demonstrations: A Gamble for Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: The slogans and speeches in the three Baltic republics Tuesday night must have burned the ears of the more conservative colleagues of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. The speakers, Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians who had received official permission to assemble, called for independence from Moscow, equated Communism with the Nazi swastika and accused the Soviet authorities of falsifying history.

headline: Purchasers Report June Expansion
abstract: LEAD: An increase in production and new orders, fueled by a growth in exports, helped the economy expand in June at the largest rate since December, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report scheduled for release today.

headline: Beverly Hills Savings Shift
abstract: LEAD: Federal savings and loan assoiciation regulators have forced the resignation of Beverly Hills Savings and Loan's chairman, Thomas F. Carter, one of a number of directors installed by regulators after the insolvent thrift institution was seized in 1985. Mr. Carter resigned effective

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 443 money market mutual funds increased by $276.2 million, to $266.61 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 123 institutional funds decreased by $310.5 million, to $69.21 billion. The assets of the 220 general-purpose funds were up by $284.2 million, to $82.93 billion.

headline: Reebok Executive Settles Insider Case With S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: A vice president of Reebok International Ltd. today settled insider-trading charges that accused him of selling shares of Avia Group International Inc. because he had confidential information that Reebok would merge with its smaller rival.

headline: U.N. Plans $35 Million for Conference Centers
abstract: LEAD: The United Nations plans to spend up to $35 million in 1990 and 1991 to build conference centers in Addis Ababa and Bangkok, according to unpublished budget projections prepared by the Secretariat and made available to member governments.

headline: Burmese Curfew Is Lifted
abstract: LEAD: The authorities today lifted a dusk-to-dawn curfew imposed in Rangoon after thousands of students rioted in the streets June 21, the state radio said. A ban on public gatherings also was lifted, the broadcast said. According to the Government, six policemen and three civilians were killed in the rioting.

headline: President of Fotomat Resigns After 3 Years
abstract: LEAD: The effort to turn around the fortunes of the Fotomat Corporation has gone slowly, and John R. Chase, the company's president for three years, is leaving.

headline: Sprinkel Is Optimistic On Growth and Inflation
abstract: LEAD: As part of a cheery, partisan appraisal of the Reagan era, Beryl W. Sprinkel, the President's chief economist, said today that the economy could keep growing at about its current pace without risking higher interest rates and inflation.

headline: Mutual Fund Sales Decline
abstract: LEAD: Monthly mutual fund sales fell to $7.1 billion in May, compared with $9 billion in April and $13.5 billion in May 1987, the Investment Company Institute said today.

headline: GLOBAL BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Peru's economy minister resigned Friday, three months after taking office, after a Government report showed that inflation had soared a record 243 percent in the first eight months of the year. President Alan Garcia Perez immediately appointed a new economy minister, Abel Salinas, to fill the post vacated by Cesar Robles, according to the official newspaper, El Peruano.

headline: Penrod Plan Is Approved
abstract: LEAD: A Federal bankrupcty court has approved a plan to convert the Penrod Drilling Company into a corporation that will be 50 percent controlled by the banks that are creditors of the trust estates of the Hunts of Texas.

headline: About Real Estate; Dispute Over Connecticut Site Ends
abstract: LEAD: A fiercely debated redevelopment site in Greenwich, Conn. - the 20-acre Electrolux factory site next to the Old Greenwich Metro North station - is finally entering the construction phase.

headline: Station for Sale In Connecticut
abstract: LEAD: Viacom International Inc. has put WVIT-TV, Channel 30, up for sale. The station is the NBC affiliate in the Hartford-New Haven market.

headline: Rivals Set Challenge To I.B.M.
abstract: LEAD: Since its entry into the personal computer market, the International Business Machines Corporation has been the standard setter for design of the internal workings of the desktop computer.

headline: I.B.M. in Joint Deal On Trading System
abstract: LEAD: I.B.M. said it is developing a portfolio trading system in a joint arrangement with Sumitomo Bank Capital Markets and Decision Software. The system, intended to automate the flow of paper generated by securities trading, will use the PC/RT work station made by the International Business Machines Corporation.
