headline: NBC Faces a Tough Fight As Olympics Ratings Lag
abstract: LEAD: Like some American athletes at the Summer Olympic Games, the National Broadcasting Company is finding that the competition is tougher than expected.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Agence Havas, France's largest media group, announced a restructuring this week, including the breakup of a friendly group of institutional shareholders.

headline: A Deficit That Will Avoid Spending Cuts Is Projected
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration predicted today that the budget deficit in the fiscal year 1989 would be $144 billion - low enough to avoid the automatic spending cuts that are specified by the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law.

headline: Dissidents See Scherer Victory
abstract: LEAD: The dissident shareholders of the R. P. Scherer Corporation said today that their candidates would win two contested seats on the board when the offical results are announced on Wednesday. A group organized by Karla

headline: Southmark Expects Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Southmark Corporation said it expects to report a sizable loss for the year ended June 30 because of higher reserves against deterioration in the real estate and securities markets.

headline: Kenya Bars Rights Lawyer From Visiting U.S.
abstract: LEAD: In the last four months, Gibson Kamau Kuria, a Kenyan lawyer, has received four invitations to visit the United States and be honored.

headline: News Digests By Facsimile
abstract: LEAD: USA Today, the newspaper known for its concise writing, has come up with a package for people who find its regular package too bulky.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Pepperell Names Official To Position at Stevens
abstract: LEAD: West Point-Pepperell Inc., one of the nation's leading textile companies, has appointed a senior executive as the president of J. P. Stevens & Company, which it acquired in May for $1.2 billion.

headline: Stricter Observance of Afghan Pact Pledged
abstract: LEAD: The parties to the accords on Afghanistan have agreed to overlook some 400 accusations of Pakistani violations, to guarantee better access for United Nations forces monitoring compliance and to observe the agreement more strictly, the top official overseeing the settlement said.

headline: Hirohito Watches TV To Catch Sumo Match
abstract: LEAD: Emperor Hirohito lay in serious condition today but was alert enough to watch the finals of the autumn sumo tournament on television, the Imperial Household Agency said.

headline: Promoting C.D.'s With Politics
abstract: LEAD: Trying to harness the excitement over Presidential politics, several savings associations are offering bonuses to depositors who pick the winner of the election.

headline: Trade Bill Nears Passage As Key Obstacle Is Cleared
abstract: LEAD: A bill ushering in the broadest overhaul of trade policy in the postwar era is expected to become law soon, following President Reagan's decision today not to veto a separate measure requiring companies to provide 60 days' notice of layoffs or factory closings.

headline: GROWTH OF LOCAL-NEWS STATION IS WATCHED BY CABLE INDUSTRY
abstract: LEAD: Every day, 24 hours a day, the news of Long Island flows from a small cable television studio here to more than 540,000 homes in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

headline: CRUSADING PROFESSOR: Louis Lowenstein; From C.E.O. to Corporate Critic
abstract: LEAD: LOUIS LOWENSTEIN'S opinions make Frederick H. Joseph, head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., fulminate. Mr. Lowenstein so irritated Irwin L. Jacobs, the takeover specialist, that ''I told him it was pathetic he was teaching kids, especially at a prestigious place like Columbia,'' Mr. Jacobs said. Barron's, the investor's weekly, described Mr.

headline: De Laurentiis Entertainment Seeks Chapter 11 Protection
abstract: LEAD: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group Inc., the financially troubled film company founded by the Italian-born producer Dino De Laurentiis, filed today for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

headline: An F.T.C. Rule Is Reviewed
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would consider easing rules covering purchases of 10 percent or less of a company's stock.

headline: Company News; Data Concern Dispute Settled
abstract: LEAD: The West Publishing Company and Mead Data Central Inc. said yesterday that they had settled their three-year dispute between Westlaw and Lexis, two computer research systems marketed by the companies and used by thousands of lawyers, judges and academics.

headline: Another Deadly Parisian Train Crash
abstract: LEAD: A passenger train slammed into a barrier at a railroad station here today, killing one person and injuring 57, the Paris fire department said.

headline: INVESTING; Behind the Collapse in the Price of Gold
abstract: LEAD: IN the last two weeks, prices of precious metals have dropped sharply. On Wednesday, gold fell below $400 an ounce to its lowest level in more than a year and a half. And many experts expect prices to fall even more in coming months. The slide has convinced some portfolio strategists and economists that an increase in the rate of inflation - a threat that has hung over the financial markets since the

headline: Technology for Korea
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's imports of advanced technology for machinery and other projects rose 49 percent in the first half of this year from a year earlier, Government officials said today. Japan was the largest supplier of technology, with 181 imports, followed by the United States with 90 and European nations with 46.

headline: Yield Set at 9.41% In Masco Offering
abstract: LEAD: The Masco Corporation, a manufacturer of building and home improvement products based in Taylor, Mich., is offering $300 million of 9 1/4 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.375 to yield 9.41 percent through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

headline: Product Introductions Fell a Bit in August
abstract: LEAD: Even though the drop was slight, August was the fourth month this year that had a decrease in product introductions, compared with comparable months in 1987, according to Gorman's New Product News.

headline: U.S. SEES NO BAR TO ARMS IN ANGOLA
abstract: LEAD: American officials say the new Angola peace plan does not prevent the United States from continuing to send weapons and ammunition to Angolan guerrillas fighting against the Soviet-backed Government in Luanda.

headline: Japan Gain for U.S. Builders
abstract: LEAD: Three of Japan's leading companies plan to help United States concerns win Japanese construction licenses, an official of the Mitsui Trust and Banking Corporation said today.

headline: Dollar Doings
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Mexican Victor Urges Party To Adapt to New Challenge
abstract: LEAD: After the official announcement of his victory in the presidential election, Carlos Salinas de Gortari of the ruling party urged his supporters today to adapt to the new political landscape.

headline: U.S.-Japan Food Accord
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Japan signed a farm trade agreement Tuesday. The Reagan Administration expects it to double American exports of processed food products to Japan, to $160 million annually, by 1990. Japan is to phase out quotas on imports in seven categories, including dairy and fruit items, while increasing quotas in two others and compensating the United States for keeping restrictions in two others.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Chevron Canada Resources Ltd., Calgary, a unit of Chevron Corp., said it would purchase the assets of Columbia Gas Development of Canada Ltd.'s Eastern properties for $82.75 million.

headline: Rumrill-Hoyt Resigns From a Pfizer Account
abstract: LEAD: Nicholas I. Orloff, the president of Rumrill-Hoyt, and Gale A. Johnson, the senior vice president and director of public relations, were in town from Rochester last week to resign Pfizer Inc.'s United States Animal Health Operations account.

headline: Yugoslav Politburo Member Resigns Over Ethnic Dispute
abstract: LEAD: Franc Setinc, a Slovenian member of the Yugoslav Communist Party Politburo, resigned today to protest Serbian agitation over ethnic troubles in Kosovo Province, Tanjug press agency said.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Unisys Corporation yesterday priced $200 million of 9 percent notes, due 1993, through competitive bidding.

headline: Dalkon Shield Trust Fund Organizes
abstract: LEAD: The panel that will direct the $2.47 billion Dalkon Shield trust fund has taken preliminary steps to organize itself and prepare to disburse the money.

headline: Britain Signs Deal With Saudis, Replacing U.S. as Big Arms Supplier
abstract: LEAD: Britain announced a major arms agreement with Saudi Arabia today, apparently involving planes, helicopters, ships and construction projects in a 10-year arrangement that will replace the United States as the Arab kingdom's main arms supplier.

headline: Goldsmith/Jeffrey Wins El Al Account
abstract: LEAD: Goldsmith/Jeffrey, an agency begun a little more than a year ago, has been awarded the El Al Israel Airlines account. The budget is $1 million, bringing the agency's billings to more than $15 million.

headline: In a Poll, Americans Appear To Lose Sympathy for Israel
abstract: LEAD: The number of Americans sympathetic to Israel declined from 48 percent in February to 37 percent in April in the wake of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, according to a poll released yesterday by the American Jewish Committee.

headline: Belfast Shipyard Plan
abstract: LEAD: The British Government confirmed today that it planned to sell the troubled Northern Ireland shipyard Harland & Wolff and said Ravi Tikoo, an India-born shipping entrepreneur, might be the buyer. Mr. Tikoo wants to build the world's biggest luxury cruise liner in the Belfast yard, which has 4,000 workers.

headline: Litton Profits Rise by 23.4%
abstract: LEAD: Litton Industries, a maker of electronics gear, ships and automated factory equipment, said today that its profits rose 23.4 percent in the fourth quarter and 20.9 percent in the fiscal year.

headline: Coastal in Deal With China
abstract: LEAD: The Coastal Corporation and a company owned by the Government of China today announced plans to form a joint venture to own and operate Coastal's West Coast refining and marketing properties. The announcement said

headline: Army Called as Police Rebel in Indian State
abstract: LEAD: Indian Army troops were instructed today to maintain order in parts of the western state of Gujarat after a revolt there by thousands of police officers.

headline: U.N. PRESSES IRAQ TO STOP BLOCKING A GULF CEASE-FIRE
abstract: LEAD: Iraq came under increasing pressure in the United Nations today after raising a new obstacle to an early cease-fire in the eight-year-old Persian Gulf war.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Treasury Offering Only Bills This Week
abstract: LEAD: The schedule of new Treasury issues for this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills.

headline: BURMA ARMY URGED TO AID PROTESTERS
abstract: LEAD: Large crowds gathered Friday at the Shwe Dagon Pagoda in Rangoon, where speakers called on the army to support the peaceful but leaderless insurrection that has turned much of the Burmese population against the Government.

headline: U.S. TIES ARMS DEAL TO A SOVIET RADAR
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that it would complete no new arms control agreements with the Soviet Union until Moscow agreed to dismantle a disputed radar station.

headline: Open Positions on Short Sales Decline by 0.5% on Nasdaq
abstract: LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a five-tenths of 1 percent monthly drop in the ''short interest'' for the most-active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

headline: Report About S.E.C. Post
abstract: LEAD: Congressional staff members said today that Mary Schapiro, the general counsel of the Futures Industry Association, is the leading contender to fill the vacancy on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: South Africa Cracks Down on Anti-Draft Group
abstract: LEAD: The Government restricted an anti-draft organization today, under nationwide emergency laws.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Creative Pair Shifts Style At D.D.B.
abstract: LEAD: ROBERT MACKALL and John Mariucci, executive vice presidents and executive creative directors of DDB Needham, are following in the footsteps of Bob Gage, Bob Levenson, Margin Honig, Roy Grace and John Noble, all of whom were past creative leaders at Doyle Dane Bernbach. But they are the first to do the job as a duet.

headline: Failure Admitted By OPEC
abstract: LEAD: After five years of trying to reverse the drop in oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that the effort had failed and that it had to search for ''a new approach'' or face the possibility of another collapse of prices next year.

headline: As Its Problems Mount, Rio Declares Bankruptcy
abstract: LEAD: After quarreling with bankers and creditors for weeks, the Mayor of Rio de Janeiro has publicly declared the city in a state of bankruptcy.

headline: Farm Credit System Offering Is Scheduled
abstract: LEAD: The schedule of new Treasury issues for this holiday-shortened week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

headline: Dome Officers to Resign
abstract: LEAD: Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, said this week that four of its five senior executives had decided against taking up offers to join Amoco Canada Petroleum Ltd., after the Amoco Corporation unit merges with Dome. Resigning are Howard Macdonald, chairman; John M. Beddome, president, and two senior vice presidents, H.

headline: U.S. SEES INCREASE IN AFGHAN OPIUM
abstract: LEAD: The State Department said today that it expected an increase in the illegal cultivation of opium in Afghanistan after Soviet troops completed their withdrawal from that country.

headline: New Structure At Raychem
abstract: LEAD: The Raychem Corporation, a manufacturer of plastic insulation materials based in Menlo Park, Calif., said today that Paul M. Cook, its chairman and chief executive, and Robert M. Halperin, its president and chief operating officer, would work together in the new office of chairman.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: CNW Adds No. 2 Post To Ease Chief's Load
abstract: LEAD: The CNW Corporation, a major railroad company whose chief executive, James R. Wolfe, is ailing, announced yesterday that it had named Robert W. Schmiege president and chief operating officer in a move to ease the burden on Mr. Wolfe.

headline: Irish Distillers Bid To Undergo Study
abstract: LEAD: A takeover bid for the Irish Distillers Group P.L.C., the makers of Jameson's and Bushmills whiskies, has been referred to the Fair Trade Commission. The bid of 198.5 million Irish pounds, or about $312 million, for the maker of Ireland's top whiskies, was made last month by two British companies, the soft drink manufacturer Cantrell & Cochrane, and Gilbeys of Ireland, makers of Bailey's Original Irish Cream

headline: Article 585588 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: MNC Financial Inc. is issuing $300 million of variable-rate renewable notes through Goldman, Sachs & Company. The initial coupon yield is 8.30 percent, scheduled to be reset monthly at 17 basis points over the 30-day commercial paper money-market equivalent.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Shultz's Aim: Isolating Sandinistas?
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit to Central America last week appeared to be a renewed effort to isolate Nicaragua at a time when the Reagan Administration is perceived to be weakening and its policy toward the Sandinistas is seen to be in disarray, according to diplomats and government officials in the region.

headline: 2 Whites Die in Blast at a Johannesburg Stadium
abstract: LEAD: Two whites were killed and 29 other people, including two blacks and an Asian, were wounded today when a car bomb exploded as 10,000 spectators were leaving a sports stadium at the end of a major rugby match.

headline: Magazine Pursues Advertisers for the High School Market
abstract: LEAD: High School Sports magazine, which has quietly addressed almost three million students for more than three years, has begun a campaign to sell the advertising world on an economically powerful age group that spends more than $80 billion a year on everything from sneakers to stereos to groceries.

headline: Profit Doubles At Berkshire
abstract: LEAD: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. reported today that its second-quarter profit more than doubled to $94.4 million, or $82.37 a share, from $46.2 million, or $40.31 a share, partly as a result of a lower tax rate.

headline: 2,000 Missing in India Floods
abstract: LEAD: About 2,000 people are missing in devastating floods in four states in northern India, flood control officials said today. They said five days of nonstop monsoon rains caused floods over huge areas of Punjab, Himachal Pradesh and Haryana states and flashfloods in mountainous Jammu and Kashmir. The official death toll in the four states stood at 330 today, but the figure is expected to rise.

headline: Korean Talks Adjourn in a Deadlock
abstract: LEAD: Talks between North and South Korea ended in a deadlock today, with the two sides saying they had no plans to resume meetings until after the Olympic Games in Seoul are over in October.

headline: Steel Restraints
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: INTERNATIONAL REPORT: GLOBAL BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: Iraq is to sell 47 state-run factories in a drive to spur private industry, The Baghdad Observer said. Hussein Kamel, the new Minister of Industry and Military Industrialization, told a recent meeting of business officials that the sale was ''designed to give a wider role for this sector in pushing forward Iraq's economic development.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD: General Assembly  Meets at 10 A.M.

headline: Teheran Reports Successes Along the Battlefront
abstract: LEAD: Iran said today that its troops drove Iraqi soldiers occupying four towns back to the border and blunted a new Iraqi offensive elsewhere. Iraq said it withdrew from occupied areas.

headline: Talking to Machines: Progress Is Speeded
abstract: LEAD: Designing a computer-based system that can recognize human speech has long been a cherished goal of artificial intelligence researchers and linguists. After almost three decades of agonizingly slow progress, some researchers believe they are closing in on the ability to create machines that can recognize naturally spoken language from a variety of different speakers.

headline: Key T.W.A. Executive To Go to Lifeco Service
abstract: LEAD: Morton Ehrlich, a top officer at Trans World Airlines Inc. and a key architect of its recovery after its takeover by Carl C. Icahn, resigned yesterday to become the president of the Lifeco Service Corporation, a travel company.

headline: VOLVO BROADENS A SPORTS MARKETING STRATEGY
abstract: LEAD: When the National Football League played its first exhibition game in continental Europe last month, it came to Goteborg, Sweden's leading industrial center and the headquarters town of A.B. Volvo, the game's sponsor.

headline: PNC to Acquire Delaware Bank
abstract: LEAD: The PNC Financial Corporation, an aggressive super-regional banking company based in Pittsburgh, said today that it would acquire the Bank of Delaware Corporation, the second-largest banking company in the state, for $230 million in stock. ''The merger will expand

headline: Big Investors Meet Texaco
abstract: LEAD: Representatives of two groups with large positions in Texaco Inc. stock met yesterday with James W. Kinnear, Texaco's chief executive, about ways they could have more say on the company's board.

headline: Turnaround Specialist Settles In at Franklin
abstract: LEAD: The Franklin Computer Corporation is the third company that Morton E. David has turned around. It may be his last, because Mr. David appears to have found a home at Franklin, and he intends to stay put as chairman and chief executive.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * New Hampshire Housing Finance Authority is issuing $75 million of single-family residential serial mortgage bonds priced at par with yields ranging from 6 percent in 1990 to 8.9 percent in 2020, through Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.

headline: A Shift by Sears On Appliance Sales
abstract: LEAD: In a first for the nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Company stores will offer appliances and home electronic equipment carrying outside brand names starting Thursday in 13 Indiana stores. Some 60 national brands, including Sears's Kenmore appliances, will be available.

headline: Dollar Declines Widely After Central Banks Act
abstract: LEAD: The dollar fell against all major currencies in busy trading yesterday after the central banks of West Germany and several European nations raised key interest rates.

headline: Insider Link Cited by U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Stephen S. Wang Jr., the financial analyst charged in June with engaging in an insider trading scheme with an investor from Taiwan, was paid $7,000 from a checking account in the name of an individual whose stock trading was illegal, according to court papers.

headline: Angola Confirms Pullout by Pretoria's Forces
abstract: LEAD: A top Angolan military officer confirmed today that all South African troops had left Angola, as South Africa reported on Tuesday.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Armor All Products Corp., Irvine, Calif., said it had agreed to acquire the car-care unit of Borden Inc. for about $26 million.

headline: Unisex Insurance Rules Are Upheld
abstract: LEAD: Massachusetts last week joined Montana as the only states that prohibit life insurance companies from charging men higher rates than women - a common practice.

headline: AT LEAST 700 DEAD IN A MAJOR QUAKE IN THE HIMALAYAS
abstract: LEAD: A devastating earthquake rumbled across eastern India and Nepal before dawn Sunday, killing more than 700 people.

headline: Soviets Face Up to an Alien: The Specter of Bankruptcies
abstract: LEAD: Soviet banks today released a list of industrial enterprises that cannot pay their bills, with a pointed warning that the Government plans to begin forcing failing companies into bankruptcy.

headline: Mugabe Wins Anti-Hunger Prize
abstract: LEAD: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe was named yesterday as the winner of a prize given to African leaders who have worked to increase food production and end hunger.

headline: Detained Foe of Apartheid Is Hospitalized
abstract: LEAD: A black member of a labor group that opposes apartheid has been admitted to a hospital in Johannesburg in serious condition after more than two years in detention under South Africa's emergency laws, the police said today.

headline: Polish Unrest, in 10th Day, Shows Signs of Waning
abstract: LEAD: The latest round of labor unrest in Poland appeared on the wane today, as strikes ended at five coal mines and work resumed at a rail repair yard and large turbine factory.

headline: Statement by Joint Chiefs' Chairman: 'U.S. Deeply Regrets This Incident' . . . but Commanders on the Scene Believed 'Their Units Were in Jeopardy'
abstract: LEAD: Following is a transcript of the briefing conducted today by Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff:  OPENING STATEMENT

headline: Investment Plan For General Tire
abstract: LEAD: Continental A.G., the German-based parent of General Tire Inc., plans capital investments totaling $470 million to improve General's plants in the next four years, Continental's chairman, Horst W. Urban, said. The investments will be in addition to $220 million in previously announced capital expenditures.

headline: In a Time of Openness, Things Worth Reading Remain Elusive
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet reader in the days of glasnost knows the frustration of Tantalus. The rich fruits of Moscow spring hang on the branches, many of them no longer forbidden but just out of reach.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, an insurer, promoted Stephen B. Middlebrook to senior vice president and general counsel.

headline: A Triumphant Showing for ESPN
abstract: LEAD: Advertiser-supported cable services are coming into their own. Nowhere is that clearer than at ESPN Inc., the sports service that is 80 percent owned by Capital Cities/ABC Inc. and 20 percent owned by RJR Nabisco Inc.

headline: COMPANY NEWS Fieldstone in Deal For BCE Holdings
abstract: LEAD: The Fieldstone Company, a San Diego home builder, said it had agreed to buy most of the Southern California land holdings of the BCE Development Corporation for $250 million. The holdings include 2,700 acres near the La Costa Spa and Resort in Carlsbad, Calif. The deal includes the purchase of the land near La Costa, where 3,000 houses are planned;a stake in a resort development on Catalina Island, offshore California, and an option to become an equal partner with BCE in a 1,200-acre northern San

headline: 200,000 Youths Said to Be in World's Armies
abstract: LEAD: The world's armies include about 200,000 youths, some as young as 12 years of age, according to a report issued to a United Nations human rights meeting. Governments forcibly conscript many of the youths, the report said, and parents urge others to join to help the family gain food or money.

headline: Mandela Reportedly Treated In Hospital for Lung Trouble
abstract: LEAD: Nelson Mandela, the imprisoned leader of the outlawed African National Congress, has been hospitalized with a lung ailment, the South African Press Association said today.

headline: Profits Rise At 7 Big Oil Companies
abstract: LEAD: Seven oil companies yesterday reported sharply higher earnings in the second quarter, reflecting strong profits in oil refining and marketing operations, as well as higher returns from chemical operations.

headline: Japan Consumer Prices
abstract: LEAD: Consumer prices in Japan fell two-tenths of 1 percent in July from the previous month, but rose five-tenths from the year before, the Government's Management and Coordination Agency said today. The year-to-year increase marked the 14th monthly rise in a row. Prices had also fallen in June by two-tenths, but were up by the same amount from the previous year.

headline: Senate Criticizes the Chinese On Missile Sales in Mideast
abstract: LEAD: The Senate today approved $15 billion for the State, Justice and Commerce Departments after calling on the Reagan Administration to reassess relations with China if Beijing does not stop selling missiles in the Middle East.

abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization            Aug. 19   Aug. 12   Aug. 21       1988   1988   1987       Gasoline production, daily   7.0   6.9   6.9        Distillate production, daily   2.8   2.8   2.7        Gasoline stocks   214.8   214.4   227.7        Distillate stocks   123.0   120.9   121.3        Crude imports, daily   4.5   5.6   5.8        Product imports, daily   1.9   1.9   1.6        Crude stocks   340.0   344.3   330.5        Crude production, daily   8.2   8.2   8.2        Refinery utilization (%)   87.3   87.6   86.3

headline: Dollar Firm In Spite of Pressures
abstract: LEAD: The dollar held firm against major foreign currencies yesterday, despite efforts by the Federal Reserve, the Bank of England and the Bundesbank of West Germany to slow its advance.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Michael Daly has been elected senior vice president at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver.

headline: ABC Suing Israeli Agency for Showing News Tapes
abstract: LEAD: The ABC television network is suing an Israeli media relations agency for showing taped copies of the network's evening news coverage of the Arab uprising.

headline: Unisys Loan of Computers Is Said to Be Under Scrutiny
abstract: LEAD: The Army and a Congressional committee are investigating whether the Unisys Corporation illegally supplied computers to the National Guard in 1986 without having received a valid order for the equipment, committee officials say.

headline: Economic Growth Even Stronger, But So Is Inflation, Revision Shows
abstract: LEAD: The nation's economic growth during the spring was stronger than previously reported, despite the depressing effect of the drought. With the growth, however, came the specter of inflation.

headline: LVMH Names Board Officials
abstract: LEAD: LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton announced today that Alain Chevalier would continue to head the world's largest luxury goods conglomerate as president of a six-member board.

headline: U.S. Shift on the Dollar; Administration, Which Cheered Big Drop, Views Recent Recovery as an Overall Plus
abstract: LEAD: For the last three years the Reagan Administration was eager to see the dollar fall so that exports could climb. But during the dollar's remarkable surge in the last month, the officials in Washington have been uncommonly quiet.

headline: Sallie Mae Markets Variable-Rate Issue
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $250 million of short-term floating-rate notes due in 1993 at par through various dealers.

headline: Iraq Chief Insists on Broad Accord, Not Just Truce
abstract: LEAD: President Saddam Hussein said today that his country could not settle for a cease-fire that would only ''temporarily freeze'' war activities, and that it was seeking a comprehensive peace agreement with Iran and the normalization of relations.

headline: Macmillan Rejects Bid Of Maxwell
abstract: LEAD: Macmillan Inc. said today that it had rejected the $2.1 billion takeover offer from Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, calling it inadequate.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Public Relations Firms Join New Joint Venture
abstract: LEAD: Many public relations firms that belonged to the Honolulu-based, Japanese-owned International Public Relations Group of Companies have joined Worldcom, a 40-member joint venture that has been incorporated in Washington.

headline: Bass in Talks On Macmillan
abstract: LEAD: The Robert M. Bass Group disclosed yesterday that it had met with Macmillan Inc. to explore alternatives to Macmillan's restructuring plan.

headline: Baku Journal; Citadel of Privilege, Where Now the Masses Marry
abstract: LEAD: Geidar A. Aliyev, the former party leader of the Azerbaijani Republic, is recalled by his admirers as a gracious host and by his detractors, including the Soviet press, as a notorious toady.

headline: Irving Bank Gets Personal In New Way
abstract: LEAD: IN the crowded byways of New York one of the more pleasant pastimes is listening in on strangers' conversations.

headline: 1 Dead and 42 Hurt in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: One person was killed and at least 42 were wounded today when cars rigged with explosives blew up near a Syrian Army checkpoint in West Beirut and near a Syrian military camp in the Bekaa region of Lebanon, officials said.

headline: Resolutions Speed Pace Of Gorbachev Changes
abstract: LEAD: The Communist Party has set deadlines for overhauling the party, Government and judiciary to quicken Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of change in the Soviet system, according to resolutions made public today by the official press agency Tass.

headline: Biotechnology Merger Completed
abstract: LEAD: Novo Industri A.S., a Danish company that produces industrial enzymes and insulin, said it had acquired control of Zymogenetics Inc., a private biotechnology company based in Seattle, in the consummation of an agreement announced in May.

headline: Hong Kong Journal; Boat People Now Face Tide of Chinese Prejudice
abstract: LEAD: The 23 Vietnamese children, neatly dressed in white shirts and blue shorts, the uniform of the old makeshift school in their refugee camp, stood out from the Chinese children who were dressed in the proper orange uniforms of the Cho Yiu Chuen Primary School.

headline: Greece, the U.S. Bases and the Dukakis Factor
abstract: LEAD: A frequent topic of conversation among officials here these days is the question of how Greek-American relations would be affected if Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts were elected President, a debate that is particularly pointed because of the prolonged talks over the future of American military bases here.

headline: Brazil Asks for I.M.F. Loan
abstract: LEAD: Brazil has formally asked the International Monetary Fund for a $1.44 billion loan and presented its economic program to the fund, Government officials said Friday.

headline: Gulf Canada's Arctic Rite of Passage
abstract: LEAD: By early September the Arctic winter is closing in on this 32,000-ton exploratory oil rig, with plunging temperatures bringing a rapid freeze-up to the surrounding sea. Then, as the polar region moves into the 24-hour winter night, heaves in the icepack thicken to as much as 13 feet, pressing the rig's huge steel skirt with forces that have crushed dozens of ships.

headline: Ending PC Chaos in the Workplace
abstract: LEAD: A new era in corporate computing is emerging, bringing an end to the chaos and tension that have prevailed at companies since personal computers invaded the workplace.

headline: Argentine Rebel Sentenced
abstract: LEAD: A retired air force commodore was sentenced to 12 years' imprisonment Tuesday night for leading a rebellion against the Government in January. The commodore, Luis Estrella, led a group of officers who occupied Buenos Aires' domestic airport for several hours before surrendering to loyal troops.

headline: Now, in India, Sacred Water Packaged to Go
abstract: LEAD: If Kamal Meattle has his way, small laminated pouches carrying printed images of deities and filled with sacred water from the Ganges River will replace the traditional brass and aluminum containers used to sell sacred water.

headline: New Yorkers & Co.; A Village Club's Long Lease on Success
abstract: LEAD: In 1955, Art D'Lugoff produced a series of midnight folk music concerts and had to turn away 5,000 people clamoring to hear Pete Seeger and Sonny Terry.

headline: Navigating Through a Job Hunt
abstract: LEAD: As the autumn winds begin to blow, many executives find themselves with the urge to roam. According to Drake Beam Morin Inc. of New York, the world's largest career counseling and outplacement firm, more executives change jobs in September than in any other month.

headline: SENATE, BY 72-23, APPROVES NOTICE OF PLANT CLOSINGS
abstract: LEAD: The Senate overwhelmingly approved a bill today that would require companies to give workers 60 days' notice before closing factories or ordering large-scale layoffs.

headline: New Insider Case in London
abstract: LEAD: Three staff members have been dismissed at three securities firms for possible insider dealings, several newspapers reported today. It is the second such scandal in London within a week.

headline: President Resigns At Apollo Computer
abstract: LEAD: Apollo Computer Inc. said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Roland D. Pampel, had resigned, a year after he left Prime Computer to join Apollo.

headline: Belgian Inflation Rises
abstract: LEAD: Belgium's annual inflation rate stood at 1.21 percent in September, the highest this year, the Government reported today. The Belgian Ministry of Economy said the rate compared with 0.91 percent in August and 1.01 in July.

headline: Patents; Electromagnetic Gun
abstract: LEAD: The Army has patented a portable electromagnetic rail gun. The device, which propels a bullet by applying an intense electromagnetic pulse, is similar to weapons under research for use in space against missiles. The Army said the gun could fire a bullet four times as fast as an M-16, and rip apart a steel plate.

headline: Trucking's New Labor Problem
abstract: LEAD: Larry A. Myers's aim as the director of recruiting for the Jones Motor Group is to find enough new truck drivers to support the company's ambitious growth plans. But his real problem is simply keeping up with the turnover in Jones's current pool of 350 drivers.

headline: Savings Unit Takeover
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had arranged the acquisition of the insolvent Coosa Federal Savings and Loan Association of Gadsden, Ala., by the Birmingham-based Secor Savings Bank. The transaction brought to 103 the number of troubled savings units dealt with this year, 85 of them through federally assisted acquisitions or mergers, the bank board said.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 452 money market mutual funds increased $654.2 million, to $267.24 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 126 institutional funds rose $496.9 million, to $69.06 billion. The 223 general purpose funds fell $102.4 million, to $84.82 billion.

headline: Excerpts From Hussein's Address on Abandoning Claims to the West Bank
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from King Hussein's address today, as translated from the Arabic by The Associated Press:

headline: Silicon in Deal With I.B.M.
abstract: LEAD: Silicon Graphics Inc., a Mountain View, Calif., maker of computer work stations, said that the International Business Machines Corporation had agreed to purchase certain proprietary components and to license its software. Both companies declined to state the monetary value of the arrangement or I.B.M.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Chubb Drops Key Defense In Its Fight With Farmers
abstract: LEAD: The Chubb Corporation has dropped one of its main defenses in its battle with thousands of farmers who paid for drought-insurance policies but were denied coverage.

headline: Big Banks Shift From 3d World
abstract: LEAD: Quietly, without great fanfare, major United States banks have embarked upon a serious effort to shed their troubled loans to developing countries.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Cushman & Wakefield Inc., a real estate subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group Inc., named Stuart L. Phelps senior vice president of the financial services group.

headline: Hyde Athletic Shoes To McKinney & Silver
abstract: LEAD: Hyde Athletic Industries, a shoemaker in Massachusetts that has been through a number of local agencies in recent years, has discovered McKinney & Silver in Raleigh, N.C. The agency said the billings would be about $5 million.

headline: Northrop Contract
abstract: LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said it had received a new $730 million contract from the Boeing Company to build more main fuselage sections for its new 747-400 jetliner. Northrop, which has built 720 of the 153-foot-long sections since 1966, expects to add another 300 employees this year to the program, which already has a 2,100-member work force.

headline: Dow Falls 17.07, to 2,081.08; Volume Down
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices moved lower yesterday as volume contracted sharply.

headline: U.S. Oil Rigs Increase
abstract: LEAD: The number of rotary rigs working in the United States rose by 5 rigs, to 926, for the week ended last Friday, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. A year earlier, there were 891 working rigs, the company said. The count of rigs working offshore rose by 2, to 130, while the number of rigs working in shallow inland waters was unchanged at 28, Baker Hughes said.

headline: U.S. Rejects Soviet Offer on Disputed Complex
abstract: LEAD: The White House said today that the Soviet Union must tear down the Krasnoyarsk radar and that turning it into an international center on space research would not be good enough.

headline: Limited National Impact Seen If Drought Lasts Only a Year
abstract: LEAD: A summer-long drought would inflict numerous hardships on farmers and others who depend on agriculture for a living, but the national economy as a whole will not be hurt if the drought is only a one-year phenomenon, many economists believe.

headline: A Rise in Mortgage Rates
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates on adjustable-rate home mortgages reached their highest level of the year and fixed-rate mortgages approached their yearly high in the week ended yesterday, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said.

headline: Tate & Lyle Sets Deal To Buy Amstar Sugar
abstract: LEAD: The Amstar Corporation, which makes Domino sugar and is the nation's largest refiner of cane sugar, agreed yesterday to sell its Amstar Sugar unit to Tate & Lyle P.L.C. for $305 million.

headline: U.N. CHIEF PRESSES A GULF COMPROMISE
abstract: LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar asked the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council today to help him break the deadlocked Iran-Iraq peace talks, diplomats said.

headline: Crop Futures Fall on News Of Rainfall
abstract: LEAD: Prices of corn and soybeans plunged yesterday after large areas of the parched Farm Belt received unexpected soaking rainfall over the weekend. With meteorologists predicting more rain for today and tomorrow, corn and soybeans were bid down the maximum levels allowed from the opening bell at the Chicago Board of

headline: COMPANY NEWS; Fidelco to Buy Out National Car Partners
abstract: LEAD: The Fidelco Capital Group, a Minneapolis-based investment firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy out two of its partners in the 1986 acquisition of National Car Rental System and to sell a minority interest to the General Motors Corporation.

headline: MEXICANS REJECT CRITICISM FROM U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Responding to unusually heated American protests, the Mexican Foreign Minister has declared that his Government's refusal to extradite a Puerto Rican to the United States on terrorism charges ''was in strict compliance with Mexican law'' and should not be construed as a deliberate anti-American act.

headline: On This Tour, Those Who Serve Also Play Host
abstract: LEAD: TENNIS - especially tournaments featuring the grand old players - is increasingly being used as a promotional tool and a form of business entertainment. One of the best known is the Prudential-Bache Securities Grand Champions tour, in which the players do double duty as competitors and hosts.

headline: GLOBAL BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Spain may have to raise its inflation target of 3 percent for the year, after an unexpectedly sharp rise in the consumer price index. The index rose 1.3 percent in July, which puts inflation so far this year at 2.9 percent. That compared with monthly rises of four-tenths of 1 percent in June and 1 percent in July last year.

headline: New Doskocil Bid Urged by Wilson
abstract: LEAD: The Wilson Foods Corporation, facing a takeover threat by the Doskocil Companies, said it was willing to discuss the possibility of an improved offer that could lead to a friendly merger.

headline: Art Work 'Fingerprint'
abstract: LEAD: To help prevent art forgeries, Ioan G. Crihan, an engineer in New York City, has developed a radioactive ''fingerprint'' that is to be placed on valuable works. Mr. Crihan's procedure calls for mixing a radioactive isotope with a resin and planting a speck of the material on the painting or sculpture.

headline: Comedians as Ad Stars: Absurd Yet Credible
abstract: LEAD: To Jeff Altman, Nestle Toll House Ready-to-Bake Cookie Dough is very much a laughing matter. Valvoline motor oil, Arby's Roast Beef and Tostitos corn chips are hysterical.

headline: American Medical Holders in Filing
abstract: LEAD: An investor group said it had sought Federal antitrust clearance to buy up to 14.9 percent of American Medical International Inc.'s common stock. Richard Rainwater, a member of the group, said the group held more than 5.3 million American Medical shares, or about 7.3 percent of the total outstanding.

headline: Citizens' Holders Vote Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: Citizens Financial Group Inc.'s shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale of the company to the Royal Bank of Scotland, the sixth-largest bank in Britain, for $440 million in cash. If the $30.50-a-share deal is approved by regulators, it would be the first foreign takeover of a leading New England bank and would transform Citizens into one of the largest of the regional banking companies in the Northeast.

headline: Rise in Interest Cost Hurts Adjustable-Rate Debtors
abstract: LEAD: Because of a fundamental change in the way consumers have been borrowing money in recent years, the current rise in interest rates is going to have a more pronounced effect on pocketbooks than increases in the past.

headline: S.E.C. Head Is Assailed
abstract: LEAD: David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, came under sharp attack today by House members who complained that the agency had given in to industry pressure concerning reforms of its arbitration process.

headline: IRAN IS SAID TO CHANGE DIRECTION IN DOMESTIC AND FOREIGN POLICIES
abstract: LEAD: Iran is distancing itself from the aggressive policies that characterized its behavior in the last few years, moving instead toward moderation in domestic and foreign policies, according to Iranian officials and experts in Persian Gulf affairs.

headline: BURMA'S NEW CHIEF CHOSEN PRESIDENT
abstract: LEAD: A former army general, U Sein Lwin, was elected President today, one day after being named party leader, and all but 2 of 22 posts in his Cabinet were filled by active or retired military officers.

headline: GORBACHEV DEPUTY CRITICIZES POLICY
abstract: LEAD: In a clear challenge to the current direction of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's foreign policy, the second-ranking Kremlin leader, Yegor K. Ligachev, has publicly disagreed with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on a key point of Communist ideology.

headline: 3 Governors Visit Japan
abstract: LEAD: Three United States Governors met with Japanese officials today and appealed for more investment in their states. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Buddy Roemer of Louisiana and Ray Mabus of Mississippi said their states' economies have been damaged by declines in manufacturing and the oil industry. But they emphasized that the region is rich in assets Japan needs.

headline: Vice President at G.M. Takes Post at Navistar
abstract: LEAD: Roy S. Roberts, who presided over an effort to shake up the General Motors Corporation's entrenched bureaucracy, was named yesterday as vice president for truck operations at Navistar International Corporation.

headline: U.S. AND ALLIES ASK U.N. TO SEND TEAM TO KURDISH AREAS
abstract: LEAD: The United States and several of its allies asked the Secretary General of the United Nations today to send an investigative team to Iraq to determine whether the armed forces there used poison gas against Kurdish guerrillas, diplomats said.

headline: Patents; Measuring the Blows Received in Football
abstract: LEAD: John A. Carlin, a Denver entrepreneur and sports fan, received two patents this week. The first covers a device to measure the cumulative battering sustained by an athlete during a game. The second invention does the opposite, measuring the amount of shock an athlete can dish out.

headline: A Pizza Hut For Beijing
abstract: LEAD: Pizza Hut will soon join Kentucky Fried Chicken in bringing American fast food to China's capital.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Lisa Blumenstein and John Draper have been named senior vice presidents at Sudler & Hennessey Consumer Group.

headline: U.N. Basks in Success but Still Needs Money
abstract: LEAD: These are heady days at United Nations headquarters, with positive developments on Afghanistan and the Persian Gulf and the United Nations getting most of the credit.

headline: Home State Ruling Upheld
abstract: LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled today that the financier Marvin L. Warner cannot avoid paying $22 million in restitution stemming from the failure of Home State Savings Bank, as he was ordered to do by an Ohio court.

headline: Home Resale Rise Is 5.3%
abstract: LEAD: Sales of existing homes climbed 5.3 percent in June, helped by a smaller-than-expected increase in mortgage interest rates, a real estate trade group said today.

headline: Company News; Audi Increases Warranty Plan
abstract: LEAD: Audi of America Inc., whose sales have been affected by lawsuits over the unintended acceleration of some models, said it would offer buyers increased warranty protection.

headline: GLOBAL BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * China and the Soviet Union increased trade by nearly a third in the first half of this year, compared with the corresponding period last year. The Xinhua News Agency said China sold the Soviets $670 million worth of goods and imported $627 million worth from January to June in the largely barter trade.

headline: Pacific First Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The Pacific First Federal Savings Bank, a unit of Pacific First Financial Corporation, is offering $100 million of 9 3/8 percent mortgage-backed bonds due in 1992 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. They are backed by agency paper that includes Federal National Mortgage Association securities.

headline: Cunard Line Chief Resigning
abstract: LEAD: After spending 15 years commuting around the globe to restore luxury steamship travel to its traditional glory in the travel industry, Ralph M. Bahna is stepping aside as the president and chief executive of Cunard Line Ltd., the British company that operates the Queen Elizabeth 2, the last trans-Atlantic ocean liner.

headline: U.S. Rebukes Soviets on Afghan Mine Clearing
abstract: LEAD: The United States accused the Soviet Union today of rejecting Washington's appeals for help in removing millions of mines from Afghanistan.

headline: Doctors Find No Malignancy In Lung Biopsy on Mandela
abstract: LEAD: The condition of Nelson R. Mandela, the imprisoned South African nationalist leader, has improved since he was admitted to the hospital for a lung ailment, a physician reported today.

headline: Spy Case Leaves Ohio Town In Shock
abstract: LEAD: In this little Midwestern town of 5,000 people with its wide, tree-lined streets and classic old white-frame houses, the dominant verities include the Cleveland Browns, the flag, and the honor of the United States.

headline: Economics of Revolution Bedevil Iran
abstract: LEAD: A growing number of senior Iranian officials are warning that an acute economic crisis combined with the burdens of the war with Iraq are endangering the Iranian revolution.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Sheila Cohen and Harry Baron, respectively, have been promoted to executive vice president and senior vice president at Reichenstein Advertising, Mountainside, N.J.

headline: Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * Chief Executive Magazine says its rate base climbed 7 percent, to 30,000, and will increase its ad rates 11 percent, effective with its January/February issue.

headline: Bitter Defeat For Ayatollah
abstract: LEAD: The announcement by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today that he personally endorses a cease-fire after eight years of war with Iraq appears to signal an end to the Middle East's most vicious conflict, which has produced one million casualties, threatened navigation in the Persian Gulf and devastated the two countries.

headline: Army May Have Added To Revenge in Burundi
abstract: LEAD: Survivors of brutal tribal warfare streamed into the village hospital here today, bearing multiple wounds they said had been inflicted by soldiers who were sent to restore order, but who appeared to have taken revenge as well.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: A.T.&T. named Roger Davis corporate vice president and controller.

headline: Judge Approves Revco Financing
abstract: LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge approved $145 million in financing for Revco D.S. Inc., a drugstore chain that sought protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code last month. The package approved by Judge Harold White puts trade creditors and bank creditors ahead of all other parties - including unsecured creditors, bondholders and shareholders - to be paid should the company be liquidated.

headline: Time Inc. Stock Surges Again
abstract: LEAD: The stock of Time Inc. stock soared again yesterday, rising $9.625 a share, to $116.25, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the second day of heavy buying in the giant media company, after Friday's jump of $9.375. The increases prompted

headline: Greeks Describe Leader of Cruise Ship Attack
abstract: LEAD: Greek security officials said today that they had identified the leader of the terrorist attack last week on a Greek cruise ship in which nine people were killed.

headline: Yields Jump to a High for the Year
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell sharply for the second consecutive session yesterday, as the credit markets continued to react to the Federal Reserve's decision on Tuesday to raise its discount rate.

headline: Shopping-Center Explosion ills a Black in Johannesburg
abstract: LEAD: An explosion in a northern Johannesburg shopping center killed at least one person today, witnesses said.

headline: New Campaign From Pioneer
abstract: LEAD: The home electronics division of Pioneer Electronic (USA) Inc., which has not come out with any new advertising in two years, could not have found a phenomenon more natural than ''cocooning'' to use for its new campaign beginning in September. ''Cocooning'' refers to the stay-at-home trend of the baby boom generation.

headline: Key Sections From Speech by Gorbachev on Party's Guiding Role
abstract: LEAD: Following are key sections from the speech yesterday by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, at the Communist Party conference in Moscow, as provided in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

headline: Deal in New Zealand
abstract: LEAD: A company partly owned by Rupert Murdoch has acquired four New Zealand newspapers. Independent Newspapers Ltd., 40 percent held by Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation, said today that it had paid $6 million in New Zealand currency (about $4 million United States) to Brierley Investments Ltd. for The Daily Taranaki Herald and The Daily News as well as two weeklies, The Sunday Express and The Northern Star.

headline: Yields Post Strong Rise
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed more strength in the week ended yesterday than they have in more than a month.

headline: 'Pregaphone,' to Talk To an Unborn Child
abstract: LEAD: Janet D. Hodson, a business consultant in Ventura, Calif., received a patent this week for ''Pregaphone,'' a device that purports to let pregnant women talk to their unborn children.

headline: Tokyo Journal; A Real Estate Market No One Can Afford Anymore
abstract: LEAD: The real estate boom here has been long been out of control, but many people were still shocked when a Government-affiliated research group calculated a few months ago that the book value of all the land in Japan - $13.47 trillion and change at current exchange rates -easily exceeded the value of all the land in the United States.

headline: Missing in Action: From a Lost War, a Haunting Echo That Won't Be Stilled
abstract: LEAD: On the wall of Ann Mills Griffiths's office in Washington is a framed rubbing of her brother's name from the Vietnam War Memorial. Lieut. Cmdr. James B. Mills has been missing since Sept. 21, 1966, when his Navy F-4 was lost on a night mission over North Vietnam.

headline: Italy to Take Back Waste
abstract: LEAD: Two Italian ships will be sent to retrieve several tons of unspecified toxic waste left in Koko, a Nigerian port that has been the site of a controversy over the dumping of toxic waste in West Africa, Civil Defense Minister Vito Lattanzio said Friday. The announcement was expected to ease tensions between Italy and Nigeria and lead to the release of the Italian freighter Piave, which was seized by Nigeria pending a resolution of the waste issue.

headline: Move by Pfizer in India Spurs Furor
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to increase the sales of its sagging subsidiary in India and streamline its operations, Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceutical company, has appointed an American as the unit's new managing director after 17 years of Indian management.

headline: In a Mexican Village, Wary Voters
abstract: LEAD: The men gathered under the Spanish-style arcades of this village's only plaza all agreed that the sight of peasants in straw hats and shawls lining up this morning to vote was altogether unusual for an election day in Comanja.

headline: Adams-Millis, Sara Lee in Pact
abstract: LEAD: The Adams-Millis Corporation, which recently accepted a takeover bid by its chairman, said it had decided to terminate that agreement in favor of a higher offer from the Sara Lee Corporation that values the hosiery maker at about $80 million. The Sara Lee offer proposes a stock swap transaction that values Adams

headline: As Talks Stall, Iranian Warns War Isn't Over
abstract: LEAD: With peace talks between Iran and Iraq apparently making no headway, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was quoted today as having said that the eight-year-old conflict was not over and that Iranians should feel they are still at war.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW, WORKING GROUP ON PAYMENTS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.  AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN -10:30 A.M.

headline: Security Pacific Reorganization
abstract: LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest bank holding company, reorganized management at several of its banks yesterday.

headline: Four-Party Talks on Angola Resume Today in New York
abstract: LEAD: Officials from the United States, South Africa, Angola and Cuba will meet in New York on Monday to try to reach agreement on a Cuban troop withdrawal from Angola and black majority rule in South-West Africa.

headline: Dow Reaches Lowest Level Since May
abstract: LEAD: The prices of stocks continued a pattern of Monday listlessness yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 25.78 points in exceptionally slow trading. The drop brought the blue-chip index to 1,990.22, its lowest closing level since May 27.

headline: In Japan, the Land of the Rod, An Appeal to Spare the Child
abstract: LEAD: It was a permanent wave curling just her bangs that got her expelled right before her high school graduation.

headline: Haitians See Financial Crisis and Plead for Aid
abstract: LEAD: As calm settled over Haiti today, a week after a coup d'etat, leading businessmen declared that the country was in a severe economic crisis and appealed to the United States and other nations for emergency financial aid.

headline: Plea to End Farm Grants
abstract: LEAD: The Cairns Group of 14 farming nations today called for fundamental trade reform by phasing out agricultural subsidies worldwide by the year 2000, starting with a freeze at the end of this year.

abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   6.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.38   8.10   6.91        3-MO. headline: South African Denied Refuge
abstract: LEAD: United States officials said today that they turned away a black fugitive seeking refuge in the American Consulate, which is sheltering four escaped detainees. The man, Max Mankazana, 22 years old, was later arrested. An American spokesman did not say why the man's case was treated differently.

headline: The Two Faces of South Korea's Capital City: Rumpled and Olympic-Tidy
abstract: LEAD: There are two Seouls - the everyday one that screeches and blares and laughs out loud, and the sanitized one that is being polished and buffed for the world to see.

headline: Gillette Truce: Review Is Issue
abstract: LEAD: The Federal judge who has been hearing challenges in the Gillette Company's proxy fight with Coniston Partners has asked the parties in the case whether he needs to review a proposed settlement, according to court papers and lawyers.

headline: About Real Estate; Low-Cost Housing Need: Early Cash
abstract: LEAD: The shortage of low-cost housing in New York is acute, everyone agrees, and there is a fair amount of money available from city and state agencies and from private groups to help rebuild decaying houses for the homeless and for those unable to pay market rents.

headline: Sale of Brunswick By Scott and Mead
abstract: LEAD: The Scott Paper Company said it and the Mead Corporation had completed the sale of the Brunswick Pulp and Paper Company and related timberlands. The Georgia-Pacific Corporation purchased the holdings for about $665 million.

headline: 2 Iran F-14's Said to Have Passed A U.S. Ship Day Before Downing
abstract: LEAD: The day before the cruiser Vincennes shot down an Iranian Airbus, two Iranian F-14 fighter planes came as close as seven nautical miles to another American Navy ship, prompting it to go on combat alert and to fire a warning flare, Administration officials said today.

headline: Latin Trade Plan Shaped
abstract: LEAD: A Latin American export financing consortium, Latinequip, plans to propose to central banks of Mexico, Brazil and Argentina that foreign debt paper from those countries be used to finance trade.
