abstract: LEAD:            Net Income   Percent       Apr.-June   Change       1988   From '87       Amoco Corp.   $ 667,000,000    +114.5        Ashland Oil Inc.   56,900,000    +42.3        Atlantic Richfield Co.   400,000,000    +21.2        Browning-Ferris Industries   61,400,000    +33.8        Brunswick Corp.   78,900,000    +37.2        Calmat Co.

headline: Boeing-Short Bros.
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company said it was not interested in buying Short Brothers P.L.C. of Belfast, Northern Ireland. ''We have now completed our evaluation, and we do not have an interest in purchasing all or part of Shorts,'' said Frank A. Shrontz, Boeing's chairman. Shorts is a state-owned manufacturer of aircraft parts, which supplies Boeing with parts for its 737, 747 and 757 aircraft.

headline: Reagan Urged to Press Pretoria on Executions
abstract: LEAD: Seventy-two members of Congress urged President Reagan and other world leaders today to intervene on behalf of the ''Sharpeville Six,'' who await execution in South Africa for their part in a violent protest.

headline: Notes and Bonds Turn Downward
abstract: LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices fell yesterday, as securities dealers said investors stayed on the sidelines in advance of today's Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman.

headline: The Dark Side of Globalization
abstract: LEAD: MONEY talks. Koreans own The Washington Times. From the G. Heileman Company Inc. - the brewer - to Bonwit Teller - the department store - Australians have come up from down-under to buy companies throughout the United States. And you can drive all over this nation on General Tires - made by a company now owned by the Germans - or on tires made by Firestone - which was recently bought by the

headline: U.S. Officials Say New Haiti Rulers Are About Like the Old Ones
abstract: LEAD: American officials said today that the coup in Haiti may have been a response to the breakdown of public order and the re-emergence of the Tontons Macoute, a paramilitary security force suspected of savage attacks on a church in Port-au-Prince earlier this month.

headline: A Former Singer Becomes Largest Owner of Donnay
abstract: LEAD: Bernard Tapie, who made his fortune in France, has become the majority owner of Donnay S.A., the bankrupt maker of tennis racquets.

headline: New Yorkers & Co.; The None-Too-Gentle Art Of the 'Bankruptcy Boys'
abstract: LEAD: ''We don't like to cause pain,'' Jay Goldsmith insisted. It's just that in the game he plays of trying to turn bankrupt companies into money, pain comes with the territory.

headline: Retail Sales Down, but Just a Bit
abstract: LEAD: Retail sales dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Many economists said the small decline should not arouse any serious concerns about the economy's health.

headline: Prime Vantage Point for the Palestinians
abstract: LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission here is one of the group's most vital diplomatic outposts, a place from which the P.L.O. influences the United Nations agenda and maintains ties with dozens of nations.

headline: GDANSK SHIPYARD TO JOIN STRIKERS
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity trade union called a strike tonight at the big Lenin shipyard in Gdansk for Monday after the Government refused an earlier offer of talks with the union's national leaders to defuse a wave of labor unrest.

headline: Nigerian Leader's Political Agility Keeps Trouble at Bay and Him in Power
abstract: LEAD: Newspaper cartoonists here often sketch the President of Nigeria as a soccer star, a general in playing shorts weaving unscathed through his nation's problems.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Renee Fraser has been appointed executive vice president and general manager of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Pacific division, and Cy Schneider is coming to New York as corporate executive vice president.

headline: Prices Plunge in Active Trading
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes dropped sharply in active trading yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board said it had raised its discount rate by half a percentage point, to 6 1/2 percent.

headline: Coffee Curbs Predicted
abstract: LEAD: London coffee dealers predicted today that the International Coffee Organization would soon cut coffee producers' export quotas because of low prices, removing 1.5 million 60-kilo bags of coffee from the total of 54.5 million bags that members may now export. But forecasts of cold weather in Brazil, lifting prices today, may postpone the quota cut.

headline: Dollar Up Overseas on News of Airliner Disaster
abstract: LEAD: The dollar jumped today on news that the United States Navy had shot down an Iranian passenger jet with 290 people on board. But the price of gold, after a brief spurt, ended the day with little change in dull European trading.

headline: Brazil Will Restrict Mining
abstract: LEAD: Brazil's constituent assembly voted today to restrict development of the country's vast mineral wealth to Brazilian-controlled companies. This decision, confirming a preliminary vote in April, is to become part of the new constitution when it is finished next month.

headline: Mountbatten Slayer Fires
abstract: LEAD: A man serving a life sentence for the Irish guerrilla murder of Lord Mountbatten whipped out a pistol and opened fire in a Dublin court cell today in an unsuccessful escape attempt, the police said. Thomas McMahon, who designed and planted the bomb that killed the uncle of Prince Philip in 1979, was quickly overpowered by police officers.

headline: Dow Ends Seesaw Session Up 11.73 Points
abstract: LEAD: The stock market ended a seesaw session on the upside yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 11.73 points to close at 2,104.37.

headline: Many Minor Tax Changes In Bill Approved by House
abstract: LEAD: By an overwhelming majority, the House today approved a $7.1 billion package of minor tax changes benefiting farmers, mutual fund investors, freelance writers and rural mail carriers.

headline: Neiman-Marcus Minds the Store
abstract: LEAD: PHILIP M. HAWLEY thought he was giving up some sparkling jewels last summer, when Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. spun off its specialty stores into a publicly traded company called the Neiman-Marcus Group Inc.

headline: Israeli Troops Kill Palestinian in Gaza Strip
abstract: LEAD: Israeli soldiers shot dead a 52-year-old Palestinian in the occupied Gaza Strip today when a patrol opened fire on Arab demonstrators, the army said. The dead man, Mohammed Rezek, was the third Arab killed by troops this week.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shift at Bon Appetit
abstract: LEAD: Robert S. Phelps, 49, publisher of Bon Appetit magazine, has been promoted to general manager, which at Knapp Communications is a bigger job. Publisher since 1983, he is being replaced by George B. Dippy, 54, associate publisher and former advertising director.

headline: Earnings Nearly Doubled In 2d Quarter at Salomon
abstract: LEAD: Salomon Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings nearly doubled in the second quarter, compared with the 1987 quarter, when its trading division posted large losses.

headline: TIMING OF WRITER'S STRIKE MAY BE GIFT FOR NETWORKS
abstract: LEAD: FOR weeks, executives of the entertainment divisions at ABC, CBS and NBC insisted that the fall television season announced in May would be a casualty of the strike against producers by the Writers Guild of America. They scrambled to put together an ''interim season'' that would include reruns, coverage of news and sports events, series that had been completed but shelved, and other programs that could be made outside union jurisdiction.

headline: Burma's Army, Despite Foe, Appears to Control Capital
abstract: LEAD: The Burmese Army appeared today to be consolidating its control over the capital, Rangoon, but opposition leaders remained defiant and diplomats said militant students might be preparing for guerrilla warfare.

headline: Phillips Petroleum Cutback in Denver
abstract: LEAD: The Phillips Petroleum Company will relocate part of its operations from its Denver office to Texas in a consolidation that will affect about 125 employees, a spokesman, Dan Harrison, said. The regional oil exploration and production office and the partnership operations now based in Denver will be merged with offices in Houston and Borger, Tex., Mr.

headline: Bethlehem Steel To Increase Prices
abstract: LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would raise the prices of its major steel products. The company, the nation's third-largest steel producer, said it would increase the base price of its hot-rolled sheet steel by $15 a ton and raise its cold-rolled sheet steel prices by $30 a ton, beginning Jan.

headline: Anchor Savings Offering Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Anchor Savings Bank is offering $100 million of 9 3/4 percent collateralized notes, due in 1993, at a price of 99.98 to yield 9.755 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley.

headline: World Grain Supplies Are Dropping
abstract: LEAD: Projections by Government and private analysts indicate that droughts in North America and Asia are sharply curtailing the world's production of wheat, corn and other cereal crops, reducing grain stockpiles to their lowest levels since 1973.

headline: Corporate Prison Term For Allegheny Bottling
abstract: LEAD: In an unusual ruling, a Federal district judge has sentenced the Allegheny Bottling Company to three years' imprisonment and a fine of $1 million for a price-fixing scheme involving soft-drink bottling companies between 1982 and 1985.

headline: New Buyout Offer For Irish Distillers
abstract: LEAD: GC & C Brands Ltd. has begun a new bid for the Irish Distillers Group P.L.C. that values Ireland's leading whisky distiller at 253 million Irish pounds, or about $354 million. The $5.60-a-share offer was made hours after GC & C received regulatory clearance from Britain's Panel on Takeovers and Mergers to proceed with a new bid for the distiller, which makes Jameson and

headline: Owners of 2 Papers in Stock Swap
abstract: LEAD: The owners of two of Europe's leading newspapers, The Financial Times in London and NRC Handelsblad in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, swapped one another's shares today to guard against unwanted takeovers.

headline: Genentech Wins Ruling
abstract: LEAD: Genentech Inc. said Friday that the Federal District Court in San Francisco had ruled in its favor in a patent infringement suit brought by the Hormone Research Foundation and its licensee, Hoffman-La Roche Inc. The court ruled that Genentech does not infringe the foundation's patent by its manufacture and sale of genetically engineered human growth hormone.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: U.S. and Allies Show Ability To Influence Currency Levels
abstract: LEAD: After winning another battle this summer, the world's industrial democracies are beginning to offer convincing evidence that, more than before, they can influence the course of the volatile foreign-exchange markets.

headline: El Toro's Fights Go On, But 'Oles!' Are Fewer
abstract: LEAD: Although the fighting bulls are a long way from becoming victors instead of vanquished in Spain's national pastime, they have recently been having their day both in and out of the ring.

headline: Dalkon Shield Trust Fund Faces Appeal
abstract: LEAD: Payments to women injured by the Dalkon Shield birth control device will be delayed while the settlement that established a $2.47 billion trust fund is appealed, lawyers involved in the case said yesterday.

headline: Kahane Renounces U.S. Ties To Seek Re-election in Israel
abstract: LEAD: Rabbi Meir Kahane, who advocates expelling all Arabs from Israeli-held territory, has renounced his American citizenship so he can run again for an Israeli Parliament seat, his spokesman said today.

headline: Postal Service Truncates Perot's Role
abstract: LEAD: The United States Postal Service plans to allow competitive bidding for part of the contract it awarded without bidding to the Perot Systems Corporation, Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said today.

headline: Inland Steel Sees Strong Year Ahead
abstract: LEAD: Inland Steel Industries expects the United States steel industry to stay strong through 1989, but any profit gains are likely to come through cost cuts instead of higher prices, Inland's president, Robert Darnall, said. Interviewed after he addressed a national meeting on corporate ethics Tuesday, Mr.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Volvo Penta Engine Ads To Lowe Tucker Metcalf
abstract: LEAD: Volvo Penta of America, the marine division of Volvo North America, has awarded its engine business to Lowe Tucker Metcalf, a partner agency of Lowe Howard-Spink of London.

headline: Dow Pierces 2,100 Level With a 17.60 Gain
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rose yesterday, helped in early trading by a narrower-than-expected trade deficit report and, later in the session, by futures-related buying.

headline: 2 Top Officers Resign At Micron Technology
abstract: LEAD: Micron Technology Inc., a small semiconductor company that is fighting with large Japanese concerns in the memory chip business, announced yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Juan A. Benitez, and its chief financial officer, Leslie Gill, had resigned.

headline: ANTI-SEMITIC JOKE ASSAILED IN FRANCE
abstract: LEAD: Jean-Marie Le Pen, the defeated presidential candidate of France's extreme right, has been condemned by politicians and leaders of human rights and Jewish groups for a joke about World War II crematoriums.

headline: PRESSURE BUILDING ON NAMIBIAN TALKS
abstract: LEAD: Under the pressure of a symbolic anniversary this week, negotiators from Angola, Cuba and South Africa resumed talks today to set a timetable for the withdrawal of 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola.

headline: New Mexico Utility Cuts 799 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Mexico today announced a $250 million cost-cutting program and immediately eliminated 799 jobs, or more than 19 percent of its 4,126 staff.

headline: Silver After the Hunt Debacle
abstract: LEAD: IT is safe to say that the Hunt brothers of Dallas have never recovered from the collapse of the silver market in 1979 and 1980. Neither has the metal. Silver soared from $9 an ounce in September 1979 to $50 an ounce in January 1980, only to collapse to $10 within two months; the debacle was relived last week.

headline: A Services Trade Plan For GATT
abstract: LEAD: Australia plans to propose a set of principles Monday to establish free global trade in services, including banking, insurance and transport.

headline: Polaroid Sets Date On Shamrock Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation, target of an unsolicited $2.4 billion tender offer by the investor Roy E. Disney, said its directors plan to issue a recommendation on the $42-a-share bid by Sept. 22, when the company is obligated by law to respond. Polaroid, based in Cambridge, Mass., also postponed the effective date of an anti-takeover measure until at least then.

headline: Key Parts of Soviet Plan for Change
abstract: LEAD: Following are key sections of the resolution on perestroika, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's term for economic and political restructuring, approved by the extraordinary Communist Party conference last week and published today for the first time. The resolution and five others on such topics as legal reform and changing the bureaucracy, were distributed in translation by the official press agency Tass.

headline: Inflation Fear Casts Pall on Bond Market
abstract: LEAD: Fears of a resurgence of inflation cast a pall over the credit market last week, and investor confidence in fixed-income securities is expected to be further undermined in the foreseeable future.

headline: In Iraq, No Doubts, Merely 'Victory!'
abstract: LEAD: Iraq proclaimed a ''great victory'' today in the war with Iran, and the sky over the Tigris River blazed with fireworks.

headline: Tin Mill Prices Raised
abstract: LEAD: Two steel companies announced price increases on tin mill products today. The USX Corporation said it would raise its prices by 9.5 percent. The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would raise its prices by 8 percent. Both price increases are scheduled to go into effect on Oct. 1.

headline: Cadbury Posts Profit Increase
abstract: LEAD: The British candy and soft-drink company Cadbury-Schweppes P.L.C. announced today that pretax profits for the first six months of 1988 rose by 28.3 percent. The company's chairman, Sir Adrian Cadbury, said he expected further growth this year.

headline: Police in Israel Arrest 3 Arabs in Haifa Bombing
abstract: LEAD: The police said today that they had arrested three Arabs believed to be responsible for a bombing that wounded 25 people in downtown Haifa on Saturday night.

headline: Japan in Appeal to Soviets
abstract: LEAD: The Government asked the Soviet Union to scale down a planned military exercise in the Sea of Japan beginning Friday, Foreign Ministry officials said today. The Soviet Union earlier announced that it would conduct an artillery exercise in the Sea of Japan west of Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost island, starting Friday and lasting until Aug.

headline: Another Tisch at CBS
abstract: LEAD: Preston Robert Tisch was named yesterday to the board of CBS Inc., where his brother, Laurence A. Tisch, is chief executive. The appointment increases the broadcasting company's board to 14 members. Preston Tisch, who earlier this year resigned as Postmaster General, is the president and co-chief executive, with his brother, of the Loews Corporation.

headline: Greece Says U.S. Issued Alert on Terrorism
abstract: LEAD: Greece said today that the United States had warned it of a pending terrorist strike before last week's attack on a excursion ship that left 9 dead and 98 wounded. But it said no specific information was given on the time or place of the assault.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.  Monday  None  Tuesday  Consumer Prices July  Durable Goods July  Wednesday  Merchandise Trade Balance 2d Qtr.  Thursday  Gross National Product

headline: I.B.M. Names Head Of Marketing Group
abstract: LEAD: George H. Conrades, who was named general manager of I.B.M.'s United States marketing and services organization yesterday, faces the immediate challenge of doing more with less.

headline: Thrifts That Trip
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Radio Calls Say Flight 655 Was Climbing in Last Minutes
abstract: LEAD: The transcript of radio calls between the downed Iran Air jetliner and air controllers appears to support Iran's assertion that the plane was sending out normal radar signals for a civilian aircraft and was climbing from 12,000 feet to its assigned altitude of 14,000 feet when it was shot down by the United States

headline: Buenos Aires Journal; For Voters, a Clear Choice of Styles and Futures
abstract: LEAD: Carlos Saul Menem cooked up gnocchi for 7,000 people during his primary campaign, and he promises to govern Argentina as an updated version of Juan D. Peron.

headline: CBS Seeks New Kinds Of Promotion
abstract: LEAD: GEORGE SCHWEITZER, recently lured back to CBS Inc. from Young & Rubicam Inc. to overhaul the network's advertising and promotion efforts, is working on some innovative ideas about how to attract more viewers.

headline: Contra Leader Says Sandinistas Yield a Key Point
abstract: LEAD: A top contra leader said today that President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua, in a proposal that the next round of peace talks with the contras start July 28, appeared to have agreed to lead his Government's delegation.

headline: Brunei Journal; Sultan's Wealth Is Vast; His Power, Greater Still
abstract: LEAD: Multicolored triumphal arches are being erected throughout this capital and across the roads leading to it. Garish signs are going up on grandiose Government buildings, raw, new office towers and shoddy Chinese shops, and chains of Christmas-tree bulbs illuminate them.

headline: Business Digest: Saturday July 2, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Soviet Historian Faults Stalin About Trotsky
abstract: LEAD: A senior Soviet historian asserted today in Pravda that Stalin ordered the 1940 assassination in Mexico of his arch-rival Leon Trotsky.

headline: Beita Journal; Where the Hot Rage of April Is Now Cold Fury
abstract: LEAD: Strident anti-Israel graffiti is scrawled across almost every wall in orange paint so bright it looks as if it might glow in the dark.

headline: Rise in Farmland Prices
abstract: LEAD: A modest upturn in United States farmland values has been slowed by this summer's drought, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Rural appraisers surveyed in August reported a 1.2 percent increase in nationwide farmland prices for the May-to-July period, lower than the 1.8 percent gain reported for the preceding three months, the agency said in its monthly agricultural report.

headline: French Rail Chief Quits After 2d Paris Crash
abstract: LEAD: The president of France's state-run railroad resigned today after the second fatal train crash in Paris in six weeks. The Government attributed the crash in part to a failure by officials to move ahead with measures ordered after the earlier wreck.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: EMPLOYEE BENEFITS FOR THE 1990's; Business Needs a Family Policy
abstract: LEAD: EFFECTIVE July 1, all permanent Connecticut state employees are entitled to 24 weeks of family leave within any two-year period, upon the birth or adoption of a child or the serious illness of a child, spouse or parent of the employee. A medical leave of absence of 24 weeks is also permissible if the employee should become seriously ill.

headline: Seagate Trips, Industry Cringes
abstract: LEAD: Traditionally an industry whose profits seem always on a roller-coaster ride, the business of making hard disk drives for computers appears poised for another downturn.

headline: Maxwell Adds a Twist To Offer for Macmillan
abstract: LEAD: Robert Maxwell, the British entrepreneur, stepped up his efforts to gain control of Macmillan Inc. on two fronts yesterday.

headline: Wallenberg Seen in '86, Swede's Report Says
abstract: LEAD: A well-known Swedish businessman and novelist has given the Stockholm Government new evidence he says shows that Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat presumed to have disappeared in Soviet prisons after saving thousands of Jews from the Nazis, was alive as recently as 1986 and may be alive today.

headline: I.M.F. Leader Criticizes Dollar's Rise
abstract: LEAD: The managing director of the International Monetary Fund today criticized the dollar's recent rise, asserting that it would slow efforts to end the world's trade imbalances.

headline: Armenians Cite Deaths But Soviets Deny Clash
abstract: LEAD: Armenian militants said today that Soviet Army paratroopers had fired on protesters trying to shut down Yerevan's airport and had killed as many as five people. A Soviet official denied there had been any clashes or deaths.

headline: G.M. Extends Incentives
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet, Buick and Oldsmobile divisions today extended through Sept. 28 buyer incentive programs that were scheduled to expire on Tuesday. Many of the Chevrolet rebates will be leaner, but Buick rebates will be unchanged except for those on the LeSabre, a spokeswoman said.

headline: Computer Scientist Forming a Foundation
abstract: LEAD: Douglas C. Engelbart, a computer scientist who invented the pointing device used with computers that is known as a mouse and who is credited with work that led to several other important developments in the personal computer industry, plans to leave his position as a researcher at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and set up a nonprofit foundation called the Bootstrap

headline: Business People; A Revamped Leaseway Will Get New Chairman
abstract: LEAD: The Leaseway Transportation Corporation, a company that has gone through a proxy contest, a leveraged buyout and a refocusing of its business in the last few years, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Gerald C. McDonough, will retire later this month and be succeeded by Richard A.

headline: Tandy's Earnings Estimate Lowered
abstract: LEAD: Shares of the Tandy Corporation were traded furiously and closed at $39.625, down 87.5 cents, after analysts at Salomon Brothers Inc. and Paine Webber Inc. issued lower earnings estimates for the computer maker. The analysts said they had lowered their first-quarter projections because the Fort Worth-based company is experiencing a softness in sales volume and has yet to ship its new models, which had been expected in stores by mid-September.

headline: Beijing Criticizes Rating by Moody's
abstract: LEAD: China complained yesterday that Moody's Investors Service assigned too low a rating when the nation issued its first international bonds last October.

headline: Sequoyah Fuels Sale Set
abstract: LEAD: The Kerr-Mcgee Corporation signed a definitive agreement to sell its Sequoyah Fuels Corporation subsidiary to General Atomics, a privately held high-technology company, for undisclosed terms, the companies said on Friday. The sale will be completed once regulatory approval is received. Sequoyah''s primary business is uranium conversion at its eastern Oklahoma plant.

headline: The Big Dividends of a Gulf Peace
abstract: LEAD: In the wake of the cease-fire announcement in the Iran-Iraq war this week, foreign delegations have been descending on the capitals of the two Gulf nations to put diplomatic relations on a closer footing and to promote economic interests.

headline: Last Pontiac Cars Are Built in Pontiac
abstract: LEAD: The last Pontiac produced in Pontiac by the General Motors Corporation has rolled off the assembly line, ending more than 60 years of automobile production in the city that lent its name to the car. The last two Fieros produced at the plant Tuesday were turned over to two workers who won raffles. They were among the 1,400 G.M.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: INVESTING; A Top Fund Manager's Choices
abstract: LEAD: THE mutual fund accounts run by insurance companies are a powerful force in the stock market, representing billions of dollars from small investors. Because their portfolio managers are not usually pressured by large individual investors, these funds can sometimes take a long-term view - and search for small-company gems.

headline: Reed Meeting With Pearson
abstract: LEAD: Pearson P.L.C., a London-based publishing, banking and industrial group, said yesterday that it had been approached by Reed International P.L.C., another British publishing company, about a possible takeover.

headline: Prime Computer Adds to Series 50
abstract: LEAD: Prime Computer Inc. announced a midrange superminicomputer intended for use in offices and a more powerful machine for use in computer rooms. It said the two new members of its series 50 family of computers, the midrange 4450 and the high-end 6150, would be available immediately. Superminicomputers, very fast and powerful computers one step below mainframes, are most commonly used in specialized scientific or engineering applications.

headline: U.S. HALTS TALKS ON BASES IN GREECE
abstract: LEAD: Talks on the future of American military bases were indefinitely postponed today after the Greek Government notified United States negotiators that it would close one of the bases.

headline: 3-Part Offering By Loan Banks
abstract: LEAD: An announcement today is planned by the Federal Home Loan Banks on the interest rates for a three-part bond offering totaling $2.805 billion.

headline: International Paper
abstract: LEAD: The International Paper Company said today that it would appeal a ruling that could cost it $25 million in back pay to workers locked out of its Mobile mill. The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that it was illegal for the company to permanently replace 280 maintenance employees at the mill.

headline: Olivetti To Divide Into 3 Units
abstract: LEAD: Two days after reporting lower quarterly profits, Olivetti, the Italian computer giant, today announced a broad corporate reorganization to bolster its competitiveness.

headline: Acquisition Of Cherokee Group Near
abstract: LEAD: The Cherokee Group said today that it had entered into a definitive agreement with the Green Acquisition Company, a unit of Deutschman & Company, under which Green will acquire Cherokee for $168 million.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Cummins Engine Co., Columbus, Ind., named Peter B. Hamilton chief financial officer, effective Aug. 1. He is succeeding John T. Hackett, who is taking early retirement.

headline: Employers Act to Stop Family Violence
abstract: LEAD: Moving cautiously into a new area of corporate responsibility, a growing number of companies have begun to treat family violence as a sickness undermining the health and performance of their employees.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Technology

headline: Boom Times for 'Thrift Doctors'
abstract: LEAD: THERE were days of intense negotiations that went on long into the night, and after it was all over, the most expensive rescue of a single savings and loan association was in place. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board last week agreed to sell the nation's largest insolvent thrift association, the American Savings and Loan Association of California, to a group headed by Robert M.

headline: Gains Reported in Angola Talks
abstract: LEAD: Cuba, Angola and South Africa reported progress today in their latest round of negotiations towards peace in Angola and Namibia.

headline: A Year Later, a Saner Market
abstract: LEAD: Last summer was a golden age for Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average was at 2,700, and there was widespread belief it was headed for 3,000. Some even predicted 3,300.

headline: Sallie Mae Selling Short-Term Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $350 million of floating-rate notes due March 9, 1989, at par through various securities dealers.

headline: Dollar Has Broad Decline As Official Pressure Mounts
abstract: LEAD: The dollar fell against all major currencies yesterday in active trading. Traders attributed the decline to continued intervention by some central banks and to a report that the Reagan Administration found the recent rise in the dollar troublesome and preferred a period of stability.

headline: Managua Lifts Wages, Devalues Its Currency
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has announced a currency devaluation and wage increases to shore up an economy he said has been damaged by American support for the contras.

headline: Second Plunge For Monsanto
abstract: LEAD: The price of the Monsanto Company's shares plunged for a second day in response to concerns about its liability for the Copper-7 intrauterine birth-control device, manufactured by its G. D. Searle & Company subsidiary.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   6.50   6.50   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.02   8.25   7.32        3-MO. headline: Bankruptcy Plan For Triad Cleared
abstract: LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy judge has approved an agreement under which the Saudi businessmen Adnan and Essam Khashoggi are to pay $32 million to creditors of the Triad America Corporation. Judge John H. Allen approved the agreement Tuesday between the Khashoggi brothers and R. Todd Neilson, the court-appointed trustee for

headline: Strike in Disputed Soviet Enclave Reportedly Ended After 2 Months
abstract: LEAD: Residents of a rebellious Armenian-dominated enclave in the southern Soviet Union were reported today to have ended their two-month-long general strike, closing a tense chapter in the most perilous ethnic crisis facing Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

headline: Calmat's Japanese Sale Foils Offer by Brierley
abstract: LEAD: The Calmat Company, in a move that has defeated an unsolicited takeover offer from the New Zealand investor Ronald A. Brierley, said today that it had tentatively agreed to sell its cement business for at least $310 million to Japan's largest cement maker.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly

headline: 165 FEARED DEAD FROM OIL RIG BLAST
abstract: LEAD: About 165 oil workers were feared dead today after a towering oil platform off the east coast of Scotland exploded and burned in what officials said was the worst rig disaster in North Sea history.

headline: Brazil Votes Limit on Rates
abstract: LEAD: Brazil's Congress has voted to fix inflation-adjusted interest rates at 12 percent a year under the country's new constitution, despite protests from bankers and business executives that the measure will not work.

headline: NATO CHIEF SEES FEWER ATOM ARMS
abstract: LEAD: The commander of American and allied forces in Europe said today that the United States could achieve ''a fairly significant reduction'' in its nuclear warheads on the continent over the next decade.

headline: June Producer Prices Rose a Moderate 0.4%
abstract: LEAD: Inflation pressures continued to mount in June but remained concentrated in the early stages of production, Government figures showed today.

headline: Arrests of Burmese Dissidents Reported
abstract: LEAD: The new Burmese Government arrested a major opposition figure, at least 10 other critics and an Associated Press reporter, Western diplomats said today.

headline: 2 Publications Starting For Specific Audiences
abstract: LEAD: Hot off the press is the premier issue of Corporate Video Decisions, issued by Act III Publishing. With a controlled circulation, the new publication is intended for some 40,000 decision makers in the corporate video market. Joseph J. Allen is the publisher, and James Kaminsky is the editor. The cover price is $5.

headline: A Shadowy Kremlin Rivalry Moves Into the Public Glare
abstract: LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin came to the final session of the Communist Party conference today a prophet without honor in his own party, asking hoarsely for his honor back.

headline: Bonds and Notes Are Down Again
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell further yesterday, pushed lower by a drop in the value of the dollar and a big jump in many commodity prices.

headline: Article 029588 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month bills.

headline: 744 Insurers Quit Lloyd's
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of underwriting members have resigned from the insurance market of Lloyd's of London this year amid forecasts of possible losses from United States pollution and asbestos claims, a Lloyd's spokesman said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  International

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey's 2d-Quarter Net Shows Increase of 55%
abstract: LEAD: Grey Advertising has released its second-quarter earnings and they looked particularly good since they included an extra $1.9 million from the sale of a British subsidiary.

headline: Coca-Cola Issue Totals $300 Million
abstract: LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company offered $300 million worth of money market preferred stock yesterday through a syndicate led by Shearson Lehman Hutton. The offering consisted of 3,000 shares of stock priced at $100,000 per share, and was offered in four tranches of $75 million each.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Contractor in Pentagon Inquiry Closes
abstract: LEAD: A small Florida company that has figured prominently in the investigation of fraud and bribery in military procurement said today that it had closed its operations because it had lost its major customer.

headline: Burma Fixes Timing of Vote, But Opposition May Resist
abstract: LEAD: The Burmese Parliament set a three-month deadline today for multiparty elections that were announced on Saturday, but there were growing signs that the opposition would not accept elections administered by the ruling party.

headline: Merck Names Vice Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Merck & Company, the pharmaceutical maker based in Rahway, N.J., has named John E. Lyons vice chairman and announced several other changes among senior management.

headline: SENATORS ASSERT WARSHIP CAPTAIN REACTED PROPERLY
abstract: LEAD: Members of the Senate said after Pentagon briefings today that the captain of a Navy cruiser had acted properly in shooting down an unidentified aircraft that turned out to be a civilian Iranian airliner, even though he acted on incomplete information.

headline: Univex's Chief Expands Its Minority-Group Role
abstract: LEAD: Wendell L. Crosswhite, who was recently named president of Universal Trading Exchange Inc., known as Univex, believes that his business has virtually no competition.

headline: Car Sales Rise in Japan
abstract: LEAD: Sales of vehicles in Japan increased 14.5 percent in August from a year earlier, to 263,629, according to preliminary figures released today by the Japan Automobile Dealers Association. The rise was the 16th straight year-to-year gain. The August figures, which are compiled from vehicle registrations, were much lower than the 485,549 of July, which was 7.7 percent more than a year earlier.

headline: Botha and Mobuto to Meet Saturday on Angolan Peace
abstract: LEAD: President P. W. Botha of South Africa is expected to travel to Zaire on Saturday to meet with President Mobutu Sese Seko, in the latest move to bring peace to Angola, diplomats said today.

headline: Name Change at IC
abstract: LEAD: The directors of IC Industries have approved a change in the company's name to the Whitman Corporation, effective Dec. 1. ''The new name was selected after a year of study and research that showed the name Whitman to have the required attributes of familiarity, quality and distinction,'' the company said.

headline: Vehicle Sales Seen Rising
abstract: LEAD: The Commerce Department expects total sales of cars and trucks in the United States to rise steadily in the next few years, from 15.5 million in 1988 to 16.6 million in 1991, the director of the department's motor vehicle division said today. Albert Warner, speaking to the Automotive News World Congress, also predicted that the Japanese share of the United States market would rise to 33 percent in 1991, from about 26 percent in 1987.

headline: Archer-Daniels: A Bet on Rain
abstract: LEAD: AS the drought threatens crops in the Middle West, the prospects for the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company are beginning to look a bit shaky. The Decatur, Ill., company is a major grain processor and continued high grain prices could put a major squeeze on its profits in the fiscal year 1989, which began July 1.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association is offering $300 million of floating-rate notes, due next Jan. 12, through various securities dealers.

headline: York International Accepts Buyout Offer
abstract: LEAD: The board of the York International Corporation accepted an offer of $57.50 a share in cash and securities, or about $750 million, from a management group led by Citicorp's venture capital unit. The board rejected a $59-a-share, or $767 million, cash takeover offer from an unidentified third party.

headline: Koppers Sets Deal For Chemical Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Koppers Company has signed a letter of intent to sell its chemical division for $660 million to an investor group that includes some Koppers managers, Beazer P.L.C. said. Beazer agreed to acquire Koppers on June 1 for about $1.81 billion. The sale, which had been expected, would leave Koppers with its construction-materials business, which accounted for 60 percent of its revenue in 1987.

headline: Thatcher Sees Benefits for West If Gorbachev Reshapes U.S.S.R.
abstract: LEAD: Comparing her own experience in Britain to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempt to reshape the Soviet Union, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that it was ''in the Western interest'' for Mr. Gorbachev to succeed in his effort.

headline: Staying in Stocks, but Cutting the Risk
abstract: LEAD: AS the anniversary of Black Monday approaches, investors are reviewing their stock portfolios, assessing the past year's performance and charting a course for the future. But given the uncertain economic outlook and the looming Presidential election, many people want to minimize risk without abandoning the market.

headline: JVC Increases Output
abstract: LEAD: The Victor Company of Japan has doubled television production at its United States unit because of growing demand, it said today. Monthly output has been increased to 40,000 units from 20,000 at the JVC Manufacturing Company, Elmwood Park, N.J.

headline: Card Calculations
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Utility Chief Adds Positions
abstract: LEAD: The New England Electric System yesterday named Joan T. Bok, its chairman, to fill the positions of president and chief executive while the company searches for a replacement for Samuel Huntington, who was killed by lightning last week.

headline: Company News; American Financial
abstract: LEAD: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, increased their stake in National Convenience Stores Inc. to 17.2 percent from 15.84 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Lindner said that, although he had received Federal permission to increase the National Convenience stake to 24.9 percent, he had ''no present plans to acquire control of the company.

headline: Underwriters to Be Sought For Farm Credit Agency
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, created by the Agricultural Credit Act of 1987 to build a secondary market facility for agricultural real estate loans, will come a step closer to reality today.

headline: Chrysler and Renault Discuss Jeep Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation and Renault are discussing the possibility of building Jeeps in Europe. The talks were made known today by Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, Lee A. Iaccoca, at a news conference at the Mondiale de l'Automobile, the annual car show in Paris.

headline: African Nations Barring Foreign Toxic Waste
abstract: LEAD: Tourist guidebooks call it Congo's ''Little Colorado,'' a stunning gorge of plunging, pink cliffs draped with green Central African jungle.

headline: Deal for Friendly Offers Official Chance to Shine
abstract: LEAD: Donald N. Smith's latest venture, the purchase of the Friendly Ice Cream Corporation for about $375 million by his company, may restore his reputation as one of the restaurant industry's brightest stars.

headline: Corn and Soybeans Drop; Crude Oil Prices Also Fall
abstract: LEAD: Corn and soybean prices fell yesterday, partly because many market participants have begun to liquidate or hedge their positions as they await a special Agriculture Department report on Tuesday on the estimated crop damage caused by the nation's worst drought since the 1930's.

headline: U.S. Officials Split Over Whether to Appeal Ruling on P.L.O.
abstract: LEAD: Reagan Administration officials are engaged in a bitter internal debate over whether to appeal a Federal court decision that upholds the right of the Palestine Liberation Organization to keep an observer mission at the headquarters of the United Nations in New York.

headline: Haiti's New Leader Installs A Mostly Civilian Cabinet
abstract: LEAD: Haiti's new President, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, today swore in a new Government composed almost exclusively of civilians.

headline: Bozell, Jacobs Chosen By a Japanese Client
abstract: LEAD: The Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Pacific division has been tapped to handle the Asics Tiger Corporation's athletic shoes and active wear account in the United States. The budget is $7 million.  No agency search was conducted. The client, whose parent company is based in Tokyo, said it had chosen the shop because of its familiarity with the Pacific Rim and Tokyo affiliates.

headline: Korea-U.S. Trade Gap
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States shrank by 15.7 percent in the first seven months of the year, to $4.66 billion, from $5.53 billion a year earlier, the Government reported today. Officials attributed the reduction to Korea's revaluation of the won. Korean merchandise exports to the United States rose 10.8 percent, to $11.39 billion, in the period, while imports from the United States surged by 41.5 percent, to $6.73 billion, the report said.

headline: A Dingman Ally In Henley Spinoff
abstract: LEAD: Michael D. Dingman, chairman of Henley Group Inc., has taken on a partner in his $103.9 million investment in the Henley Manufacturing Corporation, a chemical concern that was spun off as a public company last year.

headline: I.B.M. Sells Part Of Satellite Unit
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it had sold a minority interest in its satellite leasing company to a unit of the Hughes Aircraft Company, and had contracted with Hughes to market its satellite channels to corporate customers. Terms were not disclosed. The fleet of three satellites, all made by Hughes, was valued at more than $250 million by I.B.M., which acquired the satellites in 1986 from the MCI Communications

headline: Few Are Jobless in Japan
abstract: LEAD: High demand for workers because of rapid economic growth pushed Japan's unemployment rate down to 2.4 percent in June, its lowest level in 67 months, the Government announced Friday. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate for June was a tenth of a percentage point lower than in May and sixth-tenths of a percentage point below the previous year's level, the Management and Coordination Agency said.

headline: HIGH CHINESE AIDE WILL VISIT MOSCOW, SOVIETS ANNOUNCE
abstract: LEAD: China's Foreign Minister will visit Moscow this year and meet with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman announced today. It will be the highest level at which the two nations have met since the 1960's.

headline: Patents; New Designs For Sports Equipment: A 5-Bladed Boomerang That Flies Straight Back
abstract: LEAD: J. Turner Hunt, an aeronautical engineer at the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, has invented a five-bladed boomerang that he says is easier to use than the original Australian type.

headline: Partnership Seeks Wyatt Cafeterias
abstract: LEAD: Furr's/Bishop's Cafeterias L.P. said it had offered to acquire the Dallas-based Wyatt Cafeterias Inc. for $87 a share, or $179 million. The bid follows an $84-a-share tender offer proposed three weeks ago by Wyatt Cafeterias' employee stock ownership plan. The earlier offer will be considered at a stockholders meeting on Sept.

headline: Alcoa Moves Into the Black
abstract: LEAD: The Aluminum Company of America, the world's largest aluminum producer, yesterday reported second-quarter net income of $237.6 million, or $2.69 a share, in contrast to a $91.2 million loss in the period last year.

headline: SALE OF KOPPERS CHEMICAL UNIT SEEN
abstract: LEAD: Beazer P.L.C., which struck a deal last month to acquire the Koppers Company, is expected to announce by tomorrow that it has reached a preliminary agreement to sell the Koppers' chemical unit to a management-led group, according to people familiar with the deal.

headline: Your Money Buying Property Through a Fund
abstract: LEAD: For many investors, discussions of such financial terms as CATS and TIGR's, strips and straddles, covered calls and triple witching hour seem reminiscent of Alice's encounter with the Red Queen. They long for terra firma.

headline: Holding in Lonrho Is Frozen by Court
abstract: LEAD: Lonrho P.L.C., a British mining and hotel conglomerate, obtained a court order freezing a block of its stock controlled by the New York speculator Asher B. Edelman. The freeze order is effective until a full trial, but Mr. Edelman can ask the court to lift the temporary order. Mr. Edelman said in New

headline: Canadian Legislators at Impasse on Abortion
abstract: LEAD: An emotional debate in Canada's House of Commons has failed to resolve the conflict that arose earlier this year when the Supreme Court struck down the country's abortion law.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; BBDO Promotions
abstract: LEAD: Philip B. Dusenberry, chairman and newly elected chief executive of BBDO New York, has appointed Gary de Paolo, 46, and Joseph Barrett, 53, managing directors, and Ted Sann, 43, and Charles Miesmer, 46, executive creative directors. All are already executive vice presidents and members of the New York board.

headline: Computer Chip Talks Are Set
abstract: LEAD: Semiconductor consumers and producers will hold an industry meeting Thursday in San Jose, Calif.

headline: JORDAN WILL STOP EMPLOYEES' WAGES IN THE WEST BANK
abstract: LEAD: Jordan announced today that it would stop paying the salaries of virtually all its employees in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

headline: FEDERAL RESERVE STEPS UP INTEREST TO SLOW INFLATION
abstract: LEAD: In a move to underscore its resolve in fighting inflation, the Federal Reserve Board voted unanimously today to raise its discount rate by a half point, to 6 1/2 percent.

headline: Network Computing Lures Husband-and-Wife Team
abstract: LEAD: When William Carrico and Judith Estrin resigned as president and senior vice president of the 3Com Corporation in June, their plan was to take three months off and see the world. But it has not worked out that way.  The husband-and-wife founders of Bridge Communications Inc., which merged with 3Com in September 1987, soon found themselves deluged with job offers and business plans, and yesterday announced they have joined Network Computing Devices Inc., a startup company based in Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Brunswick Corp., Skokie, Ill., said its Mercury Marine division had agreed to build an all-aluminum engine for General Motors Corp.'s Chevrolet Corvette.

headline: Strongest Quake in 54 Years Said to Rock Himalayan Area
abstract: LEAD: The strongest earthquake in the area in 54 years shook the Himalayas along the India-Nepal border early Sunday, the United States Geological Survey reported today.

headline: Volkswagen Prices Rise
abstract: LEAD: Volkswagen A.G. said it would raise its car prices by an average of 1.9 percent in its new model year, which begins Monday. Volkswagen said Saturday that the increases were linked to improvements in accessories, but the company gave no details.

headline: Pretoria Plans Black Councils
abstract: LEAD: The Government published plans today to establish black regional assemblies that would have limited powers to make laws on matters like education, welfare and local rule.

headline: Canada Trade Pact Sent To Congress by Reagan
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan sent to Capitol Hill today a sweeping overhaul of trade laws with Canada that would eliminate all tariff barriers between the two countries within 10 years.

headline: Cape Town Journal; Afrikaners Feud Over Past, and Path to the Future
abstract: LEAD: Sitting on the newly painted green bench of a canvas-and-wood ox-wagon, Flip Du Plooy cracked his whip, and the seven pairs of oxen took their first steps on a 2,000-mile journey into the past.

headline: Univision Names Head Of Spanish Network
abstract: LEAD: Univision Holdings Inc., which is owned by Hallmark Cards Inc., yesterday announced the appointment of Joaquin F. Blaya as president of its Spanish-language television network.

headline: Students Protest in Panama
abstract: LEAD: The riot police fired tear gas at rock-throwing student demonstrators today, and dockworkers went on strike to protest Panama's economic crisis.

headline: Group Buys 8.3% Of Best Products
abstract: LEAD: The Prospect Group Inc. has purchased an 8.3 percent stake in the Best Products Company and said it may hold talks with management about possible transactions, including an acquisition of the chain of catalogue showrooms. At today's closing price of $15.625 a share, down 62.5 cents, Best Products, with 26.8 million shares outstanding, is worth $418 million.

headline: Managua Journal; At Home, the Sandinistas Face a Businesslike Foe
abstract: LEAD: Although the ideals of capitalism and unbridled free enterprise are viewed suspiciously in Nicaragua, a group of outspoken businessmen has remained in the country and emerged as a key part of the anti-Sandinista opposition.

headline: Mergers Announced In Communications
abstract: LEAD: A number of ever-popular mergers and acquisitions in the communications field were reported yesterday.

headline: Long-Term Dangers in Dollar Rise
abstract: LEAD: The continuing rally in the dollar has had short-term benefits, including making imports cheaper and reducing the prospect of higher inflation. But it also hides real long-term dangers, including a slowdown in economic growth and a widening, rather than narrowing, United States trade deficit, according to three new economic studies.

headline: Economic Scene; Earnings Plight Of Baby Boomers
abstract: LEAD: COUNT the Reagan Administration's economic successes: Inflation is running a tepid 5 percent, unemployment is at a decade low and after-tax household income has never been higher. How, then, can Michael Dukakis hope to score points with voters on pocketbook issues?

headline: Hostage Slain in German Siege
abstract: LEAD: Two fleeing bank robbers fatally shot one of about 25 hostages in the head Wednesday, leaving him mortally wounded at a rest area off a highway, and speeding away with the rest of the captives in a bus they had seized, witnesses said.

headline: 15 Hurt in French Crash
abstract: LEAD: A train moving at 30 miles an hour hit another train stopped with mechanical problems today and 15 people were reported wounded. The state-run train authority said the conductor of the moving train had failed to heed a yellow warning signal to slow down.

headline: New Strife in Lebanon Amid Political Impasse
abstract: LEAD: A new round of fighting in the mountains east of Beirut and a wave of bomb explosions in the Moslem part of the capital have underlined growing sectarian tension in Lebanon.

headline: Coca-Cola Denies Bribes to Soviets
abstract: LEAD: Executives of the Coca-Cola Company have denied accusations that the company paid bribes to gain access to markets in the Soviet Union.Coca-Cola's chairman, Roberto C. Goizueta, distributed a memo to employees last week saying that an internal investigation uncovered no wrongdoing by Coke workers, a company spokesman, Carlton

headline: Senate Clears Import Curbs By 57-32 Vote
abstract: LEAD: The Senate today approved, 57 to 32, a bill to limit imports of textile goods, apparel and non-rubber footwear.

headline: Growth in Consumer Credit Slowed in July
abstract: LEAD: Americans took out $2.6 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in July, a sharp slowdown from the pace of growth during the first half of the year.

headline: Suits Filed by 2 Unions On Cutbacks at Eastern
abstract: LEAD: The pilots' and machinists' unions at Eastern Air Lines Inc. each filed lawsuits today, seeking to block the carrier's plans to eliminate 4,000 jobs and sharply reduce its flight schedule.

headline: A Munich Refrain: Peals Of Music in Hitler's Hall
abstract: LEAD: Though the cold atrium is empty, the muffled cacophony of pianos, trumpets and voices and the echo of heels clacking somewhere on a marble floor seem today to be almost a theatrical prelude to a fateful scene - like the one staged here a half-century ago.

headline: U.S. Warns Europe on Trade Plan
abstract: LEAD: The United States would find it ''unacceptable'' if the European Community's 1992 integration plans curb American access to the 12-nation bloc, a senior Reagan Administration official said today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Group Reports A Big Rise in Earnings
abstract: LEAD: The WPP Group P.L.C., the British advertising conglomerate, has reported large earnings gains for the six months that ended on June 30, mainly because of new business and operating increases at the J. Walter Thompson Company, which it acquired last year, and at Hill & Knowlton.

headline: First Fidelity Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: The First Fidelity Bancorporation said today that it would acquire Montclair Savings Bank in a transaction valued at about $80 million. Montclair, which has eight offices in New Jersey, will operate under its own name as a separate subsidiary of First Fidelity, the bank said.

headline: British Company Seeks Payless Data
abstract: LEAD: The Ward White Group P.L.C. said that it had requested information from Payless Cashways Inc. and that it might make a takeover bid for the American home-improvement store chain. ''We were just requesting information as a fact-finding operation, that's all,'' said Philip Horwath, Ward White's secretary.

headline: New Chairman At Gas Utility
abstract: LEAD: Richard D. Farman will become the chairman and chief executive of the Southern California Gas Company, the nation's largest gas utility, effective Jan. 1, 1989.

headline: Authorities in Burma Round Up Dissidents
abstract: LEAD: The Burmese authorities seized more than 10 critics of the Government and the Burmese correspondent of The Associated Press, Western diplomats contacted in Rangoon, the Burmese capital, said today.

headline: Gold Miner Weighs South Africa Move
abstract: LEAD: Consolidated Goldfields P.L.C., a leading world gold producer, has contingency plans to pull out of South Africa, where it earns 15 percent of its profits, its chairman said. ''If the world's governments tell us to depart South Africa, we will do so,'' R. I. J. Agnew said at a news conference. ''We have set up the mechanism.

headline: Greece Expects Talks On Bases to Continue
abstract: LEAD: A spokesman for the Greek Government said today that Athens expected talks on the future of the American military bases here to be continued in October. United States negotiators suspended the talks on Monday after Greece said it had decided to close one of the bases.

headline: Gabelli Settles S.E.C. Case
abstract: LEAD: The New York investor Mario J. Gabelli and companies he controls today settled disciplinary charges contending that they violated Federal securities laws in their abortive attempt to take the Di Giorgio Corporation private in 1987.

headline: Lotus Program
abstract: LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation said it had begun shipping Agenda, a software program designed to store and retrieve free-form information such as personal notes, outlines, messages and other data. The program was originally to be released in April. The company, however, said it had extensively redesigned the appearance of the program based on suggestions of its test users.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * AMP Inc., Harrisburg, Pa., said shareholders of Matrix Science Corp. had approved a merger bid that would result in an exchange of stock valued at about $110 million.

headline: Forecast Drives Up Crop Futures
abstract: LEAD: Forecasts of a return of hot, dry weather to the nation's Farm Belt this weekend again catapulted most prices of soybeans and corn to their daily permissible limits on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

headline: BIG INVESTORS FEAR EXCHANGES' PLAN
abstract: LEAD: The automatic trading halts proposed by officials of the New York Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on Thursday are being opposed by some of the market's biggest and most influential investors.

headline: Big North Carolina Bank Has 'Sweeping Ambition'
abstract: LEAD: The NCNB Corporation, which today won Federal approval to take over the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas, has a reputation for maneuvering its way into new markets ahead of its competitors.

headline: Roy Rogers To Cancel Ad
abstract: LEAD: Roy Rogers Restaurants, the roast-beef-and-burger chain, said yesterday that it would take off the air a television commercial that some school cafeteria workers had complained about.

headline: Drought's Toll on Cannery Plants
abstract: LEAD: For vegetable canners, the recent rains that have been providing some relief to the drought-stricken Midwest are likely to prove too little or too late.

headline: U.S. and Afghan Guerrillas Debate New Raids
abstract: LEAD: There is a growing debate between American officials and Afghan guerrilla leaders over how best to insure the speedy exodus of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

headline: USG Restructuring Backed by Holders
abstract: LEAD: The USG Corporation's shareholders overwhelmingly approved a restructuring plan that will increase the company's debt to $3.1 billion from $800 million. The restructuring was the legacy of its costly victory in a takeover battle with Desert Partners L.P. Under the plan, shareholders of record by next

headline: Kidder Data Link With First Boston
abstract: LEAD: The First Boston Corporation said it would give one of its competitors, Kidder, Peabody & Company, access to its computer system, a move that will help cover the system's cost and help pay for its future development. First Boston developed its advanced global trading and clearance system in 1985. It will allow the companies to do 24-hour trading, introduce new products more quickly and major costs.

headline: Allied-Signal Stake
abstract: LEAD: Siemens A.G. of West Germany said it had agreed to buy at least 51 percent of the Bendix Electronics Group unit of Allied-Signal Inc., with an option to buy the rest of the subsidiary in three years. The companies declined to specify the percentage of the equity now being transferred to Siemens, but an Allied-Signal spokesman said the company expected $200 million to $300 million from the sale.

headline: 1 Dead and 56 Hurt In Bombing at Stores Near Johannesburg
abstract: LEAD: A bomb exploded at a crowded shopping center in a white suburb of Johannesburg today, killing a woman and wounding at least 56 other people, the police said. The authorities said most of the victims were white, including the woman who died.

headline: Irish Distillers Rejects British Bid
abstract: LEAD: Irish Distillers Group P.L.C., makers of Ireland's leading whiskies, said it had rejected a takeover bid from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the big British hotel group. Distillers's chairman, Joe McCabe, said the offer by GC & C Brands Ltd., a group acting for Grand Met, valuing Distillers at 250 million

headline: AC&R/DHB Receives Sterling Auto Account
abstract: LEAD: It is hardly a surprise, but now it is official. Austin Rover Cars of North America has designated AC&R/DHB & Bess Advertising to handle its $20 million account to promote the Sterling 825S and 825SL luxury sedans.

headline: A Test for Labatt's U.S. Expansion
abstract: LEAD: For John Labatt Ltd., becoming one of the leading dairy companies in the Northeast in just three years was easy - at least when compared with the challenge of making money in the newly deregulated New York City milk business.

headline: West German Hostage Is Released in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: A West German hostage who had been held captive for 20 months was released in Moslem-controlled West Beirut on Monday, Lebanese and West German Embassy officials said today.

headline: Blount to Sell Steel Division
abstract: LEAD: Blount Inc. announced an agreement today to sell its Washington Steel subsidiary to the Mercury Stainless Corporation for $290 million, taking Blount out of the specialty steel business.

headline: Toshiba Unit To Scale Back
abstract: LEAD: The Toshiba Machine Company, whose illegal exports to the Soviet Union drew criticism from the West last year, said today that it would cut its American operations because of restrictions on its United States exports.

headline: Business Week Broadcaster Is Dismissed Over Holdings
abstract: LEAD: Business Week magazine said yesterday that it had dismissed Rudy Ruderman, who broadcasts its daily stock-market radio reports, for violating the magazine's disclosure requirements by failing to disclose all of his stock holdings.

headline: 38 Killed in India Ship Accident
abstract: LEAD: A passenger ship carrying at least 300 Hindu pilgrims capsized today in the Ganges River in eastern India. At least 38 people were reported killed and hundreds were missing, the authorities said.

headline: Notes Offered By Sallie Mae
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $400 million of short-term floating-rate notes due Feb. 9 through various securities dealers. Investors are being offered the securities at par, giving them a yield of about 55 hundredths of a percentage point more than the equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill.

headline: Wells Examines First Republicbank
abstract: LEAD: Eight auditors from Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco began examining the financial condition of the First Republicbank Corporation, First Republic said. As the list of suitors bidding to take over First Republicbank has grown to include Wells Fargo, as well as the NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., and Citicorp of New York, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has asked the Dallas bank to submit additional information regarding its recapitalization plan, First

headline: Dollar's Rise Is Curbed by Intervention
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve and several European central banks quickly stepped into the foreign exchange market yesterday in an effort to cut off a dollar rally and back up a crucial weekend communique reasserting support of stable currencies.

headline: Wall St. Fights Customer Plan
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street officials have met with staff members of the Securities and Exchange Commission in an effort to derail its proposal on customer disputes.

headline: Knight-Ridder to Buy Lockheed's Dialog Unit
abstract: LEAD: Knight-Ridder Inc. announced today that it would buy Dialog Information Services Inc., the world's biggest electronic information retrieval company, from the Lockheed Corporation for $353 million.

headline: Burma's Protest Spreads To Professional Classes
abstract: LEAD: Protesters in Burma mounted the largest demonstrations today since a widespread uprising two weeks ago, as opposition to the Government appeared to grow bolder and more broadly based.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Armco Inc., Parsippany, N.J., said it would take a second-quarter charge of about $15 million related to those insurance operations of its Armco Financial Group that have stopped writing new business and are being liquidated.

headline: A New Method to Kill Salmonella in Poultry
abstract: LEAD: The Monsanto Company received a patent this week for a new approach to killing salmonella bacteria in poultry. Salmonella causes nausea, vomiting and other flu-like symptoms, and more serious illness in people with weakened immune systems.

headline: Former Navy Chief Defends Policies
abstract: LEAD: Former Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. today called for the mandatory registration of consultants involved in military procurement, but he said the Navy's procurement policies were not to blame for possible fraud in contracting.

headline: Officials Assert U.S. Is Trying To Weaken Costa Rica Chief
abstract: LEAD: Publicly, the United States has praised President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica for leading the quest for peace in Central America. But privately, Reagan Administration officials have taken steps to embarrass and undermine him, and have derisively referred to him as ''the laureate,'' according to political leaders here and in Washington.

headline: Jamaica Counts the Hurricane Toll: 25 Dead and 4 Out of 5 Homes Roofless
abstract: LEAD: Reconnaissance flights over remote parts of Jamaica brought back reports today indicating that a hurricane left widespread devastation throughout the country and that 80 percent of the homes on the island had lost their roofs.

headline: More Job Cuts Seen for Wall Street
abstract: LEAD: Before year-end Wall Street will cut as many as 5,000 more jobs, analysts predict, as last October's stock market collapse continues to be felt throughout the financial markets. Brokerage firms have already reduced their payrolls by 15,000 since the market peaked a year ago.

headline: Treasuries Up in Sluggish Session
abstract: LEAD: The prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched upward in very sluggish trading yesterday, as market participants prepared for an inflation report due out this morning.

headline: Nigeria, Diversifying, Builds an Oil Refinery
abstract: LEAD: A glittering new oil refinery here, the largest and most efficient in black Africa, represents Nigeria's latest step away from crude oil exports.

headline: Ethnic Germans in East Bloc Now Flock to West Germany
abstract: LEAD: Their eyes ringed with the fatigue of long journeys and difficult farewells, the newcomers swarm through the barracks and yards of the reception camp speaking in a babel of Slavic tongues and archaic German dialects.

headline: Groups Taking Aid Donations
abstract: LEAD:  American Jewish World Service, 729 Boylson Street, Boston, Mass. 02116.  American National Red Cross, Bangladesh Relief, P.O. Box 37243, Washington, D.C. 20013.  CARE, Bangladesh Flood Relief, 660 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.  Operation California, 7615 1/2 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles, Calif.

headline: Ruder Urges Insider Drive
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, David S. Ruder, urged other stock market regulators today to introduce effective and compatible laws to deter insider trading.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Cain Chemical Inc., Dallas, a producer of ethylene, ethylene oxide and derivatives, high-density polyethylene and related chemicals, appointed Frank H. Romanelli president of its petrochemical division. Cain is a subsidiary of Occidental Petroleum Corp.

headline: U.S. Awards I.B.M. $3.6 Billion Contract
abstract: LEAD: The Transportation Department has selected the International Business Machines Corporation for a $3.6 billion contract to modernize the computer equipment used by air traffic controllers, the department announced tonight.

headline: North Korea Rejects Overtures From Seoul
abstract: LEAD: North Korea today rejected a South Korean proposal to end the animosity between the two countries, saying the plan served only to make the division permanent.

headline: Commerce Savings Buyout Talks Held
abstract: LEAD: The American Century Corporation, the parent of Commerce Savings Association, has discussed a buyout of the Texas savings institution with the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. The disclosure of the talks was contained in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing by a Dallas investor, G. H. Stool, who is a director of American Century.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Massachusetts Mutual Names Its Next Chief
abstract: LEAD: In 1962, his first year at the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Thomas B. Wheeler sold policies with a face value of $1.5 million and got a place on the Million Dollar Roundtable, of which he is now a life member.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Stocks Mixed in Slow Day; Dow Up 4.45
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday in a lackluster session in which the Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.45 points to close at 2,025.96.

headline: Chief of Municipal Finance At Bear, Stearns Resigns
abstract: LEAD: Three months after a management shake-up relieved him of his administrative duties, Joseph M. Giglio Jr. resigned yesterday as head of public finance at Bear, Stearns & Company, the firm said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shearson Expands TV Presentations
abstract: LEAD: FORMER Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger; Frederick W. Smith, the chairman of Federal Express, and John Templeton, an investment manager, have all been interviewed by Richard Valeriani, the former television newsman, for a series of Shearson Lehman Hutton commercials that will begin Saturday.

headline: China Issues Bonds
abstract: LEAD: China's Communications Bank in Singapore issued $100 million of five-year bonds denominated in United States dollars, China's official press agency reported yesterday. The notes, which are the first the bank has issued abroad, have a yield of 9.375 percent. The bank said the issue would be used to back ''municipal construction and technological renovation.

headline: Shell Profit Drops 1.1%
abstract: LEAD: The Shell Oil Company's profits fell to $263 million in the second quarter, from $266 million a year earlier, a decline of 1.1 percent, the company said yesterday. Revenue rose to $5.43 billion from $5.18 billion, an increase of 4.8 percent.

headline: Account
abstract: LEAD: * Ohio Grape Industries program to Meldrum & Fewsmith, Cleveland.

headline: Consumer Protection 101 for Chinese
abstract: LEAD: As China moves toward an economy driven more by consumer demand than by central planners, its leaders have begun to recognize that greater consumer choice also requires greater consumer protection.

headline: CARLUCCI SEES CUT IN U.S. GULF FLEET
abstract: LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq could bring about a substantial reduction in the American fleet in the Persian Gulf area once dangers to shipping subsided.

headline: China Nods Sagely at Soviet Changes
abstract: LEAD: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev toured his carefully crafted landscape of economic and political change with 5,000 delegates to the Communist Party conference in Moscow last week, he trod terrain that seemed familiar to many Chinese.

headline: Castro Urges Sugar Gain
abstract: LEAD: President Fidel Castro wants Cuba to increase its revenue with a bigger sugar harvest next year, according to the official daily newspaper Granma. At a Communist Party meeting on Friday, it said, he called for an increase to 8 million metric tons, from this year's estimated 7.3 million tons.

headline: Chairman of General Foods Takes Top Job at Pillsbury
abstract: LEAD: The Pillsbury Company today named Philip L. Smith, the chairman of the General Foods Corporation, as its chairman, chief executive and president.

headline: Stein & Day To Shut Down
abstract: LEAD: Stein & Day Inc., the small publisher that is one of the nation's few remaining independent publishing houses, will sell its 1,200-title backlist and go out of business.

headline: U.N. Chief Tries New Tack in Gulf Talks Impasse
abstract: LEAD: The Iran-Iraq peace talks remained deadlocked tonight after Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations submitted a new compromise proposal, United Nations officials said.

headline: New York Merc Chief Resigns After Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: William M. Bradt, the embattled chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, resigned late Thursday after the Commodity Futures Trading Commission found he had acted in an inappropriate fashion in some exchange matters.

headline: NBC Considers Scrapping Saturday Cartoons
abstract: LEAD: Saturday morning has long been the playground of network television, the place where Smurfs, Chipmunks and other cartoon creatures reigned over a time period given over by all three networks to children viewers.

abstract: LEAD: The grain and soybean markets came under renewed selling pressure yesterday as the July futures contracts expired. headline: U.S. Appeals Court Delays Detroit Newspaper Merger
abstract: LEAD: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press to delay their partial merger, which could have begun as early as this weekend, as the judges consider whether the deal should be scrapped altogether.

headline: Dow Up 15.83, Its 3d Gain in a Row
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices moved generally higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 15.83 points to close at 2,129.45.

headline: Ames to Buy Discount Unit From Zayre
abstract: LEAD: The Zayre Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Zayre discount department stores to its nearest competitor, Ames Department Stores Inc.

headline: Salvador TV Dares to Tell the News
abstract: LEAD: Barreling past sleepy sentries at the crack of dawn, a caravan of foreign journalists and Salvadoran television reporters sped into the mountains a few months ago to rendezvous with senior commanders of the guerrilla movement fighting the Government.

headline: Prices Paid to Farmers Increased 3.6% in July
abstract: LEAD: Prices paid to farmers for grain and other raw products rose 3.6 percent in July, from June levels, as drought continued to take a toll on crop and livestock production.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly

headline: Market Place; Gundle's Growth And Volatility
abstract: LEAD: GUNDLE ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS INC. is a growth stock that presents some classic quandaries for investors. The one-product company has enjoyed strong demand for the plastic liners it makes for trash dumps and toxic waste sites. Its stock has about tripled since the Oct. 19 stock market crash, from $8 to $24.125 yesterday on the American Stock

headline: U.S. Joins in Loan for Brazil
abstract: LEAD: The United States said today that it had joined a group of countries in providing a $500 million bridge loan for Brazil until the International Monetary Fund gives final approval to a new Brazilian financial package.

headline: Expert in Turnarounds Gets the Top Job at York
abstract: LEAD: James T. Dresher, who helped pull off a turnabout at the York International Corporation, has been named chairman and chief executive of the air-conditioning manufacturer.

headline: Making Garbage 'Disappear Like Magic'
abstract: LEAD: THE movement to ban many categories of plastics unless they degrade in the environment is not founded strictly on logic. After all, plastics make up only about 7 percent of the garbage in waste dumps. But to the casual observer, that is a highly visable 7 percent.  ''What the public is reacting to is the fact that the first plastic clam shell that was ever thrown out is still lying there,'' said John Angus, a director of the Eco Corporation, a Canadian maker of additives that make plastics degrade.

headline: MEXICANS PROTEST DELAY IN RESULTS OF THE ELECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of Mexicans gathered at vote tallying centers around the country today to protest the delay in announcing official results from the July 6 presidential election.
