headline: Seabrook Moves Aid Both Sides
abstract: LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday removed one major obstacle to giving a test permit to the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire, but reluctantly agreed with opponents of the plant on another issue.

headline: Chrysler Forecast
abstract: LEAD: Chrysler Corporation officials said they did not expect sales to increase in 1989, despite the introduction later of three new car models. Bennett E. Bidwell, president for marketing at Chrysler Motors, said he expected sales of about one million cars and the same number of trucks next year, about even with projected 1988 sales.

headline: Bank of New York Loses Request for Quick Hearing
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of New York suffered a legal setback yesterday in its long-running battle to acquire the Irving Bank Corporation and will be forced to ask the Federal Reserve Board for a third extension for its bid.

headline: U.S. Among the Targets of Third World Bloc
abstract: LEAD: The foreign ministers of the 101-nation Nonaligned Movement have ended their four-day annual conference with a statement criticizing the United States, South Africa and Israel and expressing support for Nicaragua.

headline: HIJACKING SUSPECT IS CALLED A KILLER
abstract: LEAD: The pilot of a T.W.A. jet hijacked in 1985 testified in a West German court today that it was the defendant at the trial, Mohammed Ali Hamadei, who killed an American hostage and who was the more savage of two men who seized the plane.

headline: Company News; GPA Buys Option On Braniff Stake
abstract: LEAD: The GPA Group said today that it had acquired an option to buy 10 percent of Braniff Inc. as part of an airplane deal. GPA Group, a privately owned financial services company based in Ireland, specializes in aircraft asset management. BIA-COR Holdings Inc., a United States investment group formed by the Paine Webber Group, recently acquired the Dallas-based Braniff from the Pritzker family of

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Consumer Health Picks Messner, Vetere, Berger
abstract: LEAD: Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey has become agency for Consumer Health Services of Boulder, Colo., which operates a reference service for consumers who want to know more about a physician or dentist. The hospitals the professionals are affiliated with pay the fee; there is no charge to consumers.

headline: Company News; Qantas Jet Order
abstract: LEAD: Australia's international carrier Qantas Airways Ltd. has placed an order for three additional jetliners from the Boeing Company. ''The acquisitions, which will build the Qantas fleet to 43 aircraft, are needed to meet traffic demand,'' Jim Leslie, Qantas's chairman, said in a statement. He said the planes, two 747-400's and a 767-300ER, would lift the airline's order list to 11 new planes at a total cost of $2.06 billion.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Centex Corp., Dallas, the home building, cement manufacturing and general construction concern, said Laurence E. Hirsch, its president and chief operating officer, had been given the additional title of chief executive. He is succeeding Paul R. Seegers, who continues as chairman.

headline: U.S. Presses Targets for Aid In Pentagon Fraud Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Federal prosecutors are increasing the pressure on some of the targets in the Pentagon fraud and bribery investigation, warning them that time is running out to make deals to cooperate with investigators in return for immunity from prosecution.

headline: Speech by Reagan to U.N. Today Seen as Sign of Change in Attitude
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan, who has regarded the United Nations with skepticism for most of his years in public life, is expected to salute the international organization Monday in his address to the General Assembly.

headline: Deal Sought By Nomura
abstract: LEAD: The Nomura Securities Company is negotiating to purchase a large stake in GNP Commodities Inc., GNP's chairman, Brian Monieson, said today, although the deal is not imminent and terms were not disclosed.

headline: Dillon Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: The Dillon Companies, a supermarket chain based in Hutchinson, Kan., said its Kwik Shop Inc. subsidiary had agreed to buy forty-six 7-Eleven convenience stores from the Southland Corporation, based in Dallas. Terms were not disclosed. Dillon, a unit of the Kroger Company, said it would operate the stores as part of its Kwik Shop chain.

headline: Dow Slumps 20.27 in Lackluster Trading
abstract: LEAD: The stock market sagged sharply yesterday, in trading that remained desultory.

headline: Patrick Is Selling Billboards to Lower Debt
abstract: LEAD: The Patrick Media Group, the largest outdoor advertising company in the country, is selling an undisclosed number of billboards as part of a recapitalization to reduce its debt.

headline: Bulgarian Jet Crashes; 23 Are Reported Dead
abstract: LEAD: A Balkan Bulgarian Airlines jet crashed just after taking off from Sofia today, killing 23 people and injuring 14, the official Bulgarian press agency said.

headline: Flying Tiger Files Japan Complaint
abstract: LEAD: The Flying Tiger Line Inc. said it had filed a complaint with the Transportation Department charging that Japan has unfairly restricted its proposed service between Tokyo and Frankfurt. Since 1985, Flying Tiger, a Los Angeles air-cargo carrier, has sought new routes into Japan, but the country has historically restricted the operations of United

headline: Lord & Taylor's New President
abstract: LEAD: Ronald F. Tanler was named president of Lord & Taylor, the retail fashion chain, effective Aug. 5, its parent, the May Department Stores Company, said yesterday.

headline: 2 Pay Dearly For Affront To Hirohito
abstract: LEAD: One of Japan's largest newspaper groups demoted its editor in chief today and dismissed another senior editor after an English-language edition of the newspaper mistakenly published an editorial lamenting the death of Emperor Hirohito.

headline: Time Magazine to Begin New Editorial Features
abstract: LEAD: Time magazine, the largest United States news magazine, will make several editorial changes, starting with its Oct. 17 issue.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * British Petroleum Co., London, postponed the initial public offering of its BP Gold Co. subsidiary because of the recent drop in the price of gold.

headline: Regional Successes Bring New Support
abstract: LEAD: The Persian Gulf peace talks here are the latest indication that the United Nations, long faulted for failing to act as a world policeman, is finding growing importance in the more modest role of a kind of international go-between, resolving regional conflicts. It is not the role the

headline: South Koreans Woo Communists; Move to Full Ties With Hungary
abstract: LEAD: South Korea announced today that it would exchange permanent missions with Hungary, the first step toward diplomatic relations with a Soviet bloc country since South Korea became a separate nation 40 years ago.

headline: COMPANIES
abstract: LEAD:  Drexel employees are expected to be charged with a broad pattern of criminal activity over at least two years and possibly with racketeering, people close to the investigation said. They said the indictments against the Drexel executives, expected in October, would probably delay the huge civil proceeding initiated against the firm last week by the S.E.C.

headline: C.F.T.C. Deal With British
abstract: LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it had reached agreement to share information with the British Government in an effort to better coordinate the regulation of the futures industry.

headline: American at Hijacking Trial Describes Beating of Diver
abstract: LEAD: Mohammed Ali Hammadi, the Lebanese hijacker of a Trans World Airlines plane, severely beat a United States hostage and shouted ''let the pig suffer'' before hustling him at gunpoint to the spot where he was shot dead, a witness said at his trial today.

headline: Israelis Open Fire on Arabs, Wounding 24
abstract: LEAD: Israeli troops fired live ammunition and plastic bullets today to put down widespread Palestinian unrest, including an attack by masked, ax-wielding youths. Twenty-four Palestinians were wounded, Arab hospital officials said.

headline: Company News; Spanish Airline Buys Boeing Jets
abstract: LEAD: Hispania Lineas Aereas has purchased four advanced-technology 737-500 aircraft, valued at more than $105 million, from Boeing Commercial Airplanes, Boeing announced. The airline, based in Palma de Mallorca, Spain, will take delivery of the 130-passenger airplanes between June and August 1991.

headline: Chinese in Swedish Deal
abstract: LEAD: A Chinese enterprise has purchased Vetlanda Nordiska, a Swedish piano manufacturer, and is shipping its plant to China, the paper People's Daily reported today.

headline: 400 Now Feared Dead on Ganges Ferry
abstract: LEAD: Indian Navy divers joined local rescue workers today in the rain-swollen Ganges River in a search for survivors of an overcrowded ferry boat that capsized, killing as many as 400 people.

headline: Morgan Guaranty Sells 8.95% Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company is offering $100 million of 8.95 percent notes due in 1990 at par through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.

headline: No Escape of Radiation Seen In Fire at a Lithuanian Plant
abstract: LEAD: A nuclear power plant caught fire in Lithuania today, but automatic safety systems put out the flames before radiation was released, the official Tass press agency reported. Tass said no one was injured in the blaze, which began at 12:50 A.M. in a control cable of the second reactor at the Ignalina nuclear power plant, about 60 miles northeast of Vilnius, the capital of the Lithuanian Republic.

headline: Technicolor Purchase Is Set By Carlton Communications
abstract: LEAD: Carlton Communications P.L.C. said yesterday that it would acquire Technicolor Holdings Inc. from MacAndrews & Forbes Group for about $780 million.

headline: U.S. Notes and Bonds End Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were mixed in fairly active trading yesterday, as investors, attracted by yields that have risen sharply over the past few days, began to show interest in owning securities.

headline: Buyout at Steel Heddle
abstract: LEAD: The Steel Heddle Manufacturing Company, a producer of textile mill supplies based in Greenville, S.C., said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $105 a share by an investor group led by its senior management. The $75 million leveraged buyout is subject to the execution of a definitive agreement and requires shareholder approval.

headline: Turf Trade and a Tussle: Just a Berlin Kind of Day
abstract: LEAD: Several score West Berliners scrambled across the Berlin wall at dawn today in a brief eastward flight, adding a bizarre Berlin touch to the swap of several bits of misplaced land between the two halves of the divided city.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  COMPANIES  First Boston is discussing a possible merger with its European investment bank to form a private company. The talks are being held with Credit Suisse, the Swiss bank that is First Boston's partner in the jointly held European venture, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston. The announcement followed months of rumors and speculation, and a $15 rise in First Boston's stock since May.

headline: Israel Bombs Lebanese Radio Site Linked to the Palestinian Uprising
abstract: LEAD: Israeli fighter bombers raided Palestinian positions in southern Lebanon today and knocked out a radio station that reportedly broadcast messages from the Palestine Liberation Organization encouraging the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.

headline: Terrorist Blast Sets Off International Mystery
abstract: LEAD: Important new information is emerging about the life of one of the world's most wanted terrorists, who was apparently killed here last month in an incident that still baffles investigators, according to Greek, Italian and American antiterrorism officials.

headline: Mexico to Raise Oil Prices
abstract: LEAD: The Government oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, will raise its prices for crude oil exports to customers in the Western Hemisphere on Sept. 1, but the prices will not change for exports to Europe.

headline: Former Stock Analyst Admits Insider Guilt
abstract: LEAD: Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr., a former financial analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company, yesterday pleaded guilty to charges that he had engaged in an illegal insider trading scheme with at least two people.

headline: Interco Is Seeking Alternatives to Bid
abstract: LEAD: Interco Inc. said it had begun discussions with third parties, including commercial banks, about alternatives to a hostile takeover offer of $70 a share from the Rales brothers of Washington. Interco has rejected the $2.53 billion bid by City Capital Associates, a company controled by Steven and Mitchell

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WCRS Group Acquires Public Relations Concern
abstract: LEAD: The WCRS Group, one of the smaller British communications empires, has acquired Thomas L. Richmond Inc., a public relations company that will be merged into Creamer Dickson Basford, public relations.

headline: U.S. WILL PROVIDE BILLIONS TO RESCUE AILING TEXAS BANK
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation tonight announced a bailout of the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas, one of the nation's largest and most troubled banking companies.

headline: Durables Orders Up a Strong 8.8%
abstract: LEAD: Orders to the nation's factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods advanced in June at their fastest pace in 42 months, an 8.8 percent increase that was propelled by heavy demand for new commercial aircraft.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Radio Entrepreneur Mixes Fun and Money
abstract: LEAD: Three rules guide Robert F. X. Sillerman's life: having fun, making money and having fun at making money.

headline: Copper Price Forecast
abstract: LEAD: Higher world copper output next year is likely to end a run of price increases that began about a year ago, Shearson Lehman Hutton predicted Friday in its quarterly report. Shearson said copper prices, which earlier hit spot highs of $1.50 a pound, had not regained these levels. Shearson said the current year's surplus would be 65,000 metric tons, against a previous estimate of 130,000 metric tons.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
abstract: LEAD: Dunlop Slazenger's racquet sports division to Cole Henderson Drake, Atlanta.

headline: Waiting Out the Dollar's Rally
abstract: LEAD: THIS summer's dollar rally caught most forecasters and traders by surprise and it certainly got the attention of many corporate executives. But not for long.

headline: Tulsa Brokerage To Be Investigated
abstract: LEAD: The Oklahoma Securities Department will investigate the brokerage firm of Fitzgerald, DeArman & Roberts Inc., officials said. The department's administrator, Susan Bryant, said the investigation would focus on complaints about sales tactics used by the firm, which was closed Tuesday at the request of the Securities and Exchange

headline: Mubarak, in Europe, Stresses Role as Peace Broker
abstract: LEAD: With a European tour that took him today to Paris, President Hosni Mubarak has cast himself more forcefully than in recent months as a broker and central figure in the stalled quest for a Middle East peace.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; In-Flight Magazines Offering Bonus Pages
abstract: LEAD: Jeffrey S. Butler, president of East/West Network, which publishes seven in-flight magazines, has created a wonderfully expensive carrot on a stick.

headline: Arafat Backers' Ouster From Beirut Shifts P.L.O. Tensions to South
abstract: LEAD: Two days after the last Palestinian fighters loyal to Yasir Arafat were evicted from Beirut, tension in Lebanon has shifted to Palestinan districts near the southern port city of Sidon.

headline: Issue for SSC Holdings
abstract: LEAD: The SSC Holdings Corporation is issuing $500 million of debt in three tranches through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The first tranche of 13 percent senior subordinated extendible notes is priced at par and due in 1998. Due in 2000 will be $125 million of 12 1/2 percent notes and $175 million of 13 1/4 percent notes.

headline: Hedging Plan For Aluminum
abstract: LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has authorized a Federal power agency to buy option-like contracts to protect it against falling aluminum prices, officials of the agency, the Bonneville Power Administration, said today. The contracts would be bought from a broker - not acquired through trading.

headline: WALESA, MEETING WARSAW LEADERS, URGES STRIKE HALT
abstract: LEAD: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, called today for Polish strikers to return to work. The call was issued after Mr. Walesa met with members of the Polish leadership for the first time since Solidarity was suppressed in 1981.

headline: Japan to Pay Less for Rice
abstract: LEAD: Japan will lower the price it pays farmers for rice this year, a Government spokesman said today.

headline: Lebanon's Religions
abstract: LEAD:  Christians

headline: Business People; Bank Names New Officers
abstract: LEAD: The Greater New York Savings Bank, moving to fill a vacancy caused by the death of its top executive, yesterday named Charles J. Ohlig chairman and chief executive and Gerard C. Keegan president and chief operating officer.

headline: Fujitsu to Sell Sun Products
abstract: LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., and Fujitsu Ltd. of Tokyo said today that they had signed a five-year agreement valued at a minimum of $280 million under which Fujitsu would market Sun's ''S Family'' products.

headline: Shultz Holds Off on Soviet Emigres
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has decided against taking any immediate action to counter a recent move by the Israeli Cabinet that would effectively require most Jews who leave the Soviet Union to settle in Israel, State Department officials say.

headline: Strawberry Board Gives Account to Ketchum
abstract: LEAD: After a two-month review, the Strawberry Advisory Board has picked Ketchum Advertising/San Francisco to represent its product, a member of the genus Fragaria that is commonly known as the strawberry. The budget is between $1 million and $2 million.

headline: Wace to Acquire Techtron in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The British printing and publishing company Wace Group P.L.C. will acquire Techtron Imaging Network of Chicago for about $:33.4 million, or about $55.9 million. Techtron is the largest United States color separation and electronic imaging company, with revenue of $83 million last year.

headline: U.S. WILL ALLOW P.L.O TO MAINTAIN ITS OFFICE AT U.N.
abstract: LEAD: Acting on foreign policy grounds, President Reagan decided today not to contest a ruling allowing the Palestine Liberation Organization to maintain its observer mission to the United Nations.

headline: Loan Talks For Brazilian
abstract: LEAD: A Brazilian Finance Ministry official began a tour of Persian Gulf banks today to outline details of a new $63.6 billion debt-rescheduling package and a plan to raise $5.8 billion.

headline: Socialist? Yes, Says Sandinista Chief
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra defined his Sandinista Government today as socialist, but said it would continue to encourage ''mixed economy and political pluralism.''

headline: F.T.C. Favors Mark IV Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission approved the application of Mark IV Industries to acquire up to 15 percent of the common stock of the Armtek Corporation, Armtek announced yesterday. On July 4, Mark IV, based in

headline: IRAQIS PULL BACK FROM IRAN AS WAR AGAIN QUIETS DOWN
abstract: LEAD: Iraqi troops started pulling back today from Iranian territory that they had occupied, according to information from both warring Persian Gulf neighbors, as the fierce fighting that flared between them last week appeared to subside.

headline: British Bid For M.T.M.
abstract: LEAD: M.T.M. Entertainment Inc., the highly successful television production company co-founded by the actress Mary Tyler Moore, has agreed to be acquired by a British production company, published reports say.

headline: Solidarity Calls For Talks Again
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity labor union appealed again yesterday for talks with the Polish Government, a day after a range of emergency measures were instituted to halt a wave of labor disruptions.

headline: Israeli and 3 Arabs Are Killed In a Clash in South Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: An Israeli soldier and three Arab guerrillas were killed in a short exchange of fire this afternoon when Israeli troops entered the southern Lebanese village of Libbaya on a search-and-destroy mission, the army said tonight.

headline: Newcomers Rank High As Israeli Party Votes
abstract: LEAD: Herut, the party of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, selected its list of candidates for Parliament today, and ranked high among them are two new figures Israelis are already beginning to call the ''princes'' of the political right.

headline: Elders Has Stake In Anheuser-Busch
abstract: LEAD: Elders Investments Ltd., an affiliate of the Australian brewer Elders IXL Ltd. disclosed today that it holds almost 1 percent of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the St. Louis-based maker of Budweiser beer. John D. Elliott, the chairman of Elders, confirmed that the company still held the stake - about 0.84 percent - but would not comment on its intentions toward the company.

headline: Home Sales Jump 8.4%, Biggest Rise in 4 Months
abstract: LEAD: Sales of new homes surged 8.4 percent in June, the biggest increase in four months, as rising mortgage rates encouraged potential buyers to close deals before rates increased further.

headline: Chairman and Chief Resigns at Foxmeyer
abstract: LEAD: William Y. Tauscher has resigned as chairman and chief executive of the Foxmeyer Corporation, a big drug distributor that he co-founded and sold to National Intergroup Inc. in 1986 for $343.3 million.

headline: South Korean Leader Calls for Talks With Kim Il Sung
abstract: LEAD: On the anniversary of the liberation of Korea in 1945 from Japanese occupation, the South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo, proposed a meeting with North Korea's leader as Seoul braced for protests by students who want Korea to be the unified nation it once was.

headline: Treasury Prices Tumble on Jobless Report
abstract: LEAD: A report of a steep decline in the nation's unemployment rate in June sent prices of Treasury notes and bonds tumbling and yields soaring yesterday. The discount rates on Treasury bills also soared as this latest sign of economic growth heightened fears that the Federal Reserve would tighten credit to prevent a resurgence of inflation.

headline: Interco Shuns Higher Offer From Suitor
abstract: LEAD: Interco Inc., the nation's largest manufacturer of furniture and shoes, yesterday rejected a takeover offer of $70 a share, or about $2.53 billion, from an investor group.

headline: SEAGRAM'S 'NEGOCIANT': Abdallah Simon; A Superpower in the World of Fine French Wines
abstract: LEAD: A READER of the French gastronomic journal Cuisine et Vins de France wrote an angry letter to the editor recently. He had just been to New York, he said, and was dismayed to discover that fine French wines were much cheaper there than in Paris.

headline: Bulgarian Party Chief Ousts A Key Proponent of Change
abstract: LEAD: Todor Zhivkov, the Communist Party chief of Bulgaria, has bolstered his position by ousting a proponent of changes similar to those of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, Western diplomats said today.

headline: G.A.O. Lifts Bailout Estimates by 25%
abstract: LEAD: The General Accounting Office said today that it would cost at least 25 percent more than it had estimated to clean up the nation's savings industry.

headline: Market Place; Basic Industries: A Closer Look
abstract: LEAD: FOR some investment professionals, it is back to basics - basic industries, that is. Stocks of companies in such areas as chemicals, steel, paper and forest products are undervalued and offer buying opportunities, thanks to stronger earnings, leaner operations and an improved outlook for exports, these professionals insist.

headline: I.B.M.'s European Goal
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to increase its European sales by 10 percent in 1988, the president of IBM Europe, Michael Armstrong, said today at a conference here. I.B.M.

headline: Coniston Wins Round In Gillette Lawsuits
abstract: LEAD: A Federal district judge in Boston said yesterday that the Gillette Company had violated a Securities and Exchange Commission rule by running a misleading newspaper advertisement that helped it win a proxy battle with Coniston Partners this spring.

headline: Official Sees Rate Stability
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the International Monetary Fund's chief policy-making committee said today that he thought the recent round of interest rate increases was over. H. Onno Ruding, who is also

headline: Doubts Emerge About Plan To Aid Texas Savings Units
abstract: LEAD: With only one of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's three completed merger deals in Texas having attracted much new cash from investors, some experts fear that the agency's slowly moving plan to close or merge more than 130 of the state's savings and loan institutions could hurt healthy institutions.

headline: Hungary Tries Letting Its Unions Be Unions
abstract: LEAD: Three times since the last week in August, the Hungarian press has carried unusual reports of brief strikes in a coal mine, a printing plant and an optical factory. Even more surprisingly, the articles have indicated that the outcomes have favored the strikers.

headline: THOUSANDS MARCH IN BALTIC CAPITALS, AIRING RESENTMENT
abstract: LEAD: Tens of thousands of demonstrators, some demanding independence from Moscow, marched through the capitals of the three Baltic republics tonight to mark the anniversary of the 1939 Nazi-Soviet pact that led to the Soviet takeover of their region.

headline: Murat Khan Journal; A Place Where the Broken People Are Mended
abstract: LEAD: ''Bomb shrapnel had almost torn his shoulder off,'' Dr. Csaba Hethalmi recalled matter of factly about a young Afghan guerrilla he had treated the month before. ''His shoulder blade was broken in a couple of pieces. We did several operations. He was with us for three weeks and then he went straight back to fight.

headline: F.C.C. Approves 2 Settlements by Gencorp
abstract: LEAD: In a decision that may provide the model for resolving the highest-stakes licensing dispute in broadcasting history, the Federal Communications Commission approved settlement agreements today that clear the way for Gencorp Inc. to sell a Los Angeles television station and a Memphis radio station for about $217.5 million.

headline: Pillsbury's Pay To Ex-Official
abstract: LEAD: The Pillsbury Company, which is in the midst of a reorganization after a loss of $69 million in 1987, has agreed to pay its former chairman $75,000 a month for two years, a person close to the company said today.

headline: Market Place; A Takeover Bid Revives Interco
abstract: LEAD: A HOSTILE takeover bid has worked magic on the stock of Interco, a St. Louis company not highly rated by Wall Street, but one whose subsidiaries in shoes, furniture and apparel are among the best known in the country.

headline: Henley Plan On Splitting
abstract: LEAD: Henley Group Inc. yesterday provided details of its plan, announced in March, to split into two separate public companies. The two companies would be Wheelabrator Group Inc., which would hold Henley's refuse-to-energy assets, and the new Henley Group, which would get the remaining assets, mainly in manufacturing and chemicals.

headline: Fed's View Of Foreigners Now Tougher
abstract: LEAD: In deciding to change how it treats foreign governmental entities that seek to acquire banks in the United States, the Federal Reserve Board has turned its back on a strongly worded 1983 memorandum that Paul A. Volcker, then the chairman, sent to Congress.

headline: Report Says Debt Crisis Lacks a Quick Solution
abstract: LEAD: No acceptable solution to the debt crisis in the third world will be found in the near future unless developing countries pay out less money and achieve faster economic growth, the World Bank said today.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * American Barrick Resources Corp., Toronto, which is engaged in the mining of gold, petroleum and natural gas and coal, appointed Marshall A. Cohen, president of Olympia & York Enterprises Corp., to be a director.

headline: Competition For Insurers
abstract: LEAD: Competition will increase among life-and-health and property-and-casualty insurers between now and 1995, according to the results of a study released Thursday.

headline: LITHUANIANS PLAN MEMORIAL TO JEWS
abstract: LEAD: Authorities in Vilnius, the capital of the Lithuanian republic, have authorized construction of what would apparently be the first Holocaust memorial in the Soviet Union, according to an American involved in the project.

headline: On Czechoslovak Mountain, Piety and Politics
abstract: LEAD: Teen-age girls, holding hands in a circle, recited a psalm. ''This is probably the only place we can do this publicly,'' one of them said later.

headline: Two Churches in Paris Battle Across the Lefebvre Schism
abstract: LEAD: It was a battle for the hearts, minds and souls of thousands of traditionalist followers of Marcel Lefebvre, the dissident Archbishop who was excommunicated Thursday.

headline: Marietta to Buy Gould Division
abstract: LEAD: As part of the continuing divestiture of its military businesses, Gould Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its Ocean Systems division to the Martin Marietta Corporation, a major military contractor. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The division, which makes underseas surveillance systems for use against submarines, posted revenues of about $100 million in 1987.

headline: Excerpts From the President's Speech to the U.N.
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's address to the 43d General Assembly of the United Nations yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.

headline: Solzhenitsyn, in Exile, Is Asked to Join Soviet Panel
abstract: LEAD: Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the exiled Russian writer, has been invited to join a committee that will supervise the building of a Soviet memorial honoring the victims of Stalin's repression, an organizer of the project said today.

headline: U.S. and U.N.: Stating Case For Big Role
abstract: LEAD: Mary E. Baker, 82 years old, remembers the evening 24 years ago when Adlai Stevenson asked her to found a chapter of the United Nations Association here.

headline: Squeeze on U.S. Agency Seen As Result of Savings Rescues
abstract: LEAD: The flurry of rescues of savings institutions in the last three weeks may have left the insurance fund of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in a troubling cash squeeze.

headline: California Savings Rescue Begun by Federal Agency
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today placed the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., in receivership and injected $250 million in cash to return it to solvency.

headline: Medserv Chief Returns From Russia With Deal
abstract: LEAD: Dennis A. Sokol arrived from the Soviet Union via London on the Concorde yesterday morning and complained, ''I'm tired.'' But Mr. Sokol had two agreements in his pocket to provide health care services to the Russians.

headline: Corn, Soybeans Fall Again As Does Rain in Farm Belt
abstract: LEAD: Corn and soybean prices continued to fall yesterday, largely because more of the Farm Belt received modest rainfall and partly as a result of the liquidation of sell orders that could not be executed during Monday's sharp declines.

headline: McCann-Erickson Wins Champion Plugs
abstract: LEAD: The Detroit office of McCann-Erickson, the agency for General Motors' Chevrolet, has been awarded the Champion Spark Plug Company business, which, trade sources say, could bill up to $15 million.

headline: ANTI-U.S. ATTACKS SPREAD IN PANAMA
abstract: LEAD: The regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama has widened its harassment of American officials in recent weeks as a way of forcing the United States to lift punitive financial measures against the country, senior Administration officials said.

headline: Patents; Tapping the Energy Of Geothermal Steam
abstract: LEAD: Engineers at the Unocal Corporation have designed a system that makes it easier to tap the energy of geothermal steam.

headline: Market Place; Underleveraged Food Retailers
abstract: LEAD: LEVERAGE, in the financial sense, is a word not normally associated with radishes, English muffins, London broils and deli salads. But the way the supermarket industry is going, it probably should be.

headline: Alajarvi Journal; Boys of Summer in the Midnight Sun
abstract: LEAD: It is the time of year when night in much of Finland means the sun lowers itself onto the horizon and perches there until morning, when you can read on a park bench at midnight and when this northern nation's boys of summer thrill their countrymen in contests of pesapallo, or Finnish baseball.

headline: Eritrean Rebels Emphasize Women's Rights
abstract: LEAD: ''The difficulties started just when I was born,'' Besrate Mengeste said, describing the life of women in traditional society in the Eritrean region of north Ethiopia.

headline: Maxwell Is Joining Fight for Macmillan
abstract: LEAD: In his latest effort to gain a large publishing foothold in the United States, Robert Maxwell, the British entrepreneur, yesterday offered to buy Macmillan Inc. for $80 a share, or about $2.06 billion.

headline: Forstmann And Pullman Reach Deal
abstract: LEAD: Forstmann Little & Company and the Pullman Company have reached a definitive merger agreement under which Pullman would receive about $650 million.

headline: 1.5 Million Sudanese Homeless After Floods
abstract: LEAD: About 1.5 million of Khartoum's 4 million people are without food or shelter after floods devastated the Sudanese capital last week, Government officials said today.

headline: Salvadoran Army Starts a Shake-Up
abstract: LEAD: At a time of coup rumors, back-room maneuvering and some handholding from the American Embassy, the Salvadoran Army high command has begun making major command changes that could affect the course of the civil war.

headline: Corrections
abstract: LEAD: The Personal Finance column on Aug. 21 about tax planning misstated the cutoff point for the exemption to the Alternative Minimum Tax. For a married couple filing a joint return, the exemption is reduced at the rate of 25 cents for each $1 of alternative minimum taxable income above $150,000 ($112,500 for single taxpayers).

headline: Managing Crises by Taking to the Airwaves
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the Samurai crisis hit the American Suzuki Motor Corporation in June, the company turned to video. Right after Consumer Reports magazine declared that the Samurai had flunked its road tests, Suzuki's general manager, N. Douglas Mazza, mailed videotapes to the company's dealers. On screen, Mr.

headline: Zayre Discloses F.T.C. Notice
abstract: LEAD: The Zayre Corporation said today that it had received a notice that the Haft family of Washington intended to seek Federal antitrust permission to purchase more than $15 million worth of its stock.

headline: Contra Officer Gets New Job To Soften His Military Role
abstract: LEAD: The leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels have announced an expected realignment that removes Col. Enrique Ber mudez as chief field commander for the contras but allows him to continue to supervise all military planning.

headline: Rig Count Falls by 5
abstract: LEAD: The number of working domestic oil and gas rigs fell by five this week, to 940, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. Last week the rig count jumped by 51, to 945. A year ago this week, the count was 998, the company said. Baker Hughes's rig count, a widely watched index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil as of Friday, not the number of rigs producing oil.

headline: American Soldiers in Panama Exchange Fire With Intruders
abstract: LEAD: American soldiers exchanged gunfire with unidentified intruders spotted twice at a United States military installation near the Panama Canal, the United States Southern Command reported today.

headline: French Left's Wooing of Center Is Dealt 2 Setbacks
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Michel Rocard's efforts to open up his Socialist Government to the political center faltered this week as a result of two highly embarrassing clashes with new Cabinet ministers.

headline: Manhattan,inc. Plans Advertising to Trade
abstract: LEAD: This week Manhattan,inc., the business publication whose ad revenues were hurt by last October's stock market crash, is going to start its first advertising to the trade in three years. It will be done in-house and will run in The New York Times, Advertising Age and Adweek. Additional advertising, aimed at building circulation, will run on six radio stations.

headline: Wall St. Unruffled by Drexel Case; Highlights of the Investigation
abstract: LEAD: Major developments in insider cases related to the Boesky scandal:  May 12, 1986: Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Dennis Levine of Drexel Burnham Lambert of making $12.6 million in illegal trading on inside information. He agrees to surrender the money, plead guilty to criminal charges and aid the inquiry.

headline: Patents; New Designs For Sports Equipment:
abstract: LEAD: Standard sports can still generate attention from inventors.

headline: S.E.C. Assails Brokerages In '83 Default
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today harshly criticized securities firms for their practices in the 1983 default on muncipal bonds issued by the Washington Public Power Supply System.

headline: Tokyo Stock Prices Plunge With the Dollar Up Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Share prices plunged this morning in thin trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, while the dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen.

headline: Talks on Angola Fight Are to Continue Today
abstract: LEAD: Citing progress ''in overcoming a number of obstacles,'' American diplomats said today that talks here over the withdrawal of 50,000 Cuban troops from Angola would continue on Thursday, a day beyond schedule.

headline: Text of Agreement on Southwestern Africa
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of the agreement initialed by delegations from Angola, Cuba and South Africa in New York on July 13. The statement was subsequently approved by their Governments and made public today.

headline: Confusion Causes a Run
abstract: LEAD: A case of mistaken identity spurred a $2 million run on a Chinatown savings institution Thursday. Hundreds of customers lined up at the Elmhurst Federal Savings and Loan Association to withdraw money after confusing the association with a financially troubled bank in the suburb of Elmhurst. The assets of that institution, the United Security Bank, were frozen by a judge last week.

headline: U.S. Film Industry Assails Seoul's Curbs
abstract: LEAD: The American film industry today filed a major trade complaint against South Korea, charging that it is maintaining unfair barriers against American motion picture exports and tolerating piracy of American films in its home video market.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Drossman Wins Ellesse
abstract: LEAD: Ellesse, acquired by Reebok International Ltd. in January, has moved its in-house account to Drossman Lehmann Marino without a competition. The budget is expected to exceed $3 million. The $25 million agency plans to develop print and television campaign for the sports shoe and sportswear maker.

headline: Haitian Vows 'Irreversible Democracy'
abstract: LEAD: The head of the new military Government, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril, said today that his goal was to establish ''an irreversible democracy'' in Haiti.

headline: 26-Mall Partnership Is 'Developer's Dream'
abstract: LEAD: PruSimon, a joint venture formed by Melvin Simon & Associates Inc. and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, is likely to make Herbert Simon an even more prominent force in commercial real estate.

headline: Treasury Prices Off in Slow Day
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in slow trading yesterday, pushed down by a drop in the dollar and an economic report that suggested that the pace of the expansion and inflation continued to accelerate in the second quarter.

headline: Face in Crowd Is Premier's
abstract: LEAD: Even after the assassination of Olof Palme two and a half years ago, a Swedish Prime Minister mingles with election crowds here in a way that would be unthinkable for American Presidential candidates.

headline: 9.4% Deposit Notes By Mitsubishi Unit
abstract: LEAD: The New York branch of Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. is offering $100 million of 9.4 percent deposit notes due in 1993 at an initial price of 99.60, to yield 9.515 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: Talking Deals; F.D.I.C.'s Savvy On Bank's Taxes
abstract: LEAD: NO one likes to pay taxes. That includes the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which helps explain why the agency last Friday picked the NCNB Corporation to rebuild the crippled banking network of the First Republicbank Corporation.

headline: Saatchi Seeks to List Its Shares in Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: Saatchi & Saatchi announced that it had filed an application to list its shares on the Tokyo stock exchange, and that it expected to begin trading in mid-October. It has already filed a securities registration statement with the Japanese Finance Ministry for a public offering of 1.56 million shares, at a price to be fixed at the time of issue.

headline: Daily Car Sales Down 7.2%
abstract: LEAD: Sales of domestic cars and light trucks ran at a daily rate of 34,946 units in August, down 7.2 percent from the same month last year, according to final industry reports.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Mistral, a Munich, West Germany maker of windsurf boards, and sportswear, to Trahan, Burden & Charles, Baltimore, for advertising and public relations.

abstract: LEAD: A Moscow lawyer recently overheard a conversation that went something like this:

headline: Sandinistas and Contras Resume Some Talks
abstract: LEAD: Representatives of the Nicaraguan Government met with rebel leaders today for the first time in three months, but both sides remained sharply divided on ways to end seven years of civil war.

headline: Dusty Titles Add Luster To Publisher' Profits
abstract: LEAD: In the late 1930's Vanguard Press published two books by Dr. Seuss, ''And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street'' and ''The 500 Hats of Bartholomew Cubbins.'' While the author later moved to Random House, the books are still earning money for Vanguard and the 84-year-old author a half-century later.

headline: Third World Bank Aid
abstract: LEAD: Commercial banks must do more to help highly indebted middle-income countries by mixing new money with debt-reduction plans, Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today.

headline: Dissident Group Says It Shot Eldest Son of Iraqi President
abstract: LEAD: An Iraqi opposition group backed by Iran said today that its agents in Baghdad had shot and seriously wounded the eldest son of President Saddam Hussein.

headline: Matrix Accepts Bayer Unit's Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Matrix Corporation announced that it had accepted an offer to be acquired by Agfa Gevaert Inc. for $10 a share, or $115 million. The merger agreement was approved at a special meeting of the Matrix board.

headline: Postal Service Is Criticized By G.A.O. on Perot Contract
abstract: LEAD: The General Accounting Office criticized the United States Postal Service in a preliminary report yesterday for the contract it awarded without bidding to a company owned by H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire.

headline: Afghan Guerrilla Campaign Sputters
abstract: LEAD: Soviet and Afghan attacks on positions captured by Afghan insurgents have recently stalled and in some areas reversed the guerrilla campaign to topple the Kabul Government, Western diplomats said today.

headline: How NBC Union Lost Olympics
abstract: LEAD: When NBC goes to Seoul, South Korea, this summer to televise the Summer Olympics, 488 of the 1,100 people in its entourage will be technicians - camera operators and video crews. But of those, none will be American employees who belong to the biggest union at the network, the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians.

headline: Ford Reports Record Net For Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Bolstered by record overseas earnings that more than offset a slight decline at home, the Ford Motor Company reported today that it earned a record $1.66 billion, or $3.43 a share, in the second quarter.

headline: Polaroid's Stock Advances On Rumor of Fuji Interest
abstract: LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation announced yesterday that it would give ''due consideration'' to an unsolicited takeover bid from Roy E. Disney, the West Coast businessman and nephew of Walt Disney.

headline: U.S. Embassy Holding Up Visas for Soviet Emigres
abstract: LEAD: The American Embassy has temporarily stopped issuing refugee visas to Soviet citizens seeking to emigrate to the United States, preventing thousands of Armenians and dozens of Jews from moving to the West.

headline: CONSUMER RATES

headline: Contractor Fund Raising Called Inquiry Topic
abstract: LEAD: During wiretapped telephone conversations, a former executive of the Unisys Corporation told military contractors they should raise money for Florida charities to influence decisions by Representative William V. Chappell Jr. of Florida, NBC News reported tonight.

headline: European Talks On Currency
abstract: LEAD: Central bankers in the European Community took the first steps today toward a European monetary union, but some said creation of a common currency or a European central bank remained distant goals.

headline: BURMA RULES OUT NEW CONCESSIONS
abstract: LEAD: Confrontation between the Burmese Government and its people intensified today as huge crowds filled the streets to demand democratic elections and the President responded on radio that no further concessions would be made.

headline: A Modern Computer Chip Is Born
abstract: LEAD: In the early years, creating an integrated circuit began with a designer guiding a group of draftsmen who painstakingly mapped out a circuit on drafting paper. Today, the draftsmen are gone and circuit designers sit in front of powerful engineering work stations. They lay out and test a new chip design on a computer screen before storing the design on a special tape for transmission to a semiconductor factory.

headline: Mexican Shift on Economy Seen
abstract: LEAD: The contentiousness and turmoil of their Presidential election largely behind them, Mexicans are once again focusing on the country's longest-running drama: the perils of the economy.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Subscription Promoter Tries Charity
abstract: LEAD: UP against some of the most high-powered marketing sophisticates in magazine subscription sales, M. Richard Parisi, president of Great American Magazines, is nonetheless determined to make his mark against the likes of American Family Publishers, Publishers Clearing House and Magazine Marketplace.

headline: Talks Continue on Sale Of American Savings
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the Robert M. Bass Group negotiated through the day on the purchase of the American Savings and Loan Association of Stockton, Calif., the nation's largest insolvent savings and loan association.
